The employer is not complying with the Governor¿s COVID-19 mandate in regard to social distancing between employees and the public. 5. The employer is requiring employees to reuse the extra swabs that come in test kits to essentially make their own separate test kits. Hazard.Desc.Loc: The Employer is not enforcing social distancing so that employees stay at least six-feet apart to reduce their potential exposure to the COVID-19 virus. For employee workstations that are less than 6-feet apart, the Employer has installed partitions between the workstations that are too low to be effective in preventing the possible spread of the virus. California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Section 3380. Personal Protective Devices. The Employer does not enforce the use of face coverings inside the offices. For instance, some Managers refuse to wear face coverings inside the building. Complainant notes: As of the week of 7-13-20, all EEs have been ordered to work from home. However, prior to this stay at home order, ER did not enforce social distancing and PPE per above. Complainant would like to file this complaint so the workplace will be safer when the stay at home order is lifted.

The employer only has two plastic face shields available for employee use, and they are not being cleaned between use. 4. The employer is not following State of New York COVID-19 requirements by not requiring customers to wear face masks when not maintaining a 6 foot distance. 5. Employees have been told to follow COVID-19 safety precautions until it starts affecting business, such as when customer lines are getting too long. 6. The employer has not installed any physical barriers to protect employees from customers.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Employer not providing hand sanitizer|Employer not enforcing social distancing|Employer not disinfecting/deep cleaning work place|Employer not providing PPE such as gloves, masks, face shields, etc. Shipping/Inspection work in enclosed areas . At times, there are 3-4 people in the inspection area, less than 2 ft apart. This same scenario is in shipping also. Both areas have many employees touching the same equipment. Many of the machines are closer than 6 ft. The company told the employees they could not ""find"" hand sanitizer, disinfectant, or PPE. Many of the employees have brought their own disinfectant in, but machines, computors, work appliances, bathrooms, doorknobs, common areas are not disinfected. Given the distance between employees, masks should be given to employees and mandated to be worn if the 6 ft distance can not be adhered to. A few employees have been off work with Covid-19 symptoms (they were not tested because they were not ""bad"" enough, however they were instructed by their physicians to stay home for two weeks). The plant has not been deep cleaned even though they have suspected employees to have had the virus. This inattention to mandates given by the government puts ALL employees and their families at risk for infection. I would like to give my name, but in the past they have fired employees who have complained about safety issues. The company had a meeting with the employees when the essential business mandate was first put into place. They told the employees if they found disinfectant, to buy it and bring in their receipt and they would be reimbursed. However, other business' are supplying face masks (fabric ones), hand sanitizer, disinfectants and cleaning their businesses, so obviously these items CAN be obtained. This company is blatantly disregarding all safety measures mandated by the governor. All employees are at risk for infection.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1 Fifty to sixty employees working in the Bullpen are not social distancing, both employees and supervisors are also not wearing masks, exposing employees to Covid-19 transmission. 2 Manual pallet jacks have wheels in disrepair, and dont turn or turn the opposite direction of intended travel, and strike employees causing injury. 3 In the APP department, the APP machines have mail bags that are supposed to be secured by hooks. Many of these hooks are broken , and some bags have to be manually tied onto the supports. The packages ejected into the bags miss the bags that are poorly secured due to broken / missing hooks, and strike the workers. 4 There are no sanitizing stations provided in this area for employees to sanitize hands while working. 5 The supervisors prevent or do not allow employees to use the lavatory / restroom facilities when they need to or to wash hands.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Through the EOC, we've received 9 calls about 8 - 9 different locations (one unknown) with one call coming in directly to me. Amazon's Director of Global Health & Safety assured me that she will address each one with specifics so including this table with phone/fax letter. Amazon COVID 19 concerns reported through WA Governor¿s hotline, March ¿ April 2020 Everett SWA1 3/30/2020 Security guard and workers too close to flex workers. Self-check in too close to line. There is little to no enforcement of 6¿ social distancing. There are 15 people waiting to get in; line backs up. People are going up and down ramp delivering and returning packages, overlapping and next to each other. 410 Terry Avenue N, Seattle 3/31/3030 Amazon is failing to protect its workers (and therefore its customers and everyone else) in many ways, including failing to provide paid sick leave so that sick or compromised workers are more likely to come to work, putting work stations and workers too close together, failing to provide protection such as hand sanitizer, goggles, masks, and gloves, and punishing workers who express concerns and/or have underlying health conditions. Warehouse, 18323 Andover Park West, Seattle 4/1/2020 This is a warehouse where food delivery packages are put together and delivered throughout the entire Seattle area. Over a hundred and fifty people in one small building with no hand sanitizer available nor wipes. Absolutely no enforcement of 6-foot distance. Talked to management several times and they said they don't have time to implement the procedures. One person infected will create havoc for thousands because this is a grocery delivery business. BFI4, 21005 64th Ave S, Kent 3/30/2020 Many workers in places, including management, not allowing for social distancing. No cleaning after positive cases of employees. Whole Foods, 2210 Westlake Ave, Seattle 3/30/2020 Store is not enforcing social distancing between team members. Many use public transit for long distances potentially exposing themselves and others. Buyers sit 2-3 ft. away from each other in the back office for hours. Same for employee training done on computers. Employees are not washing hands or changing gloves. Store leader is allowing 100 customers in the store at one time (not counting the many employees). AMZL Warehouse, 1101 SW 16th , Renton Business is not enforcing social distancing and allowing sick employees to come into work, putting others at risk. Amazon, 2121 7th Avenue, Seattle Building staff remains on site. Often facilities such as the mailroom are fully staffed. This is true for all Amazon buildings and includes janitors, security, and reception. Social distancing guidelines are not possible to follow in many buildings. PPE is not available. Warehouse, Center St, Dupont Amazon staff here are walking around in the way of people working and not following social distancing. Costco and Walmart limit customers for everyone¿s protection but Amazon is not promoting social distancing. Two people were fired for complaining about Amazon's practices. Apparently, Amazon has a firing policy for reporting concerns. Delivery driver, 27th Avenue between Jefferson and Cherry, Seattle on April 24 AM An Amazon delivery truck driver made several deliveries near here with multiple packages not wearing a mask or practicing social distancing. He got close to elderly people potentially exposing them and others from multiple package handling. Didn¿t notice whether gloves were worn. Amazon distribution center, no address listed Workers too close to each other; no social distancing and no masks worn. There was a positive COVID 19 employee working here April 12 and they didn¿t deep clean until April 22. Workers worked in the area the entire time.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer has not identified and implemented necessary workplace controls (engineering, administrative, work practices) to reduce employee exposure to the COVID-19 virus such as barrier sneeze guards, additional training, social distancing practices, increased cleaning, utilization of face coverings and masks, etc. per OSHA publication # 3990-3 2020 https://www.osha.gov/Publications/OSHA3990.pdf and CDC guidelines. 2. The employer has not identified specific type(s) of personal protective equipment (PPE) (i.e. gloves, masks, etc.) that need to be available to reduce employee exposure to the COVID-19 virus. 3. Adequate infection control prevention policies and procedures are not being implemented and enforced to avert the spread of the COVID-19 virus as employees are not required to wear face coverings and/or masks.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: SH-900 Logs of Work-related Injuries and Illnesses were not provided by the end of the business day following the request. RN exposure records were not provided to Authorized Employee Representatives (AER's) following a written request. The employer did not conduct an appropriate hazard assessment related to employee exposure to COVID-19. The employer did not provide adequate personal protective equipment (PPE) to nurses exposed to COVID-19. Hazard.Desc.Loc: Edinburgh Community Schools is trying to do in-person education. There are a lot of students and not a lot of space for these students. With the start of a new semester, many students have returned to in-person classes instead of online. This has added many more students to each class a teacher is in charge of. Before the return of these students, many teachers were unable to keep the students socially distanced and now it is even more of a challenge. With more students in the halls and classes, there is a greater risk of spreading Covid-19, causing more strain on teachers and paraprofessionals, and putting more at risk for severe health problems for those with underlying conditions. Sporting events are still occurring, but those in attendance are not required to wear face coverings or social distance. There are signs posted reminding and stating it is required for all to wear masks and social distance, but these rules are not enforced by administration. Administration has stated that they will not switch to hybrid or virtual education unless told to do so by Governor Eric Holcomb, even if and when cases increase.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: It is alleged that: Two employees have tested positive for the Coronavirus on or about May 4 and May 13, 2020. The employer is not following the recommendations (as noted in paragraph two) put in place by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) to help prevent and slow the spread of COVID-19 in the workplace. Safety practices for workers who may have had exposure to a person with suspected or confirmed COVID-10 are recommended as follows: Pre-screen employees to ensure an employee does not have a temperature upon arriving at work. Employees who have been exposed (the time the employee had symptoms and 2 days prior to symptoms) should self-monitor under the supervision of their employer. The employer should provide employees with masks and gloves. Employees are not able to self distance on the lines as at times it takes two to lift heavier boxes. Masks are not being worn by the majority of employees. The employer should ensure employees social distance when feasible and, the employer should clean and disinfect all areas such as offices, bathrooms, common areas and shared electronic equipment routinely.

We have a full packed schedule. Seeing 4-5 patients across at a time. There is not a safe distance between patients as far as covid-19 regulations. We are seeing normal appts not what is instructed. Employer said ordered disposable gowns but those have not arrived so the girls who have already returned to work are having to come home and wash their dirty uniforms every night. Employer is not thinking through and not following proper protocols. Some of them yes, but as far as how full the clinic will be and going against missouri govenor and st.louis county executive order as well as the aao anf ada, i dont believe he is being completely safe about reopening his business for his employees or patients.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1: Although legally required to publicly encourage all injuries to be reported, whenever an employee tries to file a report about an injury they are highly discouraged by management. 2: Supervisors cleaning up blood incorrectly, they wear PPE but do not use any kind of cleaning supply to clean the contact surface, other than a towel. 4: There were 3 reported cases of COVID 19 in the plant, they only shut down for 14 hours before resuming production and also required employees to work an extra day that they are usually not required to. Increasing the possibility of even further contamination. 5: Wet floors and puddles without a caution sign. 6: There was an incident where a fork truck (or high bay) driver had ran materials too far into the shelves and caused damage to the safety containment fence on the other side. Therefore it was unsafe to stand in the area due to the risk of falling material. The material in question was poorly banded together as well and seemed to be stacked in a manor that was unstable. When several employees reported this to management, it took them a week to fix and they did not block the area off from employees.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer failed to give written notice, within one business day, that people at the worksite may have been exposed to COVID-19. Written notice may include, but is not limited to, personal service, email, or text message, if it can reasonably be anticipated to be received by the employee within one business day of sending. The notice shall include the disinfection plan required by Labor Code section 6409.6(a)(4). Employees are receiving notification greater than the one business day. T8 CCR 3205(c)(3)(B)(3) 2. The employer is not following applicable orders and guidance from the State of California (CDPH) and the local health department related to COVID-19 hazards and prevention by allowing employees and customers into the store without face coverings. T8 CCR 3205(c)(2)(F) & (c)(6)(l)

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Compression piston machines (JIGs) are not guarded where the piston comes out. Employees get their hands caught resulting in injuries. An employee was injured at the end of June and another was recently injured. 2. Employees are injured from carts and machines that have sharp edges causing cuts and bruises. 3. A 25 foot, 4-5 inch diameter galvanized steel pipe for compressed air fell from the ceiling and hit an employee on the back. This has happened two other times. 4. Employees are required to work in hot temperatures with no circulating air and no water. There is no water in the work area and employees cannot leave the area except to take two breaks for the whole day. 5. Employees are exposed to diesel exhaust which is released from an autoclave and there is no ventilation in the area. 6. Employees are not required to wear masks and there is no sanitizing of the area or hand sanitizer available where there have been employees with Covid-19. The employer is not doing anything for Covid-19. Work stations are 6 feet apart but employees walk all around to get parts and cannot social distance.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Hazard Location: School Buses and Bus Garage Transportation is deliberately disregarding COVID-19 protocols and guidelines. They wear masks under their chins while driving, do not sanitize the bus after students get off, congregate in a small breakroom without masks on, do not open windows for air circulation, and do not have students sanitize before or after getting on the bus. They also do not sanitize when in the building. There was a director that followed COVID guidelines but they were harassed out of their job because the drivers did not want to comply. There is a new director that has made the breakroom open again and does not have the drivers comply with any COVID protocols. The seats on the buses are already overcrowded, with the majority being 3 students to a seat. This situation is incredibly unsafe. The buses see more of a variety of students than classrooms and nothing is being done to keep the students safe. The Superintendent and the school board is well aware of the non-compliance and will not do anything to change it.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 8311 Ne Vancouver Mall Vancouver, WA 98662 There are three complaints for this employer at the same location. 7/10/2020 The hazard I am reporting is COVID-19 related. Appropriate and state mandated protocol is not being followed in order to ensure employee and customer safety. First, temperatures of employees entering the building are not being taken at all. The only time someone gets their temperature taken is when the individual requests to have their temperature taken, at that point we are told to do it ourselves, which increases risk of exposure due to increased touching of a service, and no sanitation happening in between uses. There is no log being kept of employee temperatures. Additionally, proper mask wearing in not being implemented. Employee¿s are wearing their masks below their noses, or even under their chins. Employees also remove their masks as soon as the restaurant closes to the public, and they then do their closing duties around other employees without social distancing or wearing masks. Even more concerning, we recently (last week) had an employee miss work due to Covid like symptoms, he posted on his social media about having a cough and a fever for over a week that he couldn't kick, and that it was the most sick he has ever been in his life. He claims to have taken a covid-19 test and got a negative result, but I do not believe proof of this was provided. He also came back to work 2 days after posting that he was so sick from fever that he felt like he was dying, and when he returned to work he still had a cough. I am unsure if his temperature was taken upon his return to work, but I feel it is highly unlikely. Our company protocol is that when you are sick you are supposed to be in communication with corporate and they make the determination of when it is safe to return to work, however our management has not enforced this protocol, and they are taking it upon themselves to make the determination of when a sick employee can return ( corporate suggests 3 days after being symptom free, however management approved return while said employee still has symptoms). There have been multiple other sick employees who have not had to communicate with the corporate office either. All employees at this location have been exposed to these unsafe working conditions. 7/7/2020 One employee very sick for two weeks and was tested positive for COVID-19. Employee was sick on the 4th and allowed to come back to work on the 6th. They did not disinfect the restaurant or do anything about it. 7/8/2020 An employee with COVID symptoms returned to work without the mandatory 72 hours of being fever free per protocol. 20 + employees in contact with the person plus all the guests in the building.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Three violations of the State of Indiana Executive order 20-50. Violation 1; Section 4 a, subsection iv of exec. order 20-50: Wherein "complying with social distancing requirements established by the CDC, including maintaining six-foot social distancing for both employees and members of the general public." The employer of Java House has neglected to take action or make a statement on the existence of allowed bar seating less than 3ft where open beverages are prepared to be served to the general public and employees are within less than a 6ft radius of sometimes unmasked individuals drinking/ eating at the bar. Multiple employees have raised concerns with the owner via verbal and written complaints including citing exec. order 20-50 as well as an ignored request of barriers to protect employees. Violation 2; Section 4 b, subsection i of exec. order 20-50: Wherein "All Hoosier businesses are required to place clearly visible signage at their public and employee entrances notifying that face coverings are required for all individuals entering the business." There is no posted signage notifying customers or employees of the state mask requirement on the Java House premises. Violation 3; Section 4 b, subsection iii of exec. order 20-50: Wherein "Businesses should only admit those customers, clients, vendors, and other visitors who wear face coverings." The employer has stated that Java House does not comply with the Indiana state mask mandate on the grounds that it negatively impacts "customer experience." Despite employees concerns of our health, safety, and the lives of our loved ones.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Employees are being required to wear face masks which according to OSHA needs to have a proper fit test and medical evaluation to require. ¿Nevertheless, it is within the discretion of an employer to require and mandate the continuous use of facemasks. If an employer requires its employees to wear facemasks, the masks must be National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH)-approved and used in the context of a comprehensive, written respiratory protection program that includes fit-testing, training, and medical exams. The appropriate form of mask/respirator will depend on the type of employee exposure and on the transmission pattern of COVID-19.¿ Employees should be asked to but not required as above mentioned. There have been concerns with breathing as we work in tight areas at times and the mask prevent good oxygen flow. If requirement is needed then medical evaluation needs to be provided each employee.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Single use N95 respirators are being re-used for multiple patient encounters. They are donned and doffed repeatedly, risking contamination. 2. Storage is in a plastic bag or paper bag that is not protecting the mask from physical manipulation or damage. Used masks are collected at the end of the day in a bag and sanitized; the University refuses to release data or other information proving the safety or efficacy of this. The respirators are labeled for single use only and the manufacturer webpage states they are not supporting sanitation or re-use. 3. PAPRs are not available for staff that previously failed respirator fit testing. No additional training is provided. 4. We are not informed of safety measures unique to the reused masks. Employees are given respirators that are damaged and do not pass a user seal fit check; the University has provided no instruction to employees that user seal fit checks are recommended. They are handing us defective safety gear without proper instruction.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: T8CCR 3203 I work for Le Saint Logistics located at 13204 Philadelphia Ave., Fontana, Ca 92337. Recently there was a co-worker who tested positive for covid-19. She has come in contact with other co-workers; however, those workers have not been sent home for self quarantine. The company states they have completed a cleaning of the facility, but it appears they have not. There are no safety protocols in place to protect other employees from spreading the virus, nor are there safety protocols to screen employees daily for temperatures or symptoms. Employees are not wearing face mask to help with spread. I have pre-existing medical conditions that leave me vulnerable to this virus. The company is not showing concern for the safety of their employees or the partnering entities. It would help relieve anxiety and stress of all employees if the company was assessed for any violations and/or advised of safety protocols that should be in place to ensure the safety of all.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Store has a "mask required" policy for employees and customers. No one in the store (salaried management included) is supposed to say anything to customers not wearing masks. There are just signs posted to make it look the the company cares. Customers are aware of this and frequently come in not wearing masks, which is a hazard to the employees who are required to still serve them, per management. 2. It is impossible for employees working on the front end specifically (self checkout and bagging especially) to socially distance from customers, many of whom do not wear masks because there is no enforcement. Cashiers have plexiglass barriers, which helps some, but baggers are still exposed to the customers, who often will get very close to them in an effort to "help." Self checkout workers are required to go to the machine to help the customers and the customers often do not move from in front of the screen, even when asked, creating extreme risks for the workers. 3. It is impossible for customers to socially distance in the long checkout lines for the most part. The company has only continued to cut hours, knowing that less cashiers available causes customers to stand in line closely together or go to a self checkout, where it is not possible to socially distance. Aisles are full of PickUp shoppers and customers and employees are not able to safely keep distanced. Store capacity is limited to half capacity, which may be almost 1000 people, which obviously does not leave room for adequate social distancing nor does it take into account where the customers are at in the store. 4. Kroger had given extra hours in April for cleaning and cashiers to wash hands, but those hours were gone by May or June. Bathrooms are not frequently cleaned, used masks and gloves end up on the ground, and cashiers are only able to wash hands on breaks and lunches now. 5. PPE is provided by Kroger, but gloves in the correct sizes are nearly impossible for the entire store to have. 6. Customers are very aggressive often about the other customers who are not wearing masks. They will yell and scream and sometimes get to a point where I am fearful of what they might do. Management will not always come speak to these people and we no longer have police officers in our store for safety because the company no longer wants to spend the money at this location. 7. An employee tested positive for Covid-19 and the company did not tell associates who may have come in contact with this person. Workers from the department may have known, but any employee could have come in contact with this person at the timeclock or breakroom and no one was told there even was a positive case. There was also no additional cleaning done as a result. 8. Sick employees and employees who have been exposed to Covid-19 are often encouraged to come to work due to the few hours the store has to schedule people.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: On January 24th, the OMB put out a memorandum outlining minimal principles that should be incorporated in order to meet the President's Executive Order for protecting the federal workforce. Other than issuing a mask mandate, our Agency is ignoring most of these principles. This includes: Maximum Telework - while our operations and maintenance workers are not telework eligible, there are many other positions located in the dams that are. Currently, the agency is ignoring the maximum telework mandate and it's business as usual. OMB principles say federal workplaces should be no more than 25% of normal occupancy. There is currently no restrictions or requirements for outside contractors to come into our dams from any place at any time. There is no screening whatsoever. There is supposed to be enhanced cleaning in common use, high touch, high density spaces such as lobbies, restrooms, elevators, and stairwells. This requirement is being ignored. Physical barriers such as plexiglass shields are to be installed where appropriate. This is being ignored. There is supposed to be a Covid-19 Coordination Team or a field office/agency component designee. Our agency doesn't seem to even know what that is. Finally, the Agency is supposed to update Covid-19 workplace plans and consult with the Union. I can say that the Agency has not reached out at all to work with the Union on workplace plans.
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: on january 24th, the omb put out a memorandum outlining minimal principles that should be incorporated in order to meet the president's executive order for protecting the federal workforce. other than issuing a mask mandate, our agency is ignoring most of these principles. this includes: maximum telework - while our operations and maintenance workers are not telework eligible, there are many other positions located in the dams that are. currently, the agency is ignoring the maximum telework mandate and it's business as usual. omb principles say federal workplaces should be no more than 25% of normal occupancy. there is currently no restrictions or requirements for outside contractors to come into our dams from any place at any time. there is no screening whatsoever. there is supposed to be enhanced cleaning in common use, high touch, high density spaces such as lobbies, restrooms, elevators, and stairwells. this requirement is being ignored. physical barriers such as plexiglass shields are to be installed where appropriate. this is being ignored. there is supposed to be a covid-19 coordination team or a field office/agency component designee. our agency doesn't seem to even know what that is. finally, the agency is supposed to update covid-19 workplace plans and consult with the union. i can say that the agency has not reached out at all to work with the union on workplace plans.

Staff share a breakroom where they remove their masks, and they share desks, computers, phones, and bathrooms.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The employer is not following the guidelines set forth in Executive Order 20-81 and for COVID-19 Preparedness Plans for Minnesota businesses, specifically: 1. The facility does not have a written Covid-19 Preparedness Plan in place. 2. The facility has not trained employees on Covid-19 procedures to follow while working. 3. The facility does not ensure employees are wearing facial coverings while working. 4. The facility does not have protocol in place for housekeepers who enter occupied rooms. 5. The facility does not have a health screening process in place to ensure employees are healthy when coming to work. 6. The facility does not have cleaning processes in place for high touch surfaces such as elevators, the arcade room, door handles, and the front desk space. 7. Hotel guests have been bringing trash and used towels to the front desk when housekeeping staff are not available and staff has no protocols in place as to how to handle soiled items from guests. 8. Physical distancing is not enforced in areas where hotel patrons and staff interact.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1) Employees are exposed to infectious disease in that the employer does not enforce the 6 ft. social distancing requirement per CDC guidelines in that the employer does not limit the amount of customers that can enter the store at one time and the employer does not provide shielding (sneeze guards) in between employees and customers that are required to work in close proximity. 2) Employees are exposed to health hazards associated with COVID-19 in that the employer does not require employees and visitors to wear masks per CDC (Center for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines. 3) Employees are exposed to health hazards related to the employer not informing them of when other employees have tested positive for COVID-19 (coronavirus disease) within the facility as in accordance to CDC (Center for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines. 4) Employees are exposed to health hazards related to the employer not cleaning and sanitizing the workplace regularly per CDC (Center for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines after employees tested positive for COVID-19. 5) The employer requires employees to come to work that have received advisement from a healthcare professional to quarantine for COVID-19; exposing employees to infectious diseases in the facility. 6) Employees are exposed to health hazards associated with COVID-19 in that the employer does not screen employees for symptoms of the virus per CDC (Center for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1.Employees were not provided with any kind of training on COVID-19 when returning to the workplace. 2.The employer is not following social distancing guidelines. 3.The employer is providing their employees with personal protective equipment. 4.Cooks are not wearing masks and gloves or practicing proper sanitation, are smoking inside the building and drinking on the cook line. 5.Waitresses are not required to wear masks and are not being provided with personal protective equipment. 6.High contact areas are not being cleaned down; items that are shared on tables such as coffee pots, condiments, sugar caddies, etc. are not being wiped down. 7.The employer says they are sanitizing and cleaning but they are not.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: During this Covid epidemic my employer has glossed over facts, have told employees to lie to health department officials who've investigated claims, and things are constantly getting swept under the rug with corporate investigations. They've exposed multiple employees to Covid, and are halfway doing general measures to guarantee our safety which is second to them making a profit. They refuse to do anything about the masks, except remove a few people from the store to say they're doing something. . The neglect they have shown during the first and second phases of Covid-19 has been grossly negligent to the point of them telling employees to continue to come to work even while they wait on Covid test results thus putting 350-400 people on top of the various community who shop there at major health risks. They brought a Hazmat crew to clean the store one night, while not notifying the employees working during the time, and thus subjected them without prior knowledge to dealing with chemicals. They've threatened, and guilt people into lying during assements, or making them go stand in cold spots to reduce fevers long enough to get an accurate temp reading during the pre-work assessment. Which they encourage you to take at home, as to not waste their time. In fact, the thermometer they used consistently temps people at 94.7,

Hazard.Desc.Loc: COVID-19 The employer has not developed an effective plan to address the specific exposure risks, sources of exposure, routes of transmission and other unique characteristics of SARS-CoV-2. The plan should focus on engineering controls, administrative controls, work practice controls and personal protective equipment. The employer is not informing employees when they have been exposed to employees that have tested positive for COVID-19. 1. The employer is not following the CDC recommendations to protect employees. 2. The employer is not following State, and local safety requirements to protect employees. 3. The employer is not providing sanitary/good housekeeping processes, social distancing processes, or PPE as necessary for employee safety and to reduce exposure. 4. The employer is not communicating adequate information to ensure employees understand and adhere to safe work practices.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Employer does not provide adequate personal protective equipment, administrative controls, engineering controls, or safe work practices to protect employees from exposure to COVID-19 including: 1. Employer permits employees to be within 6-feet of each other throughout the work shift, breaks, and shift change. 2. Employer does not adequately clean and disinfect shared tools, equipment and surfaces that employees touch between use. 3. Employer has not implemented health screening procedures and/or ensured all people who may be sick do not enter the workplace. 4. Employer does not ensure that employees wash their hands after breaks and at other transition times. 5. Employer allows employees to come to work with COVID 19 symptoms.
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: employer does not provide adequate personal protective equipment, administrative controls, engineering controls, or safe work practices to protect employees from exposure to covid-19 including: 1. employer permits employees to be within 6-feet of each other throughout the work shift, breaks, and shift change. 2. employer does not adequately clean and disinfect shared tools, equipment and surfaces that employees touch between use. 3. employer has not implemented health screening procedures and/or ensured all people who may be sick do not enter the workplace. 4. employer does not ensure that employees wash their hands after breaks and at other transition times. 5. employer allows employees to come to work with covid 19 symptoms.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Employer has not developed and implemented a plan/procedure/protocol to protect employees who work in close proximity to customers and co-workers; 2. Employer has not provided personal protective equipment to employees who work in close proximity to customers and co-workers; 3. Employer has not provided hand sanitizer or cleaning materials to employees who work in close proximity to customers and co-workers; Recommendations 1. Contact Mass DPH or local health authority for assistance; 2. Consult CDC and OSHA webpages for assistance; a. Develop an Infectious Disease Preparedness and Response Plan; b. Prepare to Implement Basic Infection Prevention Measures c. Develop Policies and Procedures for Prompt Identification and Isolation of Sick People, if Appropriate d. Develop, Implement, and Communicate about Workplace Flexibilities and Protections; e. Implement Workplace Controls, Engineering Controls, and Administrative Controls; f. Implement Safe Work Practices; g. Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and training in accordance with OSHA standards; h. Communicate and train employee regarding the measures to take to reduce potential exposure; I. SOURCE: Guidance on Preparing the Workplace for COVID-19, OSHA publication 3990-03
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: 1. employer has not developed and implemented a plan/procedure/protocol to protect employees who work in close proximity to customers and co-workers; 2. employer has not provided personal protective equipment to employees who work in close proximity to customers and co-workers; 3. employer has not provided hand sanitizer or cleaning materials to employees who work in close proximity to customers and co-workers; recommendations 1. contact mass dph or local health authority for assistance; 2. consult cdc and osha webpages for assistance; a. develop an infectious disease preparedness and response plan; b. prepare to implement basic infection prevention measures c. develop policies and procedures for prompt identification and isolation of sick people, if appropriate d. develop, implement, and communicate about workplace flexibilities and protections; e. implement workplace controls, engineering controls, and administrative controls; f. implement safe work practices; g. personal protective equipment (ppe) and training in accordance with osha standards; h. communicate and train employee regarding the measures to take to reduce potential exposure; i. source: guidance on preparing the workplace for covid-19, osha publication 3990-03

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. There is concern about the safety of the employees and clients that come through the facility. Employees are considered essential but the only PPE provided are dust masks and it is not required to wear one in the homes. Employees that work in these homes are generally the only people wearing a mask out of 10 people. The only time employees have been required to wear a mask is when we had clients waiting to be picked up after developing a fever at our facility, which has happened twice. 2. It is nearly impossible to stay 6 feet apart in the home and it has never been asked of us by our employer. Having 10 people in the home seems unsafe to me since every 8-10 hours new staff come in from different homes. Even though we are screened before coming in, there are concerns about the child clients who could be bringing the virus in without symptoms. 3. Often times employees run out of cleaning supplies and have to limit its¿ use. Frequently used areas are not being properly cleaned. 4. There is no paid time off offered for our staff. There are no options for employees who are immunocompromised to take time off without losing a substantial amount of income. There was an incident in which a client came in whose mother had a high fever but because she said it was a tooth infection the client came in as normal.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Multiple schools in the Utica District are in violation of MIOSHA Rule 5(8), not allowing remote work, such as: a). Not allowing teachers and support staff (music teachers and literacy coaches) who only teach remotely to work from home. b). Requiring faculty to remain on site the entire workday even if their only in-person duty is getting students off the bus in the morning. c). Requiring teachers who do not instruct at the beginning or end of the workday to remain on site for their planning time rather than being permitted to plan from home. d). Teachers who work with virtual students and face to face students on alternating days are required to report to work on days when they exclusively teach virtually. 2. Social distancing is not being practiced or enforced at Shelby Jr High, Davis Jr High, and Eppler Jr High. 3. Cleaning is not being conducted after each class and no deep cleaning is being done during the evening at Shelby Jr High, Davis Jr High, and Eppler Jr High. 4. The District is not following the latest guidelines from the CDC or local public health department concerning employees being allowed to return from quarantine or isolation due to COVID positive exposure.
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: 1. multiple schools in the utica district are in violation of miosha rule 5(8), not allowing remote work, such as: a). not allowing teachers and support staff (music teachers and literacy coaches) who only teach remotely to work from home. b). requiring faculty to remain on site the entire workday even if their only in-person duty is getting students off the bus in the morning. c). requiring teachers who do not instruct at the beginning or end of the workday to remain on site for their planning time rather than being permitted to plan from home. d). teachers who work with virtual students and face to face students on alternating days are required to report to work on days when they exclusively teach virtually. 2. social distancing is not being practiced or enforced at shelby jr high, davis jr high, and eppler jr high. 3. cleaning is not being conducted after each class and no deep cleaning is being done during the evening at shelby jr high, davis jr high, and eppler jr high. 4. the district is not following the latest guidelines from the cdc or local public health department concerning employees being allowed to return from quarantine or isolation due to covid positive exposure.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer is prohibiting employees, including direct care nurses and respiratory therapists, from wearing all personally owned PPE. The staff is caring for covid-19 positive patients without N95 or equivalent respirators. Outside eye protection (goggles, face shields) is also prohibited despite shortage where the employer cannot supply enough to staff. The employer has a written respiratory protection plan outlining permission of voluntary use of respirators but are currently not allowing any requests. Staff are threatened with discipline up to and including termination if caught wearing outside PPE. The employer is unable to provide PPE and rations it to specific scenarios such as intubation. 2. Single-use respirators are being re-worn without sanitary storage conditions which increases the risk for staff exposure due to cross contamination.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Employees are not provided enough gloves for use when cleaning the schools (COVID disinfection) and the restrooms. They are told to use only 2 pairs of gloves per day. Employees run out of gloves and extra gloves are not provided. When additional gloves are requested, it can take up to 1-2 days for gloves to be delivered. 2. Employees are not provided toilet brushes for cleaning toilets and urinals, resulting in them having to submerge their hands in the toilets. This is exacerbated by the glove issue above. 3. Employees are not provided proper PPE when having to clean up blood, vomit, feces and urine or other potentially infectious materials. They are only provided the 2 pairs of gloves. No gowns, aprons, or face shields. 4. Employees are mandated to take lunch break at a set time, resulting in them having to share the lunchroom area with the teaching staff. Due to the size of the lunchroom area, social distancing is not possible.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer has not implemented procedures in accordance with CDC guidelines for the prevention of the transmission of the COVID-19 virus in order to protect employees in the workplace. Specifically, sanitation is not adequate, masks are not being worn, and social distancing is not maintained. Employees sit directly next to each other in the lunch room. Employees have contracted COVID-19 from exposures in the workplace. Applicable OSHA Standards: Section 5(a)(1) of the OSH Act and 1910.141 2. Aisles 1-23. Racks that store pallets are damaged to the point where they are unsafe to use, exposing employees to struck-by hazards. Product hangs over the racks and vertical supports near the floor are bent and twisted. Applicable OSHA Standards: 29 CFR 1910.176 and Section 5(a)(1) of the OSH Act 3. Powered industrial trucks, including standups and sit-downs, frequently stop suddenly during operation, power steering is lost and operators have to slam on the brakes. A wrench icon appears on the vehicle¿s computer panel signaling the need for vehicle maintenance. When this occurs, operators are instructed by management to over-ride the safety feature by turning the vehicle off and on again to ¿reset¿ it and continue operating, rather than taking the vehicle out of service for repairs. Also, to avoid taking powered industrial vehicles out of service, vehicle problems are not always noted when completing daily/shift inspection information on the vehicle's computer panel. Employees are exposed to struck-by and crush hazards. Applicable OSHA Standard: 29 CFR 1910.178. 4. The employer does not ensure that employees authorized to operate powered industrial trucks and pallet jacks are adequately trained in the safe operation of the vehicles. Operators involved in powered industrial truck accidents are not removed from driving and provided with refresher training and performance evaluations (driving tests) before being allowed to operate vehicles again. Employees are exposed to struck-by and crush hazards. Applicable OSHA Standard: 29 CFR 1910.178 5. Dock locks (North Side) are faulty at approximately 15 dock doors and do not secure the trailers to the dock. The locking arm on the dock lock system does not move upward to secure the rear of the trailer to the bar when the button is pushed. When this occurs, an alarm goes off and a manager is called to enter a safety ¿over-ride¿ code into the system and loading/unloading with powered industrial trucks is permitted. Employees are exposed to struck-by and crush hazards. Applicable OSHA Standards: 29 CFR 1910.178 and Section 5(a)(1) of the OSH Act

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Employer does not have an emergency action plan, no emergency route. 2. Employees are exposed to slip hazards around the machinery flooring due to debris and water accumulation. 3. Employer does not maintain Safety data sheets for any of the products used at the facility such as concrete products. 4. Employees are no trained on the hazards associated with the handling of wet concrete and Portland cement. 5. Blocked safety exit by the hurricane line 6. The exit doors on the north side of the plant do not have exit signs. 7. The two main Overhead cranes in the plant are having faulty brakes and are not being repaired. 8. The Conveyor system do not have safety guards installed, exposing employees to amputation hazards. 9. Employees are exposed to unsanitary working conditions, increasing the risk of illness for COVID-due to employer failure to sanitize shared tools and equipment. 10. Employees exposed to silica during wet and dry concrete and cement batch processes are nor trained in the hazards associated with silica dust. 11. Employees doing quality checks on concrete pads by breaking the pad are exposed to silica dust and not provided with respiratory protection. 12. Employer does not have a hearing conservation program for employees working inside the plant and exposed to noise levels of 92 dBA. 13. Employer allows employees to use compressed air for cleaning at 135 psig. 14. Employer does not have a permit require confined space program when employees are required to enter in concrete mixers to remove concrete residues by scraping with bricking tools. 15. Employees performing maintenance on the conveyors are exposed to electrical hazards, in that, the employer does not have a lockout/tagout program and procedures. 16. Employees are not trained on lockout/tagout procedures.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: These movers are not practicing social distancing at all time!! When you have 2-4 men sitting in a cab of a moving truck it IS NOT POSSIBLE to be 6 feet away. Unless a chair or tv or heavy bookshelf or washer dryer etc... they are NOT SOCIAL DISTANCING PROPERLY ! The guys the other day were on a long distance move, so 4 men inside cab of truck 2-3hrs at a time, then get out to move people. Why did the President forfeit evictions, late fees etc when residents are STILL MOVING! It is not an ARMY move or anything, was not a necessity that these movers are allowed to not practice social distancing when moving from county to county, city to city, state to state. This is not good practice when dealing with so many of the public.

The employer allowed a COVID-19 positive employee to work with symptoms. The employer did not disinfect or sanitize the work area where the COVID-19 positive employee had worked. 3. The employer does not provide disinfectant or cleaning supplies to employees and does not sanitize or disinfect highly touched surfaces or shared equipment (door knobs, time clocks, bathrooms, break rooms, carts, pallet jacks, printers). 4. Employees are working within 6 feet of each other and the employer is not requiring the use of face coverings to protect employees from contracting or spreading COVID-19.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: This restaurant is not following the Covid-19 guidelines mandated by the Governor. Frequently, social distancing is not observed. Masks are being worn below the nose, below the chin - at times, managers wear their mask hanging from one ear. There is a very tiny break room - social distancing is not possible in there. Store policy is only one person allowed in there at a time. Yet, there are frequently 2 or more employees in there at the same time. Temperatures are rarely checked. Questions about symptoms are not asked unless they are checking your temperature - they don't always ask then either. If employees have symptoms, as long as they are not running a fever or vomiting, they are told to tough it out and come to work. If employees are already at work, they must complete their shift. One manager called out of work due to running a fever of 102F. Less than 24 hours later, they were back at work. They told at least two people including Complainant that they had missed work the day before due to the fever.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Precautions were not taken to prevent exposure. On March 20th, they shut down the building because an employee had been hospitalized since 3/10/2020 and passed away. The employer shut down the office and said they were going to disinfect. They bought sanitizer and were going to take buses to Louisville, KY to disinfect. The employees were not provided PPE when cleaning the buses. Employees do not have any Lysol, they do not have any masks. At least 4 - 5 employees are sick with symptoms on 2nd shift and 3rd shift. The other employees who have been sick have not been tested. Employees had been called off and they have been sick, they were brought back in and told to fix the bus. They are still dispatching buses. They are sending out these buses with sick employees working on them. 8 - 10 employees in the office. The employees were then told they could be furloughed. The shop is open. The business is still operating.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. All employees are not wearing facial coverings when coming in close contact with coworkers. 2. The employer has not covered proper use and care of facial covering including the need to perform proper hand hygiene after handle a face covering prior to handing equipment or supplies in the work place. 3. The common areas and equipment including high touch areas in the workplace are not being cleaned and disinfected using an EPA registered disinfectant for use against SARS-COV-2 daily or more frequently. Cleaning is only performed in certain areas of the facility on a weekly basis. 4. The thermometer being used to screen employees is not functioning properly due to having been dropped on multiple occasions and it has not been replaced with a working thermometer or alternative screening measures. 5. Employees with close unprotected contact with a coworker who tested positive for COVID-19 have not been asked to quarantine and are allowed to remain at work with no additional protocols in place to protect other employees.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: There have been several employees (10 or more) contract COVID-19 and others are showing symptoms, but the owners of Nelco are doing absolutely nothing to protect or distance workers from those who have been infected. There is absolutely no social distancing and no sanitizing whatsoever. No one is wearing masks. The entire warehouse has to share a unisex bathroom that has only 2 toilets and they are never cleaned. If employees try to use the other restrooms on the property to practice social distancing, they are fired on the spot. If anyone asks about coworkers who have been sick or exposed, they are either suspended or fired on the spot. This company has become an absolute hotbed for the virus and none of the workers are being taken care of or protected. This has been ongoing since the start of the pandemic. Those who reported the issue or self-quarantined have been fired. All employees at the company are exposed.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Through out the warehouse and in the Parts Fab Area: Complaint 1) The grinders do not have exhaust systems and employees are not provided with adequate respiratory protection from the dust when grinding. OSHA ref: 1910.94(b)(4)(iii) Complaint 2) Employees are not provided adequate fall protection when working at heights such as welding on tanks. OSHA ref: 1910.28(b)(1)(i) Complaint 3) Employees are travelling on the forks of forklifts and engaged in horseplay. OSHA ref:1910.178(n)(9) Complaint 4) Employees have not received training and certifications in forklift use. OSHA ref: 1910.178(l)(1)(i) Complaint 5) Employees are smoking cigarettes around compressed gases used for welding. Complaint 6) In the warehouse and restroom, employees are exposed to hazards of being struck by falling insulation and sheetrock. Complaint 7) In the warehouse, housekeeping and vermin controls have not been put in place. Bird nests are present and their droppings are exposing employees to respiratory hazards. Guard dogs are allowed to roam in the warehouse. Dog fecal matter and urine is not cleaned up exposing employees to health hazards. OSHA ref: 1910.141(a)(5) Complaint 8) Aisles and walkways in the warehouse are not clearly marked where employees and vehicular traffic is present. OSHA ref: 1910.176(a) Complaint 9) Forklifts in the part fab area and warehouse are not well maintained and do not have working horns to warn pedestrian when travelling around corners. The tires are worn out and have no tread causing them to slip when travelling on an incline. OSHA ref: 1910.178(p)(1) Complaint 10) Drill presses are not repaired properly by qualified personnel and employee's hands get caught in between the spindle/chuck apparatus. Complaint 11) The parking lots is not well maintained and has plenty of holes causing the forklift to become unstable when being operated on uneven pavement. Complaint 12) In the Parts Fab area and throughout the facility, employees are using grinders without guards. OSHA ref: 1910.212 (a) (1) Complaint 13) Employees were exposed to struck by and fire hazards when there was an explosion on the CNC burn table because they used the wrong type of gases. Complaint 14) There is water accumulation by the big machinery and welding machines exposing employees to electrical hazards. This is due to roof leaks when it is raining. Employees are standing in water when using these equipment exposing them to electrical hazards. Complaint 15) Electrical cords used throughout the site are damaged. The outer insulation is damaged exposing conductors. These cords are also sitting in water due to the accumulation exposing employees to electrical hazards. OSHA ref: 1910.334 (a)(2)(ii) Complaint 16) The working space around electrical equipment and circuit breaker panels obstructed preventing safe access to them. OSHA ref: 1910.303(g)(1) Complaint 17) Employees working on the ironworker, drill presses, hydraulic shears, millers and miter saws are not adequately trained. Employees are being rotated around using equipment they have not been previously trained on. Complaint 18) Employees are unable to communicate with each other when conducting shared tasks due to language barriers. Complaint 19) The employer has not instituted controls in regards to the spread of Covid 19. Employees are using shared equipment without sanitation. Controls such as hand sanitizer and soap for handwashing are not being provided. Employees are being allowed to congregate in areas without use of barriers such as but not limited to face coverings.

wrong type of gases. complaint 14) there is water accumulation by the big machinery and welding machines exposing employees to electrical hazards. this is due to roof leaks when it is raining. employees are standing in water when using these equipment exposing them to electrical hazards. complaint 15) electrical cords used throughout the site are damaged. the outer insulation is damaged exposing conductors. these cords are also sitting in water due to the accumulation exposing employees to electrical hazards. osha ref: 1910.334 (a)(2)(ii) complaint 16) the working space around electrical equipment and circuit breaker panels obstructed preventing safe access to them. osha ref: 1910.303(g)(1) complaint 17) employees working on the ironworker, drill presses, hydraulic shears, millers and miter saws are not adequately trained. employees are being rotated around using equipment they have not been previously trained on. complaint 18) employees are unable to communicate with each other when conducting shared tasks due to language barriers. complaint 19) the employer has not instituted controls in regards to the spread of covid 19. employees are using shared equipment without sanitation. controls such as hand sanitizer and soap for handwashing are not being provided. employees are being allowed to congregate in areas without use of barriers such as but not limited to face coverings.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Absence of training, cleaning directions, appropriate ventilation and proper PPE for use of new chemical cleaner 2. Spray bottles filled with some type of cleaner along with packages of paper towels were delivered to our rooms and offices a month ago with zero explanation after the buckets of Hillyard Vindicator wipes were taken. 3. Training on the hazards of the cleaning chemicals, safe work practices and the use of the cleaner against COVID-19 was not communicated at all. When concerns were raised, a label of ingredients was placed on the bottles, but still no training or explanation on how to use the spray safely or effectively was given. The expectation for staff to use the spray with no directions is worrisome. We are also concerned, with good reason, about the manner in which the cleaner was diluted. 4. We do not believe that we have the appropriate PPE to be using this type of cleanser containing these chemicals. Many windows do not open. The cleaner is GS Neutral Disinfectant Cleaner made by Spartan Chemical Company. 5. Absence of required cleaning and concerns about appropriate cleaning of frequently touched surfaces. Classroom sinks are not cleaned daily. 6. Soap is not by the sinks in several classrooms and workspaces. 7. Required signs for proper hand washing techniques are not displayed in all bathrooms. 8. Classrooms also do not show evidence of disinfection. 9. No gloves are in the computer area or library. 10. The wipes provided are hand wipes and are not designated for surfaces.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer does not require symptomatic employee to quarantine for the recommended number of days per CDC guidelines. This has resulted in 12 other employees testing positive for COVID-19. Applicable OSHA standard(s): Section 5(a)(1) the General Duty Clause of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 2. Employees are required to use a new mask each work day to protect from SARS-CoV-2, but the company does not provide them to employees and states that surgical masks at the establishment are for customers only. This results in employees working without masks at the establishment. Applicable OSHA standard(s): Section 5(a)(1) the General Duty Clause of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 3. There is no sanitization performed in the shared work areas or other high traffic areas of the establishment after employees tested positive for COVID-19. Applicable OSHA standard(s): Section 5(a)(1) the General Duty Clause of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 4. The employer is not requiring that employees evaluate their symptoms each work day, and stay away from the worksite if they have symptoms for COVID-19. Applicable OSHA standard(s): Section 5(a)(1) the General Duty Clause of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. On November 13th an employee tested positive for COVID-19. Employees who work in the facility and interacted with the infected employee were not notified of their potential exposure until 14-16 days later. Employees were not given the opportunity to test and/or quarantine if needed. Since the initial exposure, three more employees have become infected and are out. Again, the remaining employees have not yet been notified by management as to their potential exposure to COVID-19. 2. Shared work surfaces, spaces, trucks, and tools have not been cleaned and disinfected after employee(s) tested positive for COVID-19. 3. Management is lax in enforcing the mandatory mask mandate. Employees have been observed not wearing face coverings, and/or not wearing them to cover both nose and mouth. 4. Social distancing is not being enforced. Only one employee is allowed in a trailer to unload, however two to three employees have been observed inside trailers unloading. Management is aware of the work practice and stated there are exceptions to the social distancing rules depending upon the circumstances.

Please note that it is against the law to retaliate or discriminate in any way against an employee for raising safety and health issues or for exercising their rights under the OSH Act. Section 11(c) of the OSH Act prohibits discriminating against, interfering with, restraining, or coercing any employee because such employee has filed any complaint or instituted or caused to be instituted any proceeding under or related to this Act or has testified or is about to testify in any such proceeding or because of the exercise by such employee on behalf of himself or others of any right afforded by this Act

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Leaking roof on live electric wires in the building. 2. Leaking roof creates a slip hazard. An employee broke their shoulder this year because of it. 3. Safety lights on both bindery machines do not work properly. 4. The stop button on the six-pocket binder does not work. It is on pocket number one 5. Safety switches are bypassed on the Kansas inserter machine. 6. All the stackers have at least two bypassed safety switches. 7. The safety switches were removed off the S.L.S inserter sliding doors. 8. The four-pocket binder has a broken 440v plug along with many other cords in the shop. 9. Wires hanging down by the paper sheer show 'bare wire with not even tape on them. 10. Leaking high pressure air lines by the operators. 11. 440v drops not properly secured to the ceiling. If an operator pulls on the cable it may short out the 440. 12. Some of the fork trucks do not have back up horns and some of the horns do not work. 13. The emergency brake does not work on one of the fork trucks. 14. Unsanitary employee bathrooms. 15. Safety switches are tapped shut. 16. Fire extinguishers and tornado alarms are not updated nor working or properly tagged. 17. No lock out/tag out anywhere in the building. 18. Safety keys on doors and machinery are bypassed. 19. The server room has no AC and can potentially cause a fire due to boxes of paper by the hot server. 20. Full oil buckets are kept at a high temperature due to being in a closed compressor room. 21. Work tables are unstable and are jagged so they cut the operator's hands. 22. Electrical breakers are not properly marked in case of an emergency. 23. Wire wheel and grinder in maintenance does not have guards or an on/off switch. 24. No safety training for anyone. 25. Open holes in the building by the press. 26. No fork truck training. 27. The safety door on the bailing machine is bypassed where the operator loads large boxes of scrap. 28. No safety glasses are provided. 29. There are broken and hanging lights and fixtures on the east side of the building. 30. The fork trucks leak oil causing employees to fall. 31. No first aid kits on the production floor for emergencies. 32. The safety cables on the big conveyor going to the bailing machine does not work. 33. Material racks are not properly anchored. 34. Sky lift truck horn or safety lights do not work. 35. No safety harness available for sky lift truck. 36. Employee's do not know where the MSDS are kept due to lack of training. 37. No safety chains available for the lift basket for the lift truck. 38. Unmarked chemical spray bottles. 39. Eye wash stations are unsanitary and not working properly. 40. The oil separator system for the air compressor does not work causing machines to slip and is a hazard when air lines leak oil causing more oils to slip on. 41. Platforms for production workers to stand on the six-pocket bindery are not lagged in the ground so when the fork truck driver bumps the platform with a skid of material it causes the operator to fall. 42. The exhaust on the back up electric generator will leak into the shop to the point it burns your eyes, nose and causes headaches. It seems to leak more when it is warmed up. 43. 440V lines by the paper shear are not in conduit and are just hanging down. 44. The employer is not following COVID-19 precautions. 45. Employees do not wear masks. 46. Machines are not being wiped down to prevent the spread of covid-19.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The manager and the owners do not seem that concerned for employee safety. An employee is sick, throwing up, and the manager told us that its just anxiety and not to worry about corona. This has happened before, a different co-worker wasn't feeling well and they sent her home but the next day the manager said she was "fine", but the girl was coughing throughout the week. The manager had gotten Covid-19, had left her shift early when she got a fever but didn't know until she had already came back 2 weeks later, without getting her test results back, which were positive. Employees are concerned for their safety and the customers, because the manager believes employees should not freak out at every sore throat and "they didn't have fevers". The owners of the store do not seem to be any more concerned about it than the manager. It seems as though they are not taking the right precautions, besides wearing gloves and masks. All 3 of these instances, the employee showing a symptom had left town and gone out of state or to a theme park. This has all happened within the past month.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Extended use or reuse of N95s: In the event extended use or reuse of N95 FFRs becomes necessary, the same worker is permitted to extend use of or reuse the respirator, as long as the respirator maintains its structural and functional integrity and the filter material is not physically damaged, soiled, or contaminated (e.g., with blood, oil, paint). Extended use is preferred over reuse due to contact transmission risk associated with donning/doffing during reuse. When respirators are being re-used, employers should pay particular attention to workers¿ proper storage of the FFRs in between periods of reuse. If respirators are to be reused, they must be stored to protect them from damage, contamination, dust, sunlight, extreme temperatures, excessive moisture, and damaging chemicals; and they must be stored to prevent deformation of the facepiece or exhalation valve [(h)(2)(i)]. Employers must also ensure the respirators are inspected before each use [(h)(3)(i)(A) and (ii)]. Respirators that fail an inspection, or are otherwise found to be defective, must be removed from service [(h)(4)].
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: extended use or reuse of n95s: in the event extended use or reuse of n95 ffrs becomes necessary, the same worker is permitted to extend use of or reuse the respirator, as long as the respirator maintains its structural and functional integrity and the filter material is not physically damaged, soiled, or contaminated (e.g., with blood, oil, paint). extended use is preferred over reuse due to contact transmission risk associated with donning/doffing during reuse. when respirators are being re-used, employers should pay particular attention to workers¿ proper storage of the ffrs in between periods of reuse. if respirators are to be reused, they must be stored to protect them from damage, contamination, dust, sunlight, extreme temperatures, excessive moisture, and damaging chemicals; and they must be stored to prevent deformation of the facepiece or exhalation valve [(h)(2)(i)]. employers must also ensure the respirators are inspected before each use [(h)(3)(i)(a) and (ii)]. respirators that fail an inspection, or are otherwise found to be defective, must be removed from service [(h)(4)].

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Employees are potentially exposed to health hazards associated with COVID-19. It was reported that there is one positive COVID case in the facility. It was further reported that Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is not available to employees including but not limited to respirators, gloves and no training on the process on how to minimize worker exposure. Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. A member of the surgical team tested positive for covid-19. 2. Surgery team members work in a space with less than six feet of separation. 3. Management evaluated the surgical team as ¿low risk.¿ 4. Management has filled the open shifts with employees who will come in close contact with all surgery team member who have been exposed. 5. A surgery team member has MS and is pregnant and is considered high risk. No precautions are being taken to protect her from exposure. 6. Health questionnaires are filled out by employees upon entry with no management/HR present. There is no temperature check. 7. When not in office employees are still physically close/touching when restraining animals. 8. Masks are removed for eating and drinking. 9. Workspaces, computers, and phones are shared.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer has not implemented good infection control housekeeping practices of regularly cleaning and disinfecting surfaces, equipment, and other elements of the work environment. 2. The employer has not implemented a good infection control plan including things such as face coverings for employees, training, social distancing, etc. 3. The employer's infection control program is not adequate as they are not ensuring that employees who have been diagnosed with covid-19 are kept separate from employees that have not tested positive. Refer to the Centers for Disease Control CDC guidance for employers at this link. https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/businesses-employers.html OSHA in coordination with the Department of Health and Human Services has prepared Guidance on Preparing Workplaces for COVID-19. It can be found here: https://www.osha.gov/Publications/OSHA3990.pdf OSHA has Guidance on Returning to Work https://www.osha.gov/Publications/OSHA4045.pdf

Hazard.Desc.Loc: At the beginning of the pandemic, employees were scolded if they wore masks. Employees were locked out of their PPE closet. They were only allowed in the PPE closet once per week. For several months, employees were not wearing masks. If employees were sick, they were asked to come into work and have their temperature taken close to other employees. If employees are sick, other employees are not informed until they came back from isolation. They are not sanitizing the employee areas including common touch points. They have not cleaned the entire department.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Site: 1. It is alleged that over 20 employees have becomes ill with COVID and employer does not provide face masks. 2. Employer has not provided follow-up care and information (in accordance with CDC guidelines and local and state Health Authorities) to employees who co-workers have tested positive for COVID or have become ill with COVID: Employees are concerned that they should self quarantine but no one has told them. Employees are concerned that they could be taking COVID back to their families. Not all employees are able to isolate at home. Employees are concerned that co-workers have been hospitalized. 3. Employees are unable to ¿distance¿ due to the nature of the work. The employer has not developed, implemented and communicated alternate methods to protect employees from COVID. For example: engineering controls such as plexiglass barriers, increased fresh air in HVAC and other methods; administrative controls such as staggered shifts, staggered breaks and lunch, temperature screening and other methods; personal protective equipment such as face masks. 4. Employer has not developed adequate procedures to ensure the safety of employees. Employees learned that a co-worker died last night and that a different co-worker was intubated at the hospital. 5. Employer has not done deep cleaning and disinfecting per CDC guidelines 6. Hand sanitizer not provided 7. Employer has not developed adequate screening procedure to ensure that ill employees do not come to work. One method is taking temperatures to ensure sick not coming into work.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The Department of Transportation want drivers to transport two crewmember and themselves in a approximately seven feet cab of truck to assigned location for eight hour a day. However, according to the CDC recommendations; three to six feet of social distancing is required to mitigate the spread of the Coronavirus. Hazard Location: Bureau of Electric On August 30, 2021, Executive Order 2021-20 was issued by the governor¿s office which states all individuals in Illinois who are age two or over and able to medically tolerate a face covering (a mask or cloth face covering) shall be required to cover their nose and mouth with a face covering when in an indoor public place. Illinoisans should also consider wearing a mask in crowded outdoor settings and for activities that involve close contact with others who are not fully vaccinated. IL OSHA understands that the reference to following CDC guidelines is a recommendation; not a requirement. While IL OSHA cannot directly enforce this executive order, the Illinois Occupational Safety and Health Act requires employers to protect employees from recognized hazards that cause or are likely to cause death or serious physical harm to its employees (820 ILCS 219/20(a)). Employers that violate this section of the Act may be cited and/or referred to another regulatory authority.

Once inside, 5-6 people in waiting area with no masks. 2 female stylists and their clients with masks on. 3 male barbers (1 of which was the owner) and their clients with no masks. Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer is not ensuring that staff members including management personnel in the medical department and FCI 2 consistently wear face coverings. 2. Although PPE such as goggles, faceshields, gloves, and gowns may be available in the Lieutenant¿s office in the LC and LA units at FCI 2, it is not being made available to staff who perform duties such as but not limited to escorting/transporting inmates, entering rooms, opening food trap doors, providing medical care, and working in open areas with inmates in the COVID-19 isolation/quarantine units in accordance with the Recommended Use of PPE Table in the BOP COVID-19 Pandemic Response Plan. 3. Although some PPE use training has been provided for staff, some of the training sessions did not provide an opportunity for staff to ask questions and obtain clarification about proper donning and doffing, N-95 filtering facepiece reuse procedures, and recommended use criteria contained in the BOP COVID-19 Pandemic Response Plan, Module 2, Table 1. As a result some staff do not know when and how to use the COVID-19 PPE safely. 4. Until recently, water soluble bags were being required in accordance with BUX 4500.04.01F and management required their use in COVID-19 isolation/quarantine areas, which reduced the risk of SARS-CoV-2 transmission. The use of the water soluble bags was ended and the policy to use the bags was reversed, increasing the staff¿s risk of contracting COVID-19. 5. Not stationing Virex spray bottles in the staff bathrooms where they are expected to be used for frequent cleaning creates an unreasonable impediment to sanitizing bathroom surfaces. 6. General staff are not knowledgeable about surface sanitation procedures. 7. Inmates are being moved in and out of FCI 2 even though a COVID-19 outbreak exists. 8. Contact tracing is not being conducted to effectively quarantine staff and inmates and as a result staff are not being informed through official channels when they worked with inmates who recently tested positive. 9. Testing protocols are not implemented to identify the population of asymptomatic COVID-19 positive inmates in FCI 2 where an outbreak is occurring. 10. The employer is requiring staff to perform roof checks where there is a safety hazard due to missing rails on the mental health side.

The employer is not communicating with staff members who work with COVID-19 positive patients/clients.
