Hazard.Desc.Loc: Autoform Tool and Manufacturing is not taking any proper precautions for COVID 19; no available PPE nor mandating staff to wear PPE, not social distancing staff and refusal from HR to respond to incidents or questions surrounding COVID 19. A positive COVID 19 case was just reported within the building but none of the staff who were placed in contact with/near this individual were notified, or the people who share the same machine in which that individual is working on- on a daily basis, as well as the machine maintenance crew who has undeniably come into contact with that person and the machine. The several thousands of parts that the individual touched and infected are shipped around the United States and Mexico, and then are sent to multiple General Motors plants throughout the nation. Autoform Tool and Manufacturing is not taking proper action based on this incident either by disinfecting the building or machines and parts or shutting down for a single shift to do so. The threat of COVID 19 spread based on this one individual can and will affect thousands due to the carelessness of Autoform Tool and Manufacturing refusing to follow proper protocols, social distancing and state guidelines surrounding prevention of spread and exposure of COVID 19.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: In areas including the new car showroom and offices, 1 The managers required an employee who works in finance to come to work while still testing positive for Covid-19. The infected individual may have or may be infecting other employees with Covid-19. 2 The majority of approximately 15 sales and office persons do not wear facemask or face coverings. 3 Sales and customers get into test drive vehicles without face masks or coverings. 4 Three or more Employees are asked to ride together in vehicles to move cars, or perform other functions, when the number of employees in cars could be limited to a maximum of two persons. 5 The employer is not enforcing social distancing. 6 The employer has not provided employees information on any policy of what type of pay, or leave, they will recieve if they have to quarantine as recommended in CDC guidelines, after testing positive or after a Covid-19 positive exposure. The Families First Coronavirus Response Act is an example of pay benefits for employees if they are suspected or presumed Covid-19 positive. 7 When telework would be possible, for some administrative employees for example, these employees are not allowed to telework in order to reduce the number of employees in the workplace. 8 The employer does not notify the employees when an employee is presumed to be positive, or tests positive, for Covid-19. The employer according to CDC guidelines should identify the work areas and close contacts the presumed or positive person had with other employees, and notify those employees of the exposure.

The employer failed to screen visitors or employees for COVID19 symptoms before allowing them to enter the facility as in accordance to CDC guidelines for the COVID-19 pandemic. 5. The employer failed to ensure employees were practicing social distancing, maintaining six (6) feet distance, between persons within the facility or wear cloth face coverings when other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain as in accordance to CDC (Center for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines for the COVID-19 (coronavirus disease) pandemic.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: No requirement for masking in District buildings. On August 11, 2021, The Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE) issued a letter to all superintendents titled, "Enforcement of Universal Masking Requirement." This letter highlights Executive Order 2021-18, that requires that all students, staff, and visitors wear masks indoors in all P-12 schools in Illinois. While IL OSHA cannot directly enforce this executive order, the Illinois Occupational Safety and Health Act requires employers to protect employees from recognized hazards that cause or are likely to cause death or serious physical harm to its employees (820 ILCS 219/20(a)). Employers that violate this section of the Act may be cited and/or referred to another regulatory authority such as the ISBE.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The employer is not implementing safety practices to protect employees from the spread of SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes COVID-19) by implementing precautions such as, but not limited to: 1. Screening employees' temperatures and assessing symptoms prior to starting work; 2. Providing barricades or other means of protection to employees; 3. Enforcing the use of masks when social distancing is not used in the workplace; 4. Ensuring that employees who have received a positive diagnosis of COVID-19 do not enter the workplace until after their contagion period has lapsed and/or have received a negative test result; 5. Ensuring that employees who are exhibiting signs or symptoms of the COVID-19 virus do not report to work.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The employer has not taken the appropriate steps to protect employees from SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. A third employee has tested positive for COVID-19. The company is also using outdated CDC guidelines to inform workers of COVID cases, as well as using outdated guidelines to diagnose the worker who tested positive. Donatos qualifies close contact if exposure was within 6 feet and unmasked for 15 minutes. CDC guidelines are to inform employees of their possible close contact, mask or no mask, (within 6 feet of an infected person for a cumulative total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period) with someone with confirmed or suspected SARS-CoV-2 infection in the workplace, but maintain confidentiality. No employees that were within close contact of the COVID case were informed of the fact that they had exposure/contact for two days.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. I was training at SKLD Beltline on Thursday, March 19th and Friday, March 20th. We were working with high risk residents. During those 2 days, the nurse training me did NOT wash her hands between residents. 2. As we took vitals on each resident, there was no way to clean the equipment between visits with each resident. My trainer squirted hand sanitizer on a Kleenex and handed it to me to ¿clean off¿ the blood pressure cuff, O2 saturation monitor & thermometer. 3. On March 19th as I entered the facility to get me temperature checked I observed another staff person registered a temperature of 100.9 degrees F. I said to the staff member you can¿t work with that temperature. She stated, ¿oh hell no!¿ and punched in to work. Staff are working (or being required to work) with elevated temperatures. 4. During both shifts, my trainer would stand right next to me and cough on me. I asked her several time to not cough on me. She stated that she had a mask on, so she did not have to cover her cough and it was a smoker¿s cough, so she wasn¿t sick or spreading germs. 5. There were already two cases of influenza on the unit and no PPE for those rooms. The two infected individuals were sharing rooms with other residents who were not positive for influenza. 6. I sent an email to the Assistant Administrator on Sunday, March 22nd, stating that I did not feel safe working in these conditions. I was contacted by Human Resources on Monday, March 23rd. I explained what was going on and why I felt this was unsafe for staff to work under these conditions and that it was potentially deadly for the residents. 7. I was scolded for missing a training shift on Monday. I explained that I had a temperature of 100.6 degrees F. and according to their guidelines I was not eligible to work. I was instructed that I had to finish my training. I explained that I was sick and possibly contagious. I was told that did not matter, I must come to work and complete my training. 8. I was taken off the schedule. All of my shifts were removed. I was later told that since I didn¿t show up for shifts, they were taken away. I was given ¿separation¿ papers and summarily terminated. I am afraid that people will die because of their reckless endangerment. They are not even following the bare minimum of universal precautions let alone pandemic health crisis procedures or precautions.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Staff are not aware of why patients are in ¿quarantine room¿. Had two patients but they were only quarantined a few days or until they felt better. One patient was pregnant and sent to the ER and the other was not. Direct care staff, including behavioral health techs and counselors along with the patient themselves, are not informed when or why a patient is quarantined. Those in quarantine were allowed to leave the room freely (ex. Going to smoking area, etc.) 2. Daily temperatures of staff are not being taken due to the influx of traffic coming through the main entrance. Front desk clerk reporting to staff that the thermometer does not work. 3. No regular, thorough cleaning of common areas and surfaces, including telephones, door knobs, the floor, or railings. Dirty patient rooms. 4. Inadequate amount of hand sanitizer and below the recommended CDC guide (greater than 60% ethanol or 70% isopropanol) 5. Continues to hold large groups with little social distancing. Continue to have groups of 20-40. No social distancing despite red line in the hallways. Hallways always full (elbow to elbow) everyday, all day. Red lines to use for medication and lunch lines not adequate. 6. New patients and existing patients are not all wearing the mask 7. No company staff meeting(s) or training on pandemic 8. Anyone who sees patients does not get told beforehand if patient has erratic or dangerous behavior or the possibility of them being aggressive

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Employees performing cleaning, grounds and maintenance work at the Virginia rest area (mile marker 1, Interstate 77, Carroll County, VA) do not have sufficient access to personal protective equipment (PPE): ¿ The supervisor keeps face mask & gloves locked in file cabinet; ¿ When PPE becomes soiled or wet, employee do not have access to replacements; ¿ Employees on the 1st shift only receive (one) face mask and (one) pair of gloves each day; ¿ Employees on the 2nd and 3rd shift have no access to get face mask or gloves, since no one is available to provide and the PPE is locked up. The Rest Area Supervisor locks the file cabinet, leaves the location and will retaliate against employees if concerns are brought to her or her supervisor¿s attention. Employees have tried to call the DBI Management¿s phone numbers posted at the rest area, but the phone numbers posted are no longer working numbers.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: This employer cares nothing anymore about Covid protocol. Their regional manager feels that since Covid shots have been available everyone already has them. Most do not. Subsequently, on 4/19 an employee tested positive and her husband (also an employee) was off work. On 4/26 the employee who tested positive was allowed to return to work. On 5/5 an employee who was having breathing issues was transported to the hospital by the foreman; the employee who was transported admitted to already having tested positive for Covid. The foreman returned to work and awaits what the employer wants him to do. The employer is doing no contract tracing and has no care about Covid. The Mechanic Shop¿s office sits 3 people in less than a 4 foot space. Employees fear employer retaliation regarding complaints.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The office is able to work remotely but the President sent a text to the staff saying we will be working on-site after the Governor's directive to work from home if feasible. 2. There have been several instances where protocols have not been followed; lax face coverings, groups of workers going to lunch together. 3. Employees who share workspaces with someone do not wipe down commonly touched surfaces when done like computer/phone. 4. An employee was diagnosed positive with COVID in September and employees were told to stay home for a week and not to disclose to anyone why they were working remotely that week. 5. During meetings, employees go inside a closed room and supervisors conduct the meetings with masks pulled down. 6. There have been two instances where people of high temperatures have come into the office; one a customer and one a child of a colleague. 7. Social distancing is not enforced. 8. People walk around forgetting their mask at their desks. 9. Employees also only have to take their temperature, sign their name, and date when they come in, the questionnaire is only reserved for visitors, employees were told to 'keep the questions in mind when they come in.' 10. There has been no training and no written procedure or protocol provided to any employees.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: It was reported that employees are exposed to health hazards related to COVID-19 due to lack of precautions taken by the employer to avoid transmission of the virus. Contrary to 5(a)(1) of the OSH Act.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1) Employees interacting with potential COVID-19 patients are not given N95 respirators, they are only given face masks that are inadequate due to the metal part not bending to the shape of the nose. 2) Employees are not given sufficient time between patients to clean and disinfect the area where patients were seen. 3) There are no policies in place for patients to social distance in the waiting area to reduce the spread of COVID-19 to patients or employees. 4) Employees are unable to properly screen patients before seeing them because there's not enough time between patients nor there's uniform procedures to screen patients for COVID-19. 5) Employees that float between quest lab sites are not given their own face shields and reuse face shields that other employees have worn before. 6) Employees that are tested for COVID-19 are allowed to come to work pending test results instead of quarantining until the results are made available.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: ¿ The Berrien County Juvenile Center has failed to take proper precautions to protect its employees and detained youth from covid-19 exposure. ¿ There is a covid-19 positive youth in the facility. ¿ Informational material has been posted. Training was conducted on May 28, 2020 that covered only hand washing and social distancing. No training on the coronavirus, how it spreads, or preventative measures. No training on proper use, storage, and disposal of PPE. No training on how to report unsafe work conditions. Staff were told to sign a covid-19 training read-receipt, although those policies were not in place. ¿ Staff are repeatedly wearing the same face mask which is left in vehicles and taken home. ¿ PPE that was worn into the covid-19 positive youth¿s room is being left in the hallway in an open cardboard box. ¿ Face shields that were worn into the covid-19 positive youth¿s room were taken into the staff lobby. ¿ No protocols on how to clean and disinfect. High traffic areas, such as key-pad entries, prescreen check-in area, bathrooms, staff lobby, medication cart, mailroom, and copy machine are not being cleaned or disinfected. Staff are mixing chemicals with no training due to lack of supplies. ¿ No protocol on how to social distance. On May 28, 2020, residential groups were combined and moved into the smallest unit, making social distancing almost impossible. ¿ Staff exposed to the covid-19 positive youth are being assigned to multiple units increasing exposure risk. ¿ Staff in contact with the covid-19 positive youth have not been tested or quarantined. ¿ A 5-gallon Igloo water dispenser is the only source of drinking water. No protocol on how to clean or use the Igloo everyone is touching. ¿ Staff not passing the prescreen questionnaire are told to work anyway. ¿ Staff are over staff although population number have been low. The facility has made no effort to work at the minimum required youth specialist. Staff are purposely being over scheduled.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. It is alleged that within the facility, at least five (5) employees have tested positive for coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the employer is not following the current CDC Guidelines, such as but not limited to, the Interim Guidance for Businesses and Employers to Plan and Respond to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). It is alleged the employees who have come in close contact or have been impacted by with COVID-19 positive staff are either not informed, are not directed to quarantine for the recommended amount of time and/or follow other available guidance for exposure. 2. Proper disinfecting, sanitizing, and cleaning is not being performed in accordance with CDC Guidelines. These areas include, but are limited to, high touch areas, offices, restrooms, common areas, and workstations. 3. Employees, including drivers and managers, not consistently wearing mask, and/or are not practicing social distancing (6 feet distancing) in accordance with CDC Guidelines when working and moving throughout the facility. 4. Staff is not properly trained on the current guidelines, including those from the CDC and OSHA. 5. The restrooms are not cleaned daily and the soap is not available and/or replenished daily. Allegedly, the restrooms did not have soap almost a week.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Item #1 - Staff are not trained on personal protection equipment when they are expected to treat patients with potential Covid-19 patients. This is a possible violation of 29 CFR 1910.132(f)(1) Item #2 - Staff does not have access to personal protective equipment (PPE), specifically N95 respirators and gowns. This is a possible violation of 29 CFR 1910.132(a) Item #3 - Staff are instructed to dispose of PPE that had potential exposure to patients with COVID-19 into regular waste bins. This is a possible violation of 29 CFR 1910.132(f)(1)(v) Item #4 - Staff are not provided with appropriate personal protection equipment when performing swabbing and phlebotomy procedures on patients with suspected COVID-19. Specifically, N95 respirators are not provided. A personal protective equipment hazard assessment has not been conducted to ensure employees are not being exposed to COVID-19. This is a possible violation of 29 CFR 1910.132(d)(1) Item #5 - Staff are not provided with appropriate personal protection equipment when handling or working in close proximity to patients with suspected COVID-19. Specifically, N95 respirators are not provided. A personal protective equipment hazard assessment has not been conducted to ensure employees are not being exposed to COVID-19. This is a possible violation of 29 CFR 1910.132(d)(1) Item #6 - Staff are not trained on personal protection equipment, specifically powered air purifying respirators (PAPR) when they are expected to treat patients with potential Covid-19 patients. This is a possible violation of 29 CFR 1910.132(f)(1)

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1) The employer has not conducted initial employee lead exposure monitoring or implemented a lead compliance program for the lead/tin hand soldering and the Wave Machine soldering. 2) The employer has not established procedures to prevent the asbestos containing floor tile and pipe insulation from being damaged and creating friable asbestos fibers. 3) Holes in the wall in the back work area allow mice into building. The employer has not taken steps to remove the mice from the facility. 4) The back area men's room urinals and a sink do not work. 5) The back area men's room is not cleaned frequently and is not maintained in sanitary condition. 6) The employer does not enforce COVID-19 face mask usage in the facility. 7) The employer does not clean and disinfect work areas between employees when different employees are using the same equipment or work space.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Site: 1. Employer has not developed, implemented and trained employees on procedures to protect all employees from the risk of COVID-19 related illness; 2. Due to the background noise of the plant ¿ in order to communicate, employees have to be close and are unable to use social distancing; 3. White coats are not laundered between uses - may result in COVID-19 exposure. 4. Recommendations: a. Coordinate with Mass DPH or local health authority for assistance; b. Consult CDC and OSHA webpages for guidance; i. Develop an Infectious Disease Preparedness and Response Plan; ii. Prepare to Implement Basic Infection Prevention Measures iii. Develop Policies and Procedures for Prompt Identification and Isolation of Sick People, if Appropriate iv. Develop, Implement, and Communicate about Workplace Flexibilities and Protections; v. Implement Workplace Controls, Engineering Controls, and Administrative Controls; vi. Implement Safe Work Practices; vii. Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and training in accordance with OSHA standards; viii. Communicate and train employee regarding the measures to take to reduce potential exposure; SOURCE: Guidance on Preparing the Workplace for COVID-19, OSHA publication 3990-03

The bartender kept making drinks and walking back and forth sitting people because 'apparently' those were the only two individuals working at least from what it seemed and she wasn't wearing a mask. Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The outpatient department to include but not limited to endoscopies, are not testing patients to see if they are COVID-19 positive before performing procedures; therefore potentially exposing employees to COVID-19. 2. In the Emergency Department COVID-19 patients are not being put in negative air flow rooms. They are being put in curtain drawn rooms exposing all employees who work in the ER to COVID-19. 3. There are patients who come into the ER to get tested and then get discharged to go home. If that patient's COVID-19 test comes back positive, ER employees who were around that patient are not being notified of the COVID-19 positive test result/exposure. 4. Employees working with inpatient patients under investigation (PUI), who later are confirmed COVID-19 positive are not being informed of the COVID-19 positive test/exposure. 5. Visitors are not screened and required to wear a mask when they come to the hospital. 6. Patients who are getting COVID-19 infusions have to walk through the hospital exposing employees to COVID-19 positive patients.
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: 1. the outpatient department to include but not limited to endoscopies, are not testing patients to see if they are covid-19 positive before performing procedures; therefore potentially exposing employees to covid-19. 2. in the emergency department covid-19 patients are not being put in negative air flow rooms. they are being put in curtain drawn rooms exposing all employees who work in the er to covid-19. 3. there are patients who come into the er to get tested and then get discharged to go home. if that patient's covid-19 test comes back positive, er employees who were around that patient are not being notified of the covid-19 positive test result/exposure. 4. employees working with inpatient patients under investigation (pui), who later are confirmed covid-19 positive are not being informed of the covid-19 positive test/exposure. 5. visitors are not screened and required to wear a mask when they come to the hospital. 6. patients who are getting covid-19 infusions have to walk through the hospital exposing employees to covid-19 positive patients.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: a) Employees are exposed to COVID19 with no guidance. b) Staff work in pods of people such as nurses, MSAs and providers. Only close employees have been tested even though everyone works within close distance of each other. d) Management provides no guidance and instead leaves it to Occupational Health to determine what is best. All that management says is "wear a mask and wash your hands" e) Patients are instructed to isolate, not to come in the building, and the rooms are fully cleaned after their visit. However, when it's an employee, it's a different story, only some get special treatment (testing, teleworking, etc). The rest are told to come to work.

Along with the personal protective equipment that must be worn; the employer requires cloth masks be worn to prevent the spread of Covid-19. It is felt the cloth masks are doing more harm to employee lungs than any prevention of Covid-19. 2. In the autoclaves area there are four separate rooms which are around 100F. Employees are required to wear a cloth face mask that gets damp from the bath steam, bath chemical, and employee sweat. Along with the personal protective equipment that must be worn; the employer requires cloth masks be worn to prevent the spread of Covid-19. It is felt the cloth masks are doing more harm to employee lungs than any prevention of Covid-19.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Online Retail Store of Music/Audio equipment. There has been a loophole for us to stay open because we are providing audio and video equipment to important businesses, however the department I am in inspects guitars. Hazard.Desc.Loc: HAZARD DESCRIPTION: 1. The employer is not requiring that garbage truck cabs are cleaned/sanitized between shifts, prior to use. There are two drivers at a time and trucks are shared between shifts. The employer does not provide cleaning or sanitizing chemicals or wipes to clean the cabs nor provide N95 masks. The employer only provides unrated single strap masks to drivers, which are ineffective for Covid-19 prevention. Drivers have found used facial tissues and some are displaying flu/Covid-19 symptoms. The issue has been brought to the attention of management but employees have been ignored. HAZARD LOCATION: At the truck yard located on the south west corner of the intersection at West Cheyenne and North Commerce Street. 3/20/2020 ebm

Hazard.Desc.Loc: COVID-19 The employer is allowing employees that have tested positive and/or awaiting test results for COVID-19 to continue to work potentially exposing other employees. The employer has not developed an effective plan to address the specific exposure risks, sources of exposure, routes of transmission and other unique characteristics of SARS-CoV-2. The plan should focus on engineering controls, administrative controls, work practice controls and personal protective equipment. 1. The employer is not following the CDC recommendations to protect employees. 2. The employer is not following State, and local safety requirements to protect employees. 3 The employer is not providing sanitary/good housekeeping processes, social distancing processes, or PPE as necessary for employee safety and to reduce exposure. 4. The employer is not communicating adequate information to ensure employees understand and adhere to safe work practices.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Employees in the facility are exposed to COVID-19. The employer does not ensure that personal protective equipment ( face masks, gloves) are provided at no charge to each employee on a daily basis. The employer does not ensure that all employees including managers wear a face mask continuously throughout their entire work shift. The employer does not ensure that all employees are informed when other employees are confirmed to be COVID-19 positive. The employer does not ensure that contact tracing is done after an employee is confirmed to be COVID-19 positive. The employer does not ensure that all bathrooms are supplied with soap and/or hand sanitizer on a daily basis. The employer does not ensure that social distancing is practiced in the kitchen and counter areas of the facility as recommended by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC). The employer does not ensure the facility is cleaned and sanitized as recommended by the CDC after an employee is confirmed to be COVID-19 positive. Applicable OSHA Standard: 5A1 General Duty Clause

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer failed to report two fatalities of employees working at the Walmart Supercenter at 2500 W. 95th St., Evergreen Park, Illinois within (8) hours to OSHA as required. The employees died on March 3,2020 and March 29, 2020. Applicable OSHA Standard: 29 CFR 1904.39 2. As of March 1, 2020, the employer failed to ensure that employees exposed to COVID-19 were provided appropriate personal protection equipment (gloves, masks) and soap and/or hand sanitizer. Applicable OSHA Standards: 29 CFR 1910.132, 1910.134 and 1910.141 3. As of March 1, 2020, the employer failed to ensure the facility was cleaned and sanitized on a regular basis to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Applicable OSHA Standard: 29 CFR 1910.141

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Patients being transported throughout hospital without facemasks. 2. No goggles available for MRI staff after COVID Response Mandate states employees must wear them in all of diagnostic imaging. 3. The railing of steps to mobile unit not fixed and come out, causing enormous employee fall potential. 4. A tech aide was not trained for BLS when the aide was exposed/has been exposed to blood for a year. 5. The hospital main elevators close on you and do not have a safety stop, especially the furthest elevator on the left. 6. Security guards allow hostile patients into hospital causing safety risks to employees. 7. No training on panic buttons or their locations. No panic button on mobile MRI. 8. No training on eye wash stations, disposing of hazardous materials, what exits to use in case of fire, shooter, hostile patients, etc. Only online generic modules available. 9. The hospital is filthy. The entire radiology department is rarely cleaned. No vacuuming. Hand sanitizers rarely refilled or cleaned/sanitized/mopped/vacuumed. 10. Technologists disposing of sharps into the garbage can instead of biohazard container for approximately 3 years. 11. Forced to lift patients by oneself because of space constraints of the mobile MRI unit. 12. Multiple bugs; flies, gnats, pillbugs, spiders- very unsanitary within the hospital. 13. Many bathrooms uncleaned, trash cans full. 14. No protocol established for COVID patients in MRI department. Hazard locations/departments: Radiology, MRI, other areas of the hospital as noted.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Employer is not following covid-19 protocols on training, cleaning, masks, social distancing, health screening, and working remotely to keep employees safe with the reopening of campus on August 10, 2020: Training: Employees were required to complete two, 10-minute training modules on ¿Coronavirus Awareness¿ and ¿Coronavirus: Cleaning and Disinfecting your Workplace.¿ No training on masks, social distancing, and on how to report unsafe working conditions. Cleaning: No enhanced cleaning measures, aside from giving staff cleaning supplies to clean their own areas. No written plan for cleaning. The restrooms appear to be dirtier than before the covid-19 pandemic. Masks: Masks are not required when working at desks. Employees do not wear masks outside their workspaces as required. No proper and consistent signage that face masks are required to enter the buildings. The administrators have stated the wearing of masks will not be enforced, and encourage masks be worn when six feet of separation cannot be guaranteed. It is up to each individual and department to use masks as they feel comfortable. Administrators believe EO 2020-153 does not apply because the campus is not a ¿public space¿ when it is not open to the public. Social Distancing: Very little and inconsistent signage indicating where six feet from individual workspaces. Employees are encouraged to use technology, such as Zoom, to hold meetings; across campus face to face meetings are being held. Health Screenings: Human resources director states employees are not required to conduct health screenings. It is suggested employees use the MI Symptoms web app as a self-monitoring tool. Many staff are not doing health screenings and those who have failed the health screenings have not been alerted by human resources until hours or days after failing the screening. No CDC personal hygiene signage. Remote work is not being allowed when it is possible.
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: employer is not following covid-19 protocols on training, cleaning, masks, social distancing, health screening, and working remotely to keep employees safe with the reopening of campus on august 10, 2020: training: employees were required to complete two, 10-minute training modules on ¿coronavirus awareness¿ and ¿coronavirus: cleaning and disinfecting your workplace.¿ no training on masks, social distancing, and on how to report unsafe working conditions. cleaning: no enhanced cleaning measures, aside from giving staff cleaning supplies to clean their own areas. no written plan for cleaning. the restrooms appear to be dirtier than before the covid-19 pandemic. masks: masks are not required when working at desks. employees do not wear masks outside their workspaces as required. no proper and consistent signage that face masks are required to enter the buildings. the administrators have stated the wearing of masks will not be enforced, and encourage masks be worn when six feet of separation cannot be guaranteed. it is up to each individual and department to use masks as they feel comfortable. administrators believe eo 2020-153 does not apply because the campus is not a ¿public space¿ when it is not open to the public. social distancing: very little and inconsistent signage indicating where six feet from individual workspaces. employees are encouraged to use technology, such as zoom, to hold meetings; across campus face to face meetings are being held. health screenings: human resources director states employees are not required to conduct health screenings. it is suggested employees use the mi symptoms web app as a self-monitoring tool. many staff are not doing health screenings and those who have failed the health screenings have not been alerted by human resources until hours or days after failing the screening. no cdc personal hygiene signage. remote work is not being allowed when it is possible.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: COVID 19 exposure. There have been 17 employees with symptoms and possible positive results and have been out of work. We have not been informed or warned, by law the employer is obligated to inform employees in writing of such cases. The company has not sanitized exposed areas and we manufacture food products for the sale to the public. T8 CCR §3205(c)(3)(3). COVID-19 Prevention. Written COVID-19 Prevention Program. Investigating and responding to COVID-19 cases in the workplace. The employer failed to implement an effective COVID-19 Prevention Program, in that, the employer did not give notice of the potential COVID-19 exposure, within one business day, in a way that does not reveal any personal identifying information of the COVID-19 case, all exposed employees. T8 CCR §3205(c)(10)(B). COVID-19 Prevention. Written COVID-19 Prevention Program. Exclusion of COVID-19 cases. The purpose of this subsection is to limit transmission of COVID-19 in the workplace. The employer failed to implement an effective COVID-19 Prevention Program, in that, the employer did not exclude employees with COVID-19 exposure from the workplace for 14 days after the last known COVID-19 exposure. T8 CCR §3205(c)(9)(E). COVID-19 Prevention. Written COVID-19 Prevention Program. Reporting, recordkeeping, and access. The employer failed to implement a written COVID-19 Prevention Program, in that, the employer did not keep a record of and track all COVID-19 cases with the employee¿s name, contact information, occupation, location where the employee worked, the date of the last day at the workplace, and the date of a positive COVID-19 and also did not make this available to employees, with personal identifying information removed. T8 CCR §3205(c)(8)(C)(1). COVID-19 Prevention. Written COVID-19 Prevention Program. Other engineering controls, administrative controls, and personal protective equipment. The employer failed to implement an effective written COVID-19 Prevention Program, in that, the employer did not implement cleaning and disinfecting procedures by identifying and regularly cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces and objects, such as doorknobs, elevator buttons, equipment, tools, handrails, handles, controls, bathroom surfaces, or other exposed areas where employees frequent share or touch.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The employer is not following OSHA guidance to protect workers from exposure to Covid-19: 1. The employer did not adapt infection control strategies based on a thorough hazard assessment, using appropriate combinations of engineering and administrative controls, safe work practices, and taking appropriate steps to protect other workers from exposure to SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, in the workplace. These steps might include mandatory mask use, physical distancing or actions as a result of a confirmed case, such as cleaning and disinfecting the work environment, notifying other workers to monitor themselves for signs/symptoms of COVID-19, following quarantine guidelines or implementing a screening program in the workplace (e.g., for signs/symptoms of COVID-19 among workers).

Hazard.Desc.Loc: T8 5199(g)(3)(B) Employees are performing high hazard procedures (e.g. high flow nasal cannula) on COVID-19 patients without being provided powered air purifying respirators (PAPRs) or respirators providing equivalent protection. Hazard.Desc.Loc: Nurses have been exposed to COVID 19 positive patient and are not being tested themselves unless they exhibit symptoms. RNs must re-use CAPRs indefinitely unless the hospital determines the chinstrap is loose, which reportedly happens after one 12-hour shift. RNs performing nebulizing treatments are not allowed to wear CAPRs. Notification of exposures is not happening on nurses' days off. PPE is inappropriately being re-used and there are not adequately sized N95s for all. Staff are told to improvise. Some COVID 19 positive patients are in rooms without negative pressure while receiving nebulizing treatments. Airborne precaution signs are not always posted. Additional Complaint received April 8, 2020: -Location: Bellevue ICU, South Tower Third Floor. Rooms 301-308 & 323-332 -Alleged Hazard: Large number of COVID19 positive patients. Mgmt has created a "clean" side and "dirty" side. Nurses on dirty side expected to remain in a dirty gown for their shift duration, changing gloves between rooms. Nurses stations and charts in this area contaminated with COVID19. Can't drink anything on the dirty side.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer is allowing employees to continue working inside the facility while sick (coughing, sneezing, sore throat, etc.). 2. The Packaging Department is experiencing a large outbreak causing many of the employees to be out of work. The employer is taking employees from other departments to fill in. When employees display concerns or fear of moving to packaging the employer threatens the employees of being written up. 3. Employees are wearing re-usable 'frocks' on the floor. During breaks, frocks are hung up on hooks, some hooks holding multiple frocks. The frocks are not cleaned between breaks and employees cannot ensure they are putting on the same frock they had on prior to break. Employees fear the virus is being spread by means of unintentionally sharing equipment. 4. Employees are not properly wearing face masks inside the facility (below their nose and/or mouth) and the employer/supervisors are not ensuring employees are wearing face coverings correctly. 5. Supervisors are giving employees a hard time obtaining a new mask once theirs becomes soiled, wet, or damaged. 6. Some departments, to include but not limited to Frankfurter, where social distancing is not feasible, the employer had installed physical barriers; however, the barriers have been removed. 7. Management and supervisors are not ensuring employees are washing their hands prior to entering the production floor. 8. There are slip and fall hazards near the cooler in the Smokehouse department caused from oil dripping on the floor. The employer is not ensuring the oil is cleaned up in a timely manner.
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: 1. the employer is allowing employees to continue working inside the facility while sick (coughing, sneezing, sore throat, etc.). 2. the packaging department is experiencing a large outbreak causing many of the employees to be out of work. the employer is taking employees from other departments to fill in. when employees display concerns or fear of moving to packaging the employer threatens the employees of being written up. 3. employees are wearing re-usable 'frocks' on the floor. during breaks, frocks are hung up on hooks, some hooks holding multiple frocks. the frocks are not cleaned between breaks and employees cannot ensure they are putting on the same frock they had on prior to break. employees fear the virus is being spread by means of unintentionally sharing equipment. 4. employees are not properly wearing face masks inside the facility (below their nose and/or mouth) and the employer/supervisors are not ensuring employees are wearing face coverings correctly. 5. supervisors are giving employees a hard time obtaining a new mask once theirs becomes soiled, wet, or damaged. 6. some departments, to include but not limited to frankfurter, where social distancing is not feasible, the employer had installed physical barriers; however, the barriers have been removed. 7. management and supervisors are not ensuring employees are washing their hands prior to entering the production floor. 8. there are slip and fall hazards near the cooler in the smokehouse department caused from oil dripping on the floor. the employer is not ensuring the oil is cleaned up in a timely manner.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Site: Conley Terminal 1. Employer has not developed and implemented a plan/procedure/protocol to protect employees who work in close proximity to co-workers and are unable to social distance. Employee reported fever and feeling sick last week and was told to keep working. Employee finally went home but the company did not let the other workers know that he was sick. 2. Employer has not provided personal protective equipment to employees who work in close proximity to co-workers; 3. Employer has not provided hand sanitizer or cleaning materials to employees who work in close proximity to co-workers. Recommendations: 1. Contact Mass DPH or local health authority for assistance; 2. Consult CDC and OSHA webpages for assistance; a. Develop an Infectious Disease Preparedness and Response Plan; b. Prepare to Implement Basic Infection Prevention Measures c. Develop Policies and Procedures for Prompt Identification and Isolation of Sick People, if appropriate d. Develop, Implement, and Communicate about Workplace Flexibilities and Protections; e. Implement Workplace Controls, Engineering Controls, and Administrative Controls; f. Implement Safe Work Practices; g. Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and training in accordance with OSHA standards; h. Communicate and train employee regarding the measures to take to reduce potential exposure; SOURCE: Guidance on Preparing the Workplace for COVID-19, OSHA publication 3990-03

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Bus drivers are not being provided with cloth masks to protect them from COVID19 rather than with the more effective N95 or KN95 shields. In October my employer plans to resume boarding passengers via the front door of the bus to collect fares. Drivers are not allowed to refuse service to passengers not wearing masks. The plexiglass shield we have had installed recently on our coaches are not air tight. All they do is protect the driver from any direct sneeze or cough. They do not protect us from aerosol contamination. In July we were told we would be provided with both the shield and N95 or KN95 masks before they would resume front door boarding. Now I am concerned that we will not be provided with anything more than cloth masks even after we start front door boarding. They gave us KN95 masks during the smoky conditions from the fires but the sign at my base said they were only for during the fires. In addition to this the plexiglass shields they have installed present a distracting and hazardous glare to drivers during day time hours. We are being told we have to manually open and shut these doors at every stop until they are able to make them automated. So for two reasons these new shields are not safe. They create distractions and glare that could result in accidents or injury, and they will certainly cause L&I injury to drivers because of the repetitive motion of having to manually open and close them at every stop (and on hills these shields are very hard to open. I will also add that the anxiety is very high for some of us older drivers whenever we have passengers on our buses refusing to wear masks. I have personally received death threats from passengers for asking them to wear a mask? and i haven?t noticed any increased police protection against assault. The shields we have been given can easily be opened by an assailant, trapping us in our seats. And we can do nothing about it. We have been given no authority to deny service to people without masks and very soon we will have them walking right past us & paying a fare (or arguing with us about all the things passengers like to argue with drivers about) while we are not getting the protection we need nor are we receiving hazard pay.Last thing. I've heard that they want us to continue to drive even in the winter with the fans blowing and thewindows open. And yet it doesn?t seem like they are planning to grant us with additional sick leave. Even just doing this will make us more likely to get colds and / or the flu.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The facility has an epidemic of COVID-19 on the tan unit and upper red. Staff have not been provided with the proper personal protective equipment (PPE). Staff are given the same gowns to wear in the infected areas and have not been directed to change gowns once leaving the unit. 2. Proper face mask shields have also not been provided to staff to protect themselves from transmission of the virus. 3. Staff are directed to work in the front of the lobby to assist with the check-in of other staff members for security purposes, after an essential worker has been exposed to the virus the entire shift. Staff that has been in a hazardous environment should be quarantined, but that is not the case at the facility. 4. Staff should not have to touch inmate meal trays when the pod is under quarantine, especially when staff have not been give the proper PPE or training to assist with the prevention of spreading the virus. 5. Staff have worked in pods when it was later discovered that inmates tested positive for COVID-19. Some staff have not worn proper PPE when in the pods and could have been exposed to the virus and have not quarantined. In addition, medications have been administered to inmates without the employees wearing any PPE, which could have exposed the staff to the virus.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The employer has not developed an effective plan to address the specific exposure risks, sources of exposure, routes of transmission and other unique characteristics of SARS-CoV-2. The plan should focus on engineering controls, administrative controls, work practice controls and personal protective equipment. Such as but not limited to: 1. The employer is not following the CDC recommendations to protect employees. 2. The employer is not following State, and local safety requirements to protect employees. 3. The employer is not providing sanitary/good housekeeping processes, social distancing processes, or PPE as necessary for employee safety and to reduce exposure. 4. The employer is not communicating adequate information to ensure employees understand and adhere to safe work practices.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Employer is not notifying an employee of exposure to a COVID-19 case, not excluding employees who are COVID-19 positive or excluding employees who have had close contact with known COVID-19 case as well as not cleaning high touch surfaces. 1. The employer did not ensure that employees who were exposed to a known COVID-19 case during the high-risk exposure period in the management office were given notification of the exposure within one business day. T8 CCR 3205(c)(3)(B)(3). 2. The employer did not ensure that employees who were exposed to a known COVID-19 case during the high-risk exposure period were excluded from the work area until the requirements of subsection (c)(10) were met. T8 CCR 3205(c)(9)(B). 3. The employer did not ensure to exclude employees who are positive for COVID-19 until the return to work requirements of subsection (c)(10) are met. T8 CCR 3205(c)(9)(A). 4. The employer did not ensure to implement a cleaning and disinfecting procedure which includes the identification and regular cleaning of high touched surfaces in the waxing rooms, restrooms and in the reception area of the establishment. T8 CCR 3205(c)(7)(B). 5. The employer did not ensure that facial coverings were provided and worn by all unvaccinated employees at the restaurant store location. T8 CCR 3205(c)(6)(A). 6. The employer did not ensure to review applicable orders and guidance from the State of California and local health departments related to COVID-19 hazards and prevention, specifically the local requirements for the masking of employees. T8 CCR 3205(c)(2)(F). 7. The employer did not ensure to implement measures to communicate with non-employees the requirements for masking in the establishment. T8 CCR 3205(c)(6)(i). 8. The employer did not ensure that the restrooms in the establishment were kept clean and maintained in good working order and accessible to employees at all times. T8 CCR 3364(b).
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: employer is not notifying an employee of exposure to a covid-19 case, not excluding employees who are covid-19 positive or excluding employees who have had close contact with known covid-19 case as well as not cleaning high touch surfaces. 1. the employer did not ensure that employees who were exposed to a known covid-19 case during the high-risk exposure period in the management office were given notification of the exposure within one business day. t8 ccr 3205(c)(3)(b)(3). 2. the employer did not ensure that employees who were exposed to a known covid-19 case during the high-risk exposure period were excluded from the work area until the requirements of subsection (c)(10) were met. t8 ccr 3205(c)(9)(b). 3. the employer did not ensure to exclude employees who are positive for covid-19 until the return to work requirements of subsection (c)(10) are met. t8 ccr 3205(c)(9)(a). 4. the employer did not ensure to implement a cleaning and disinfecting procedure which includes the identification and regular cleaning of high touched surfaces in the waxing rooms, restrooms and in the reception area of the establishment. t8 ccr 3205(c)(7)(b). 5. the employer did not ensure that facial coverings were provided and worn by all unvaccinated employees at the restaurant store location. t8 ccr 3205(c)(6)(a). 6. the employer did not ensure to review applicable orders and guidance from the state of california and local health departments related to covid-19 hazards and prevention, specifically the local requirements for the masking of employees. t8 ccr 3205(c)(2)(f). 7. the employer did not ensure to implement measures to communicate with non-employees the requirements for masking in the establishment. t8 ccr 3205(c)(6)(i). 8. the employer did not ensure that the restrooms in the establishment were kept clean and maintained in good working order and accessible to employees at all times. t8 ccr 3364(b).

Employees are concerned that the employer has only decontaminated the USAA section of the call center floor, but has not decontaminated the Costco or Equifax areas. 7. Hazard.Desc.Loc: Medical Support Assistant Staff Work Area: Employees are not able to quickly get out of this area in an emergency because egress is obstructed. Door locks behind employees, there is no quick egress bar on the door, and the swipe card is not functioning. Points of Entry into the Facility: Screening Points are Inadequate; Patients are not being actively screened at each entry point prior to entering into the facility to minimize the spread of infection. There is no external or single-entry point to screen patients. Patients potentially positive with COVID-19 are entering through the lobby and up to the main check-in desk; exposing non-clinical staff as they are not provided with, or required to wear, Personal Protective Equipment (PPE). Hospital screening points are in enclosed walkways shared with non-clinical personnel that are not wearing PPE. Non-clinical staff are expected to protect themselves only by social distancing and hand washing. Inadequate supply, improper use, and lack of accountability for Personal Protective Equipment (PPE): 1) Employees (clinical and non-clinical) are not provided with enough PPE to adequately protect themselves from the COVID-19 virus. - Non-clinical employees are denied PPE (surgical mask, N95 respirators, gowns, face shields) when working in areas where COVID-19 positive patients, and Patients Under Investigation (PUI), are being cared for. - Clinical employees working with COVID-19 positive patients, or Patients Under Investigation (PUI), are provided one face shield, are told to reuse N95 masks, or are provided one surgical mask per day. 2) Employees are provided inadequate respiratory protection/masks when working with patients that have, or potentially have (PUI), COVID-19. 3) The employer does not have proper contamination prevention and decontamination policies in place. Infection control practices are inadequate and include: improper handling, storage, and extended use of PPE that is creating cross-contamination issues for staff, and potentially contaminating the "clean" work areas where other employees are not wearing PPE.

patients are not being actively screened at each entry point prior to entering into the facility to minimize the spread of infection. there is no external or single-entry point to screen patients. patients potentially positive with covid-19 are entering through the lobby and up to the main check-in desk; exposing non-clinical staff as they are not provided with, or required to wear, personal protective equipment (ppe). hospital screening points are in enclosed walkways shared with non-clinical personnel that are not wearing ppe. non-clinical staff are expected to protect themselves only by social distancing and hand washing. inadequate supply, improper use, and lack of accountability for personal protective equipment (ppe): 1) employees (clinical and non-clinical) are not provided with enough ppe to adequately protect themselves from the covid-19 virus. - non-clinical employees are denied ppe (surgical mask, n95 respirators, gowns, face shields) when working in areas where covid-19 positive patients, and patients under investigation (pui), are being cared for. - clinical employees working with covid-19 positive patients, or patients under investigation (pui), are provided one face shield, are told to reuse n95 masks, or are provided one surgical mask per day. 2) employees are provided inadequate respiratory protection/masks when working with patients that have, or potentially have (pui), covid-19. 3) the employer does not have proper contamination prevention and decontamination policies in place. infection control practices are inadequate and include: improper handling, storage, and extended use of ppe that is creating cross-contamination issues for staff, and potentially contaminating the "clean" work areas where other employees are not wearing ppe.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: - This is a dental service organization that has implemented the use of 3M N95 9010 respirators without first obtaining medical clearance and fit testing for employees, even though it has been brought to the attention of management several times. - According to the OSHA guidelines, each clinical member should be wearing gowns for aerosol creating procedures. The company has not yet provided such gowns that will adequately protect the employees. - Employees are not following required SOP such as wearing masks and face shields in the office, proper decontamination protocols, and PPE disposal.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The employer is not following recommended practices to protect employees from SARS-CoV-2, which causes the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). Alleged hazards including not following recommended practices such as, but not limited to the following: 1. The employer has not provide masks or face coverings for all workers. 2. The employer has not ensured that there is 6 feet of distance between employees in all departments and production. For example, in the slaughterhouse and cooling rooms. 3. The employer has not informed employees when or where there was a positive case of coronavirus. This information is critical so that co-workers can self-quarantine for 14 days and protect their families by ensuring they are not sick or exposing others.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: On May 2nd, before employees began their shift they were informed that 22 out of the 87 residents present at the site were COVID-19 positive. Upon beginning their shift, an employee was not provided either a N-95 mask or face shield even though they were working directly with positive residents. The employee was only provided a cloth mask, and they were informed that they did not have enough face shields for everyone. However, management was provided N-95 masks. An employee subsequently tested positive from working that day because they were not provided the appropriate personal protective equipment.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. There is a sign on the front desk ordering employees to mop/wipe surfaces with pine sol and bleach which are clearly labeled stating do not mix or it will form chlorine gas. 2. Employees are not instructed/trained on how to prepare/mix the chemicals used, hazards of the chemicals used or what to do if it was to get on their skin or eyes. 3. Chemicals are mixed in a chemical sink and the room is very dark with poor lighting. 4. There are no SDS's for the cleaning chemicals used. 5. PPE is shrugged off as an optional item for all interactions with cleaning chemicals. 6. Chemicals are stored with food items and this same room is also used for lunch breaks. 7. Throughout the day, the same rags used to clean the bathroom are also used to clean the treadmills and common touch-points, staff are told to only get a new rag if the old one is used to wiped up visible pee or excrement.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Concerns regarding safety of employees. When the pandemic first created the need for many closures, employees continued to work in the warehouse and inside containers loading and unloading. Employees were never compensated with bonuses or additional pay, but continued to put in the same dedication they always had. From early March until May 8, there were no precautions taken, no masks, no hand sanitizer, no distancing and no sign of union concern. No compensation for continuing to get the job done while others were at home, and no union representation in the matter. Around May 8, the Governor asks the people to wear masks and Local 89 had some made, and was handing them out. Some employees signed medical waivers that they couldn't wear them and the rest of the employees signed a paper saying that they would attempt to wear them. As the weather has warmed up, most of the employees have worn them under their chins or hanging from their ears, as the heat is unbearable and the masks make breathing difficult. It was worse working in the day. The Local 89 never showed concern and continued to ride buses into the parking lot without wearing them. The week of July 6, the Governor made masks mandatory. the union continued to collect normal union dues and support the political agenda. The Union has not represented employee's safety in this heat, nor spoke to encourage compensation for the employees continued work while others draw unemployment benefits. Even Kroger and Amazon have been compensated for risking their health to get the jobs done.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: MultiCare is not following mask requirements per the L&I updated from 6/14/21. They allow unvaccinated employees to unmask in non-patient-care areas and do not require proof or attestation of vaccination. (They ask for a daily "symptom attestation," but no vaccine attestation.) You can see in the attached email that masking is only "recommended" for unvaccinated staff. This was a memo sent out to all Puget Sound-area employees. MultiCare's stated position is that vaccines are recommended for staff, but many in management are openly contemptuous toward vaccines and masking, tell staff that masks are ineffective and vaccines are experimental, and erroneously believe they cannot ask vaccine status due to HIPAA. There is a culture of mockery toward patients or staff who bring up concerns about masking. I have brought up concerns with multiple people in management, but nothing has changed, and I am fearful of retaliation if I continue to bring up my concerns.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Improper masking -Improper social distancing -Questionable cleaning -Questionable contact tracing/quarantining standards -Unclear CDC adherence. On August 11, 2021, The Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE) issued a letter to all superintendents titled, "Enforcement of Universal Masking Requirement." This letter highlights Executive Order 2021-18, that requires that all students, staff, and visitors wear masks indoors in all P-12 schools in Illinois. While IL OSHA cannot directly enforce this executive order, the Illinois Occupational Safety and Health Act requires employers to protect employees from recognized hazards that cause or are likely to cause death or serious physical harm to its employees (820 ILCS 219/20(a)). Employers that violate this section of the Act may be cited and/or referred to another regulatory authority such as the ISBE. Employers that intentionally violate or show plain indifference to this section of the Act may be cited with a violation classified as willful. (820 ILCS 219/20) Sec. 20. Duties of employers and employees. (a) Every public employer must provide reasonable protection to the lives, health, and safety of its employees and must furnish to each of its employees employment and a workplace which are free from recognized hazards that cause or are likely to cause death or serious physical harm to its employees. The District must show that they have implemented measures to protect employees from SARS-CoV-2, and these measures are enforced. The school board and superintendent are ultimately responsible for ensuring a safe workplace and complying with the Illinois Occupational Safety and Health Act.

(820 ilcs 219/20) sec. 20. duties of employers and employees. (a) every public employer must provide reasonable protection to the lives, health, and safety of its employees and must furnish to each of its employees employment and a workplace which are free from recognized hazards that cause or are likely to cause death or serious physical harm to its employees. the district must show that they have implemented measures to protect employees from sars-cov-2, and these measures are enforced. the school board and superintendent are ultimately responsible for ensuring a safe workplace and complying with the illinois occupational safety and health act.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Points of Entry into the Facility: Screening Points are Inadequate; Patients are not being actively screened at each entry point prior to entering into the facility to minimize the spread of infection. There is no external or single-entry point to screen patients. Patients potentially positive with COVID-19 are entering through the lobby and up to the main check-in desk; exposing non-clinical staff as they are not provided with, or required to wear, Personal Protective Equipment (PPE). Hospital screening points are in enclosed walkways shared with non-clinical personnel that are not wearing PPE. Non-clinical staff are expected to protect themselves only by social distancing and hand washing. Inadequate supply, improper use, and lack of accountability for Personal Protective Equipment (PPE): 1) Employees (clinical and non-clinical) are not provided with enough PPE to adequately protect themselves from the COVID-19 virus. - Non-clinical employees are denied PPE (surgical mask, N95 respirators, gowns, face shields) when working in areas where COVID-19 positive patients, and Patients Under Investigation (PUI), are being cared for. - Clinical employees working with COVID-19 positive patients, or Patients Under Investigation (PUI), are provided one face shield, are told to reuse N95 masks, or are provided one surgical mask per day. 2) Employees are provided inadequate respiratory protection/masks when working with patients that have, or potentially have (PUI), COVID-19. 3) The employer does not have proper contamination prevention and decontamination policies in place. Infection control practices are inadequate and include: improper handling, storage, and extended use of PPE that is creating cross-contamination issues for staff, and potentially contaminating the "clean" work areas where other employees are not wearing PPE.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: I am a frequent customer and patron of Bob Rohrman Honda in Lafayette, IN. Across 5+ visits to the business in the last 6 months, I have noticed that the large majority of employees (notably the service team and the female employee in charge of payment and billing) were either a) not wearing masks when interacting with customers or other workers, b) wearing their masks below their nose and mouth when interacting with customers or other works, or c) wearing masks that are essentially ineffective at stopping the spread of COVID-19 (i.e. neck gaiters, very thin fabric masks, etc.). This has been a consistent trend across my visits to the business. Though other measures have been taken to allow for sanitary conditions (hand sanitizer available, signs prohibiting entry without a mask (a bit ironic)), this is unacceptable behavior for a business of this size and reputation. For example, while waiting for my car service appointment to be completed I sat in the waiting room adjacent to the service area, I was joined alongside 2 elderly gentlemen (i.e. an extremely high-risk population) both of whom were properly wearing masks. Several employees walked by or were within a 10-15 foot range that were either not wearing masks or wearing them improperly. The female employee working at the cash register for the service appointments did not pull her mask up above her nose or mouth when one of the elderly gentlemen walked up to pay. This is just one example of the gross negligence and/or ignorance I have seen at this business.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Plant has approximately 7 machines, each with a grinder, creating loud noise and hearing distress to employees. No PPE provided. 2. Employees in the plant have difficulty breathing due to fumes from the 1 operable diesel tow motor (Caterpillar). Near misses occur due to no operable horn. 3. Asbestos and/or fiberglass insulation falls on employees from overhead in the plant, including the vicinity around the 110 machine. Employees have to cover product to prevent contamination during production. Occurs often when nearby train rattles building. 4. Facility is infested with rats and rodents in office and plant area. Some old traps are present, but ineffective. 5. Employees operating drill press and plant machines have to reach into machines to retrieve parts, while still energized. No LO/TO procedures followed or training provided. Drill Press and Plant area. 6. Various acrylic chemicals used and mixed by Plant Manager in vicinity of employees, who are exposed to strong fumes. Employees are not provided with PPE, Hazard Communication training, or access to Safety Data Sheets. 7. Employer does not take measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19. Does not clean surfaces, provide masks, or other cleaning materials. An employee was directed to work a machine in the plant after it was used by a sick employee who had later tested positive for Covid-19.

Contrary to 29 CFR 1910.134. 2) Employer has failed to assess the workplace to determine if hazards are present, or are likely to be present, which necessitate the use of personal protective equipment (PPE). It was reported that warehouse employees are not being provided PPE like, but not limited to, gloves for general use or face fitting respirators. Contrary to 29 CFR 1910.132. 3) Employer has potentially failed to provide a safe and healthful workplace. It was reported that the hand sanitizer dispensers are empty and the employer has failed to refill the dispensers. This is contrary to 5(a)(1) of the OSH Act of 1970.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The District has not implemented and/or enforced hazard mitigations that include but are not limited to student masking for SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, to protect employees. On August 11, 2021, The Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE) issued a letter to all superintendents titled, "Enforcement of Universal Masking Requirement." This letter highlights Executive Order 2021-18, that requires that all students, staff, and visitors wear masks indoors in all P-12 schools in Illinois. While IL OSHA cannot directly enforce this executive order, the Illinois Occupational Safety and Health Act requires employers to protect employees from recognized hazards that cause or are likely to cause death or serious physical harm to its employees (820 ILCS 219/20(a)). Employers that violate this section of the Act may be cited and/or referred to another regulatory authority such as the ISBE. Employers that intentionally violate or show plain indifference to this section of the Act may be cited with a violation classified as willful. (820 ILCS 219/20) Sec. 20. Duties of employers and employees. (a) Every public employer must provide reasonable protection to the lives, health, and safety of its employees and must furnish to each of its employees employment and a workplace which are free from recognized hazards that cause or are likely to cause death or serious physical harm to its employees. The District must show that they have implemented measures to protect employees from SARS-CoV-2, and these measures are enforced. 2. It is alleged that an employee of the District was recently hospitalized with COVID-19 within the past two weeks. IL OSHA requests that the District provides their determination as to why this hospitalization was not work-related. Please provide this as a separate document to your formal response to maintain confidentiality of protected health information. If the hospitalization was work related, and the employee was admitted, the District is required to report this incident immediately to 217-782-7860. The District is also required to log this as a respiratory illness on their injury and illness logs (OSHA 300 logs). The school board and superintendent are ultimately responsible for ensuring a safe workplace and complying with the Illinois Occupational Safety and Health Act.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer is spraying solvent based paints with no fire suppression system in Paint Line 2. 2. A COVID-19 pandemic plan has not been implemented for employees to include, disinfecting and sanitizing, social distancing, personal protective equipment. Keyboards and printers are not disinfected and sanitized after each use. There's no social distancing in the cafeteria. Employer is not enforcing the proper use of the mask. 3. Lockout/Tagout was not used while removing plastic from the mold inside Injection Molding Press 1 located in Building 1 on July 2020. 4. On October 2018, a forklift tipped over while positing an injection mold into Injection Molding Press 1 located in Building 1. 5. Pallets of boxes fell over when a forklift operator improperly stacked them in Southwest corner of Building 2 on February 2019. Boxes came close to falling onto an employee. 6. A forklift driver struck and pushed a pallet into rework tables located in the Polish Room at Plant 1 on January 2020. 7. Forklift operators are not using their seatbelts and speed throughout Buildings 1, 2 and 3. 8. A forklift rolled down the ramp located between Buildings 1 and 2 and struck a guardrail on June 2018. The operator did not set the parking brakes. 9. The temperature control system for the tank containing solvent based clearcoat malfunctioned located behind Paint Line in Building 1 on June 2020. 10. Side cutters used to cut 3/8' of ABS plastic is causing blisters to employee's hands and wrist problems located at Press 1 in Building 1. 11. Angle grinder was not guarded in Maintenance Area. An employee cut their thumb on November 2019. 12. Roofs are leaking in Building 1 causing slip hazards.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Forty four (44) employees on Tour 2 alone are sick with Covid-19. Three (3) employees vomited in the facility on 1-10-20. The employer is not taking adequate action and measures to protect employees from Covid-19 infection according to CDC and OSHA guidelines: 1 The employer is not enforcing the use of face coverings for the employees working in the facility. 2 The employer is not enforcing social distancing by employees, in all departments. 3 The employer is not screening employees for possible Covid-19 symptoms, or fever, upon entry into the facility. 4 The employer is not adequately sanitizing areas, including common touch surfaces , and the bathrooms, and areas where employees worked tested positive. There has been no thorough sanitization of said areas. In addition in the bathroom there is mold around the sinks. 5 The employer has not trained the employees in the Covid-19 policies, such as the USPS Covid-19 Safety and Health Plan, their sick and leave policies if an employee tests positive for Covid-19, in departments including Tour 3, the overnight Tour. Employees report no such inservices have been provided by managers for employees. 6 There is an infestation of insects or vermin in the facility. 7 There is no hand sanitizer available in the facility for employees to sanitize their hands when they can't use washing facilities to thoroughly wash hands. 8 Employees are not being told, or notified, of how many other employees in the facility have become Covid-19 positive, or where those employees worked. 9 Fire extinguishers are blocked with improperly stored materials or rubbish, and exit doors are blocked with old cardboard boxes and mail carts. 10 On Tour 3, the overnight Tour, there was an employee who tested positive who worked in OI Cell also known as the Rapid Scan. However, the managers did not inform the employees who may have been exposed to this employee of the positive status, nor determine who else may have been exposed to the employee to address possible additional exposures. 11 Employees are coming to work sick because they have used leave or The Family First Coronavirus Response Act as administered by USPS, and have to work to get paid. This is increasing Covid-19 transmission in the facility.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Points of Entry into the Facility: Screening Points are Inadequate; Patients are not being actively screened at each entry point prior to entering into the facility to minimize the spread of infection. There is no external or single-entry point to screen patients. Patients potentially positive with COVID-19 are entering through the lobby and up to the main check-in desk; exposing non-clinical staff as they are not provided with, or required to wear, Personal Protective Equipment (PPE). Hospital screening points are in enclosed walkways shared with non-clinical personnel that are not wearing PPE. Non-clinical staff are expected to protect themselves only by social distancing and hand washing. Inadequate supply, improper use, and lack of accountability for Personal Protective Equipment (PPE): 1) Employees (clinical and non-clinical) are not provided with enough PPE to adequately protect themselves from the COVID-19 virus. - Non-clinical employees are denied PPE (surgical mask, N95 respirators, gowns, face shields) when working in areas where COVID-19 positive patients, and Patients Under Investigation (PUI), are being cared for. - Clinical employees working with COVID-19 positive patients, or Patients Under Investigation (PUI), are provided one face shield, are told to reuse N95 masks, or are provided one surgical mask per day. 2) Employees are provided inadequate respiratory protection/masks when working with patients that have, or potentially have (PUI), COVID-19. 3) The employer does not have proper contamination prevention and decontamination policies in place. Infection control practices are inadequate and include: improper handling, storage, and extended use of PPE that is creating cross-contamination issues for staff, and potentially contaminating the "clean" work areas where other employees are not wearing PPE. Additional Guidance Appropriate requirements under the CDC shall be followed, as well as, required OSHA standards including, but not limited to, 29 CFR 1910.1030, 1910.132, and 1910.134. Appropriate engineering, administrative, and Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) controls need to be established and implemented. The Tuberculosis directive CPL 02-02-078 can also be used as a tool. It has good information on prevention, safe workpractices, engineering controls, and PPE. Guidance under 29 CFR 1910.1030 includes, but is not limited to, the following: 1910.1030(d)(3)(i) Provision. When there is occupational exposure, the employer shall provide, at no cost to the employee, appropriate personal protective equipment such as, but not limited to, gloves, gowns, laboratory coats, face shields or masks and eye protection, and mouthpieces, resuscitation bags, pocket masks, or other ventilation devices. Personal protective equipment will be considered ¿appropriate¿ only if it does not permit blood or other potentially infectious materials to pass through to or reach the employee's work clothes, street clothes, undergarments, skin, eyes, mouth, or other mucous membranes under normal conditions of use and for the duration of time which the protective equipment will be used. 1910.1030(d)(3)(iii) Accessibility. The employer shall ensure that appropriate personal protective equipment in the appropriate sizes is readily accessible at the worksite or is issued to employees. Hypoallergenic gloves, glove liners, powderless gloves, or other similar alternatives shall be readily accessible to those employees who are allergic to the gloves normally provided. 1910.1030(d)(3)(x) Masks, Eye Protection, and Face Shields. Masks in combination with eye protection devices, such as goggles or glasses with solid side shields, or chin-length face shields, shall be worn whenever splashes, spray, spatter, or droplets of blood or other potentially infectious materials may be generated and eye, nose, or mouth contamination can be reasonably anticipated. 1910.1030(d)(3)(xi) Gowns, Aprons, and Other Protective Body Clothing. Approp
