Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. There is absolutely NO staggering of passing time or lunches. Students are eating lunch 10 students to a table, obviously without masks. 2. We have been instructed to sanitize our students' desks at the end of each class, by spraying hand sanitizer on each desk. When we began to quickly run out of sanitizer, we were told to only use one spray on each desk. We were also emailed a video on how to sanitize our students' desks. The video demonstrates spraying one spray per desk. It then instructs us to use C-fold paper towels to wipe surfaces that "need wiping." It does not, however, explain what those surfaces are. 3. There is not any social distancing in place at the school in which I am employed. I have an average of 30 students (face-to-face) in each of my classes. While there are plexi-glass dividers on each table of two, there is nothing in between students who are in front of/behind other students, who are far less than six feet apart. 4. We have had ONE email that told us to report any feelings of unsafe working conditions to another person in our central administration office. I am not sure if this is protocol but I will speak for myself and several of my co-workers, that we do not feel comfortable expressing these concerns with administration, for fear of retaliation. There has been no other information provided as far as reporting unsafe working conditions. Based on this complaint, we are conducting an off-site complaint investigation. We do not intend to initiate an on-site inspection currently. As part of the off-site complaint investigation, you are requested to perform a self-audit of the alleged hazardous conditions and take appropriate steps to protect employee health, including complying with the MIOSHA Emergency Rules for Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). We ask that you complete these steps within two workdays of the date of this letter.
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: 1. there is absolutely no staggering of passing time or lunches. students are eating lunch 10 students to a table, obviously without masks. 2. we have been instructed to sanitize our students' desks at the end of each class, by spraying hand sanitizer on each desk. when we began to quickly run out of sanitizer, we were told to only use one spray on each desk. we were also emailed a video on how to sanitize our students' desks. the video demonstrates spraying one spray per desk. it then instructs us to use c-fold paper towels to wipe surfaces that "need wiping." it does not, however, explain what those surfaces are. 3. there is not any social distancing in place at the school in which i am employed. i have an average of 30 students (face-to-face) in each of my classes. while there are plexi-glass dividers on each table of two, there is nothing in between students who are in front of/behind other students, who are far less than six feet apart. 4. we have had one email that told us to report any feelings of unsafe working conditions to another person in our central administration office. i am not sure if this is protocol but i will speak for myself and several of my co-workers, that we do not feel comfortable expressing these concerns with administration, for fear of retaliation. there has been no other information provided as far as reporting unsafe working conditions. based on this complaint, we are conducting an off-site complaint investigation. we do not intend to initiate an on-site inspection currently. as part of the off-site complaint investigation, you are requested to perform a self-audit of the alleged hazardous conditions and take appropriate steps to protect employee health, including complying with the miosha emergency rules for coronavirus disease 2019 (covid-19). we ask that you complete these steps within two workdays of the date of this letter.

Employer did not adapt infection control strategies based on a thorough hazard assessment, using appropriate combinations of engineering and administrative controls, safe work practices, and taking appropriate steps to protect other workers from exposure to SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, in the workplace. These steps might include mandatory mask use, physical distancing or actions as a result of a confirmed case, such as cleaning and disinfecting the work environment, notifying other workers to monitor themselves for signs/symptoms of COVID-19, following quarantine guidelines or implementing a screening program in the workplace (e.g., for signs/symptoms of COVID-19 among workers).

Hazard.Desc.Loc: On December 4th, the employer conducted dental procedures on a patient. Employees of the facility had close contact with this patient during that appointment. On the same day the employer held a close-contact meeting with all employees where no masks were worn and social distancing was not practiced. The next day (December 5th) the patient contacted the dental office and notified the employer they tested positive for Covid-19, therefore all employees had potential exposure to COVID-19 on December 4th. The employer required, in writing, that employees come back to work without negative tests and without quarantining the week ending December 11th, 2020.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: It is alleged that: Three employees covering two shifts have tested positive for the Coronavirus. The employer is not following the recommendations put in place by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) to help prevent and slow the spread of COVID-19 in the workplace. Safety practices for workers who may have had exposure to a person with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 are recommended as follows: Pre-screen employees to ensure an employee does not have a temperature upon arriving at work. Employees who have been exposed should self-monitor under the supervision of their employer. The employer should provide employees with masks and gloves. The employer should ensure employees social distance when feasible and, the employer should clean and disinfect all areas such as offices, bathrooms, common areas and shared electronic equipment routinely.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Description of complaint: EE states that he currently works out of a Lucky's supermarket for InstaCart in an area roughly 90sqft dedicated to InstaCart operations. Customers are using the area like a lottery scratch off area and not maintaining physical distance from InstaCart employees. 4-5 customers are using the area to wait in line for the lottery machine also not physical distancing from InstaCart employees. Customers are entering InstaCarts area, EE states that there are no barriers between employees and Customers. Customers in Lucky's are not wearing facial masks properly near the InstaCart employees. 1. The employer did not ensure visual cues such as signs and floor markings are placed to indicate where employees and others should be located or their direction and path of travel they need to take. Ref T8 CCR 3205(c)(6). 2. The employer did not ensure that effective barriers where installed to reduce the risk of transmission between patrons and employees. Ref T8 CCR 3205(c)(8)(A). 3. The employer did not implement policies and procedures to protect employees from the hazards of COVID-19 when patrons visit the establishment without facial coverings. Ref T8 CCR 3205(c)(7)(F).
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: description of complaint: ee states that he currently works out of a lucky's supermarket for instacart in an area roughly 90sqft dedicated to instacart operations. customers are using the area like a lottery scratch off area and not maintaining physical distance from instacart employees. 4-5 customers are using the area to wait in line for the lottery machine also not physical distancing from instacart employees. customers are entering instacarts area, ee states that there are no barriers between employees and customers. customers in lucky's are not wearing facial masks properly near the instacart employees. 1. the employer did not ensure visual cues such as signs and floor markings are placed to indicate where employees and others should be located or their direction and path of travel they need to take. ref t8 ccr 3205(c)(6). 2. the employer did not ensure that effective barriers where installed to reduce the risk of transmission between patrons and employees. ref t8 ccr 3205(c)(8)(a). 3. the employer did not implement policies and procedures to protect employees from the hazards of covid-19 when patrons visit the establishment without facial coverings. ref t8 ccr 3205(c)(7)(f).

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The employer has not taken the appropriate steps to protect employees from SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19 including but not limited to having employees wear facemasks and be able to social distance. OSHA Response: The OSHA inspection did not result in a citation issuance for this complaint item. The employer had face covering policies, engaged in employee training, performed both screening for COVID and contact tracing when appropriate. However due to some inconsistencies in enforcing the company face covering policy; OSHA has issued a hazard alert letter related to this issue. A copy of the hazard alert letter has been enclosed. No citation issued.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Employees are exposed to chemical hazards, in that the employer does not provide adequate personal protective equipment such as chemical splash goggles and aprons for employees who open and process recovered mail from the all-purpose containers (APCs) in the mail recovery center. 2. Employees are exposed to chemical hazards, in that the employer does not provide adequate safety training for employees who open and process recovered mail which contains unknown solid and liquid substances including parcels which show evidence of leaking contents. 3. Employees are exposed to health hazards associated with the SARS-CoV-2 virus, in that the employer is not effectively implementing Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines including, but not limited to, contact tracing and workplace sanitation where an employee tested positive for COVID-19 and continued to work for 11 days before being quarantined. (Advisement Letter Sent)

Hazard.Desc.Loc: COVID-19: The employees work within inches of other employees. The employer has not established social distancing. Employees wear only cloth masks. The employees are not provided the proper masks. Some employees wear masks over their mouth but not their nose. The only sanitizing station is right by the time clock. They are not sanitizing as much as they are supposed to be. Entire Building: They do not have any airflow for dust, wood particles or fibrous materials in the air. They spray chemicals; brake cleaner, rubbing alcohol, mineral metal cleaner. They spray paint inside the building. They cut metal inside the building. There is no ventilation except that they open the doors. Employees are expected to breath and work in this all day. Employees are not provided the proper PPE, not provided N95 masks. Employees experience health effects. Cargo Trailer Line - Roofing Department: There is no safety on the roof line scaffolds for the RVS. There are no safety bars installed. Employees work on double-tall scaffolds 25-feet to 30-feet up. The catwalks are not attached or latched to anything and have fallen next to employees. They do not provide enough time for employees to get work done safely and want work done quickly with no regard for safety.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. N95 fit testing denied. N95 fit testing denied for approximately 120 employees including Villa employees & contract employees through YONA Healthcare Services (housekeeping & laundry contract services) and Energize Rehab (Physical therapy, occupational therapy & speech therapy contract services) 2. Failure to notify: Three employees have been identified as COVID positive & staff were not notified. On Aug 1, 2020 a Business office employee received a positive COVID test. Staff was not notified as required (within 12 hours) as no notifications were provided on the orders of Regional Director Of Operations & Executive Vice President. On Sept 8, 2020 two additional employees received positive COVID results. This was the administrator & director of nursing. No notifications were made to staff or residents/guardians after these additional two diagnosis.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. This complaint is regarding the handling of COVID-19. It is believed that the restaurant is at risk of an outbreak. There have already been 5 servers and one manager who have gotten COVID. As an example, the roommate of one of the servers that had tested positive came into work claiming they were in the ¿clear.¿ However, this person was observed during the mandatory screening to have a temperature of 100.2° and they were still allowed into the building. Another example is a server that came into eat with her friends who the next day received results that their test was positive for COVID. This person was not wearing a mask when she greeted many of the servers, including a manager (who wasn't wearing a mask as well). 2. Multiple employees have tested positive for COVID and the restaurant has failed to do a deep clean. 3. At first the employer wasn't informing employees that anyone was exposed, and now they are saying that the tests are false positives. Those employees who were potentially exposed are urged to come to work due to a chance of "false positives".

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer is not complying with the Governor¿s COVID-19 mandate in regard to social distancing between employees. Employees are required to share trailers and buggies and do not maintain social distancing. Additionally, the employer does not provide adequate room to social distance during meal breaks. 2. The employer is not complying with the Governor¿s COVID-19 mandate in regard to employees wearing face coverings. The employer has implemented a face cover policy but does not enforce use. 3. The employer does not clean or sanitize break/rest areas and tables. 4. Employees are continuing working while displaying symptoms of COVID-19. Employees are not calling off sick until the day of their test. 5. The site tractor pulled trailers are job made and unstable. Previously, a wheel had fallen from the trailer setup, injuring employees. The employer repaired the trailer on site with substandard hardware. 6. The tractor and trailer tires and hitch are damaged and unsafe for use. 7. One of the tractors does not have a safety brake, and the employer is using a board of wood to chock the tire. 8. The employer does not provide hand wash stations on site. Hazard Location: Throughout the listed site. 12/16/2020 JB

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The employer is not following the guidelines set forth in Executive Orders 20-74 and 20-81, COVID-19 Preparedness Plan requirements for Minnesota business entities, specifically: 1. The employer is not ensuring physical distancing of at least six feet or providing protective barriers between employees and between employees and customers while performing job duties. 2. The employer is not requiring employees or team members to wear face coverings while in the establishment. 3. The employer has not trained employees on the COVID-19 Preparedness Plan for the establishment.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The employer did not maintain an effective injury and illness prevention program in that the employer did not ensure that COVID-19 precautions per the state executive and local public health department orders are being followed at the workplace in the following instances: 1. The employer did not ensure to exclude COVID-19 cases from the work place until the return to work criteria subsection (c)(11) has been met. Ref T8 CCR 3205(c)(10)(A). 2. The employer did not give notice to employees on their exposure to a COVID-19 positive case. Ref T8 CCR 3205(c)(3)(B)3. 3. The employer did not ensure employees are wearing facial coverings properly. Ref T8 CCR 3205(c)(7)(A). 4. The employer did not implement an effective screening procedure to screen employees for COVID-19 symptoms. Ref T8 CCR 3205(c)(2)(B). 5. The employer did not Identifying and regularly cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces and objects. Ref T8 CCR 3205(c)(8)(C). 6. The employer did not ensure that the restrooms were maintained in a sanitary condition. Ref T8 CCR 3366(b).
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: the employer did not maintain an effective injury and illness prevention program in that the employer did not ensure that covid-19 precautions per the state executive and local public health department orders are being followed at the workplace in the following instances: 1. the employer did not ensure to exclude covid-19 cases from the work place until the return to work criteria subsection (c)(11) has been met. ref t8 ccr 3205(c)(10)(a). 2. the employer did not give notice to employees on their exposure to a covid-19 positive case. ref t8 ccr 3205(c)(3)(b)3. 3. the employer did not ensure employees are wearing facial coverings properly. ref t8 ccr 3205(c)(7)(a). 4. the employer did not implement an effective screening procedure to screen employees for covid-19 symptoms. ref t8 ccr 3205(c)(2)(b). 5. the employer did not identifying and regularly cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces and objects. ref t8 ccr 3205(c)(8)(c). 6. the employer did not ensure that the restrooms were maintained in a sanitary condition. ref t8 ccr 3366(b).

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer is failing to ensure all employees are wearing face masks when required by orders from CDPH. Instructors are not wearing masks and have passed COVID-19 to patrons since the new year. T8 CCR 3205(c)(6)(B) 2. The employer is failing to ensure that all persons in the facility are following local health orders of Alameda County by wearing face masks indoors. Employees and patrons are not wearing masks. Fitness centers are not private locations and, therefore, are subject to the local health order. T8 CCR 3205(c)(2)(F) 3. The employer is failing, within one business day, to notify any person who might have been exposed to a COVID-19 case in the workplace. Instructors are testing positive and not telling patrons of the COVID-19 case. The employer is able to track who has been in the facility. This has been occurring during the last two weeks. T8 CCR 3205(c)(3)(B)(3) 4. The employer is not correcting COVID-19 hazards in a timely manner. The employer is allowing instructors, employees, and/or patrons to not wear masks. In doing so, they are allowing positive COVID-19 cases to have transmission within the worksite. The employer does not notify patrons when an employee is positive and allows employees to continue to work, not excluding them from the worksite. T8 CCR 3205(c)(4) 5. The employer is not excluding employees and/or patrons from the work place when there is a COVID-19 case. Instructors not wearing masks are testing positive and other employees and/or patrons are not being excluded from the workplace. This has been occurring over the last few weeks. T8 CCR 3205(c)(9)

Hazard.Desc.Loc: On or about March 22nd the employer asked emergency room nurses to remove NIOSH approved N95 respirators. The N95 respirators had been donated directly to the nurses for their protection in lieu of wearing simple surgical masks (which provide less respiratory protection). The employer asked the staff to turn over a list of the employee wearing N95 respirators in the emergency department. The next day (3/23/20) the employer implemented a new policy restricting the ability of nurses to utilize personal or donated PPE even if it met CDC standards or provided greater protection to nurses than the PPE that the employer is able or willing to provide.
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: on or about march 22nd the employer asked emergency room nurses to remove niosh approved n95 respirators. the n95 respirators had been donated directly to the nurses for their protection in lieu of wearing simple surgical masks (which provide less respiratory protection). the employer asked the staff to turn over a list of the employee wearing n95 respirators in the emergency department. the next day (3/23/20) the employer implemented a new policy restricting the ability of nurses to utilize personal or donated ppe even if it met cdc standards or provided greater protection to nurses than the ppe that the employer is able or willing to provide.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Nursing staff works 12 hour shifts. Nurse patient ratio on the cardiac care unit is suppose to be 1/4. But it's almost always 1/6. And many times CNAs are 1/12 patients. Overworked nursing staff under stressful conditions many times leads to miscommunication, mistakes and hazards. Which not only puts the staff in danger but the patients as well. It is this way on multiple units. Staff rarely get a lunch and even less time get any breaks. They usually grab bites of something between caring for patients. Nurses very Rarely leave the floor for a 30 minute lunch cause if we do we have to leave another nurse caring not only for their 4 to 6 patients they have to care for our 4 to 6 patients as well. That is too much for one nurse to do even if it is only for 30 minutes. This may not sound like a lot of patients for one nurse but these are critically ill patients.There are days the employee may only get to pee once or twice a day cause its so busy and doesn't have time. Other nurses tell the employee the same. This leads to us getting UTIs and sometimes even kidney infections. 2. Chairs in Alcoves have been complained about multiple times by staff because they are so slippery and have led to multiple staff slips and falls. These chairs are placed at each patient alcove and they are barstool type chairs with wheels that sit up high and when staff tries to climb up on the chairs they slide out from under us causing us to hit the floor or walls. When employee complained to their manager about it they were told, we should feel lucky we were even given chairs. If employee felt the chairs were dangerous they should not sit in them. According to my step count everyday, employee may walk anywhere from 6 to 11 miles per day at work. Employee needs to be able to sit down at least during their charting. In fear of losing our chairs employee doesn't complain anymore. 3. When the hospital transfers you out of your unit to work another unit that is short staffed they give you no training on this other unit first. Employee works the cardiac care unit. Employee has been trained on their unit. Last week August 25th, the employee was sent to work the COVID unit on 4th floor. Employee received no training prior to working this unit. And they do this to all nurses and CNAs. None of us get trained on units they pull us to that are short staffed. 4. Our units have limited N95 masks in a electronic supply box called the Omnicell. To get these out we have to go in and sign them out individually per person. Per the Cardiac care unit manager, staff are not allowed to sign these out unless we have a patient positive for COVID on our unit. But the hospital does not test every patient for COVID prior to coming to our unit. So we are taking care of patients for days. And find out days in that they have COVID and staff have not been allowed proper PPE to Care for Covid patients. For example we took care of a patient in room 331 for several days. Patient came in with a heart condition as well as respiratory issues. The patient was not tested for COVID when they came in through the ER. Patient should have been tested for COVID before they ever left the ER to come upstairs to our unit. So multiple nurses and aides took care of this patient for days and were not allowed to have the proper PPE. 5. We many times have patients who may be mentally unstable with confusion and are considered fall risks. These patients will get out of bed although they are asked to call for staff to help. We have alarms to tell us when they get up but many times by the time staff gets in there it's too late. Patient has already fallen. With these confused patients that are non compliant we are suppose to have sitters to come sit with them. But being so under staffed we many times can't get a sitter. So in turn this causes our staff to constantly have to run in patients rooms to try to prevent falls. Many times this may be 1 staff m

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Employees are exposed to hazards related to demolition and construction activities as these employees are not provided any personal protective equipment (PPE) by the employer. Employees are not afforded PPE for potential overhead hazards and dust inhalation hazards, or for hazards created by activities such as cutting or hammering that could result in eye or hand injury.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Guidance: Requiring Facilities to Prioritize Surgeries and Procedures and Provide Safe Environment during COVID-19 Peacetime. These guidelines are not being followed in the specific areas: 1. Screening and Testing - The employer is not following the guideline for treat all patients as being positive for COVID-19 since they since they have not implemented protocols for patient testing. From the guidelines for testing - If the facility does not implement a protocol for patient testing, the facility must consider all patients potentially COVID-19 positive and take appropriate precautions. Facilities should consider the availability, accuracy and current evidence regarding tests when developing their testing protocols. 2. The proper PPE is not being provided including N-95 Respirator mask while patients are having elective surgeries. The employee was told the employer was using crisis standard of care which is not allowed under the guidelines. From the guidelines for PPE - Facilities must ensure adequate PPE supply that accounts for a potential surge of COVID-19, including sufficient number of days' supply on hand and an open commercial supply chain that is adequate to maintain PPE supply without reliance on public PPE reserves for non-COVID-19 procedures that are offered as a result of this guidance and Executive Order 20-51. The facility's supply should be sufficient to care for all patients without resorting to crisis standards of care.
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: guidance: requiring facilities to prioritize surgeries and procedures and provide safe environment during covid-19 peacetime. these guidelines are not being followed in the specific areas: 1. screening and testing - the employer is not following the guideline for treat all patients as being positive for covid-19 since they since they have not implemented protocols for patient testing. from the guidelines for testing - if the facility does not implement a protocol for patient testing, the facility must consider all patients potentially covid-19 positive and take appropriate precautions. facilities should consider the availability, accuracy and current evidence regarding tests when developing their testing protocols. 2. the proper ppe is not being provided including n-95 respirator mask while patients are having elective surgeries. the employee was told the employer was using crisis standard of care which is not allowed under the guidelines. from the guidelines for ppe - facilities must ensure adequate ppe supply that accounts for a potential surge of covid-19, including sufficient number of days' supply on hand and an open commercial supply chain that is adequate to maintain ppe supply without reliance on public ppe reserves for non-covid-19 procedures that are offered as a result of this guidance and executive order 20-51. the facility's supply should be sufficient to care for all patients without resorting to crisis standards of care.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. An employee tested positive for Covid-19 on November 8, 2020. Employee notified management that same day that he tested positive. The owner or any other members of management have yet to give a formal verification of the positive test to the entire staff. It is unclear if everyone employed currently knows that they could have possibly been exposed to the virus. This includes office staff, Sales reps, delivery drivers, and shop workers. 2. Sales Reps were only instructed to not report to the office on the morning of November 9th, but instead to go straight onto the road. 3. There were no mandates implemented for sales entering other businesses being that they could have been exposed and infected and are in turn possibly putting these businesses at risk of spreading the virus. 4. No mandates for PPE were made either. 5. The desk and work space of the infected employee has not been cleaned. There are 4 employees that are currently working in the same vicinity of this workspace and they are not being mandated to wear proper PPE. 6. There is no preparedness plan at this time.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer encourages employees to not wear masks inside and have meetings in tight conference room settings, while not social distancing. 2. The employer has no requirements for customers coming into the office. Just last week, 8 persons were in the front office at the same; the employer instructed for them all to come in after they were initially directed by employees to wait outside. 3. One employee had to conduct 2 oral swab drug screens at the same time in different rooms. The employer requires the intern to do all of the oral swabs in the establishment's one conference; meaning the intern has to collect saliva from complete strangers. 4. The employer has been actively observed shaking customer's hands and having conference meetings in the conference room with no mask on. Furthermore, the employer has informed customers that they don't have to wear masks either. The employer then expects that employees to Clorox wipe after the room is used. 5. The employer has never taken employee temperatures nor have employees been required to complete daily health screening questionnaires. The employer has never recorded anything for the office.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: - An employee reached out to HR to ask them about getting a covid test because they had not been feeling well. The employee was informed that the company was no longer paying employees to quarantine so they could take a 14-day personal leave with no pay. This is why the company masks that it is a risk anyone is taking who is going to work. The employer also said that if an employee was unable to attend work that they would be pointed. - It is mandatory that everyone pass the temp check before entering the building. After failing multiple times an employee asked a nearby employee to get a supervisor because they told employees if they still enter the building after failing the test it could lead to termination. - A manager came to the monitor where an employee failed at least 6 more times. The manager then got a different thermometer that is on the loading docs for the trucks and told the employee that their fever was low grade and asked them if they could still stay because they would be leaving their team ?anging, if left. The manager also informed the employee if they could not stay they would have to take a point. So in other words go to work or you're fired. The manager then unplugged the monitor and had the employee go to work as if nothing ever happened.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: On 12-31-2021 New Year Eve the front line staff were exposed to large numbers of unmasked customers during a very busy New Year Eve night. The casino allowed customers in the concert halls without marks and after three shows they all came out to the deli without masks and were yelling at us when we asked them to please put their mask back on. The security staff and supervisors just stood there without helping us. Now many of us are sick with covid-19 even with our shots. I have asked the supervisor that was helping us at the deli to please do something, but she just stood there watching. We were overwhelmed with the long line of out of control customers. We worked without proper break time and were forced to deal with angry unmasked customers all night which have caused myself and many of the staff to be sick. In addition, a few of us got food poisoning when we ate at the employee kitchen. The lead night cook at the Deli and the women supervisors have their hair loose in the food preparation areas. That night we had several complains of hair in customers food. They still refused to make any adjustments. If I say anything to the cook or supervisors they get upset.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: T8CCR 3203(a)- Employees are not social distancing in the break room and have pushed tables close together. Employees are required to wear a pin that states, "Please Social Distance." The pins are shared amongst employees and at the end of each shift the pins get turned in and employees from the next shift put the pins on. The pins are not sanitized before/after each use and there has not been a training on sanitizing them or making it a requirement to do so. Employees wear masks but often times do not cover their noses and nose covering is not being enforced. The customers that enter the store are not being counted to facilitate social distancing and the register areas are no longer being consistently sanitized.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 5th floor administrative areas including room # 515, Specialty Services : 1. Four employees work in a small space that is poorly ventilated. The work involves close interaction between these employees and other employees who come and go from this space through out the day. The four employees are not required to wear masks while in this space, and there are no barriers between them. While their work stations are 6 feet apart their work often brings them with in 6 feet of each other. 2. When one of the workers tested COVID 19 positive this week there was no notification of, and no attempt at a COVID 19 exposure assessment of the other workers. 3. The work area where the COVID 19 positive employee worked was not cleaned and sanitized after the worker was removed.

Complaint item #2: Patients are not placed in negative pressure rooms with respect to covid-19 patients. Complaint item #3: Nurses told they can not wear their own personal CDC recommended NIOSH respirators with organic vapor P100 filters. Complaint item #4: COVID-19 persons under investigation are being transported from ER without staff wearing N95 masks. Complaint item #5: Hospital has run out of certain sizes of N95 masks, and refuses to let employees use own. Complaint item #6: Nurses are given only one surgical mask and are expected to re-use it over and over until soiled. Complaint item #7: PPE gowns are permeable and porous and do not offer protection from body fluids.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The location was not following any of the necessary precautions in regards to CoViD-19. Store capacity was not being controlled in any way, so customers continued to fill the store. The location only had 3-4 registers open, and there were approximately 50-60 people crowded in a line to those registers, with no social distancing of 6 feet, nor anyone controlling that customers remained with their masks on in case of the inability to social distance. Lastly, upon arriving at the register, an employee (possibly a shift manager) brings a customer next to another customer despite there being various (at least 4) other registers forcing the two customers, one with an infant in a stroller, to be directly next to each other. When customer #1 requests that the cashier please move the new customer to a register where they can maintain social distance, the cashier says she cannot, gives no explanation, and continues on. This location is entirely disregarding the health and safety of the consumer and therefore the community.

Employees do not wear masks in the workplace, which does not adhere to CDC guidance. 3. Adequate sanitization of the employees work area and within a 6 foot perimeter of the employees normal work area did not occur when the positive case was identified. This may expose employees to COVID-19 while in the workplace. 4. CDC guidance regarding social distancing of 6 feet or more is not maintained within the workplace. Meetings are held where employees are within 1 foot of one another. Employees regularly sit within 2 feet of one another when in their normal work positions.

Develop an Infectious Disease Preparedness and Response Plan; d. Prepare to Implement Basic Infection Prevention Measures; e. Develop Policies and Procedures for Prompt Identification and Isolation of Sick People, if Appropriate; f. Develop, Implement, and Communicate about Workplace Flexibilities and Protection; g. Implement Workplace Controls, Engineering Controls, and Administrative Controls; h. Implement Safe Work Practices; i. Hazard.Desc.Loc: COVID-19 safety guidelines are almost completely ignored. Safety posters are present, but ignored. Management doesn't require employees or customers to wear masks or practice social distancing. Employees are not allowed to enforce mask rules with customers. Employees are told that they must work nearly every day even if sick and possibly contagious. On at least two occasions, doctor's notes have been ignored by management, and employees were forced to come in to work & ignore doctor's orders. Items in the warehouse and on delivery trucks are stacked far too tall with no restraints creating a serious falling object hazard, and employees are instructed to simply pull down walls of high, heavy furniture in the interest of saving time. Fire exits in the warehouse are usually blocked by heavy merchandise. Employees operate a dangerous garbage compactor without any training or safety guidelines. Employees are not provided fully stocked first aid kits, proper PPE, or disinfectants.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1) Staff screening temperature is being done by staff without masks on. 2) The staff conducting the screening are not asking about symptoms or checking for the checkmark for 7 weeks now. 3) The employer is refusing to allow any off site work for many departments including completing paperwork. Location: suite G12, ART department. 4) The employer is refusing to allow "pods" in specific departments to reduce staff members which exceeds the allowable number of persons in a space at one time on a daily basis. Location: ART department. 5) The employer does not supply hand sanitizer to the departments, staff, clients, or at entrances for employees. 6) The employer does not inform staff of the clients they will be in contact with (in person) when they are Covid-positive or having symptoms. Location: ART department. 7) At the main entrance, the employer does not read signage to those who cannot read or provide translating for those who do not speak or read English. 8) The employer is allowing visitors into the building who are not necessary support people or guardians without clinical reasoning. 9) The employer does not have an on-site cleaning crew. 10) There is no cleaning of touch points during the day, bathrooms, areas of use, waiting rooms, or have staff available after 12pm to call when needed. This is more so on the ground level where all clients are seen in person during full business hours. 11) The employer does not supply office space allowing for 6 feet of distance when meeting with clients, will not supply plexiglass barriers, wipes for pens or clipboards, or related. Larger areas are available but are not allowed by management. Location: ART department. 12) The employer does not supply offices to meet with clients that meet basic safety and security needs. Location: suites G11 - G12. 13) Sessions are being held outdoors and it¿s 37 degrees.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1) The employer failed to maintain cleanable solid partitions that effectively reduce aerosol transmission between employees and other persons at fixed work locations, where it is not possible to maintain the physical distancing requirement at all times. The employer installed cleanable solid partitions made of plexiglass, but customers are leaning on them and they are now broken and ineffective. T8 CCR 3205(c)(8)(A) 2) The employer failed to ensure that employees and other persons maintain six feet of distance and wear face coverings over the nose and mouth when outdoors. T8 CCR 3205(c)(6)(A) & (c)(7)(A) 3) The employer failed to reduce capacity to ensure that employees and other persons maintain six feet of distance. T8 CCR 3205(c)(6)(A) 4) The employer failed to evaluate the need for personal protective equipment to prevent exposure to COVID-19 hazards , such as gloves, goggles, and face shields, and provide such personal protective equipment as needed. Supervisors and employees are required to handle casino chips that players frequently handle. Players are not consistently washing or sanitizing their hands, creating a hazard to employees who are picking up the casino chips. T8 CCR 3205(c)(8)(E)1. 5) The employer failed to ensure that temporary wiring is supported in place at intervals to ensure that they will be protected from physical damage. Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1) The employer has not developed an implemented a COVID-19 prevention plan that includes, but is not limited to: a) wearing face coverings b)maintaining a social distance of six feet. c) employee health screening d) sanitation of surfaces e) providing hand sanitizers. 2) Main and second building - About 3 months ago a material pallet fell off a rack onto the top of a powered industrial truck. These pallets can weigh 5000 each. Storage racks are not secured to surfaces and are overloaded with material pallets. 3) Second building - The water jet cutter pump overflows water onto the floor. The water is a slipping hazard. 4) Second building - The Herco 95S press brake has an unguarded foot bar. 5) The employer has not developed and implemented lockout/tagout procedures. 6) Second building - Stock, dies, and wood block employee access to the backs of the Herco 95S press brake and the metal shear. 7) Second building - Employees conduct MIG/TIG welding on stainless steel, aluminum, and carbon steel. Employees are exposed to welding fumes. Local exhaust ventilation has not been provided in the welding areas. 8) The employer has not developed and implemented a written hazard communication program. 9) Safety data sheets are not available for employee use. 10) Employees have not received hazard communication training.
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: 1) the employer has not developed an implemented a covid-19 prevention plan that includes, but is not limited to: a) wearing face coverings b)maintaining a social distance of six feet. c) employee health screening d) sanitation of surfaces e) providing hand sanitizers. 2) main and second building - about 3 months ago a material pallet fell off a rack onto the top of a powered industrial truck. these pallets can weigh 5000 each. storage racks are not secured to surfaces and are overloaded with material pallets. 3) second building - the water jet cutter pump overflows water onto the floor. the water is a slipping hazard. 4) second building - the herco 95s press brake has an unguarded foot bar. 5) the employer has not developed and implemented lockout/tagout procedures. 6) second building - stock, dies, and wood block employee access to the backs of the herco 95s press brake and the metal shear. 7) second building - employees conduct mig/tig welding on stainless steel, aluminum, and carbon steel. employees are exposed to welding fumes. local exhaust ventilation has not been provided in the welding areas. 8) the employer has not developed and implemented a written hazard communication program. 9) safety data sheets are not available for employee use. 10) employees have not received hazard communication training.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: T8 CCR 3203(a)(4)&(6) Employees are not encouraged to wear face coverings. T8 CCR 3203(a)(4)&(6) Employees are not encouraged to maintain physical distancing at work. Employees gather in close physical proximity during the group meetings at the beginning of each shift. Employees do not maintain physical distancing during lunch breaks. T8 CCR 3273(a) The employer has not ensured that the work floor is free from oil. Powered industrial trucks routinely leak oil on the work floor and these pools are not cleaned. T8 CCR 3338(a) & 3339(a) Pallets are not stored in a safe manner. Pallets are stacked above the approved maximum height. Pallets that are required to be wrapped are not being wrapped before being stored. Pallets on the bottom of a stack have been crushed to the point where the stack becomes unstable. T8 CCR 5185(d) Powered industrial truck batteries have acid buildup on the exterior of the battery. There acid spills are not neutralized and cleaned. T8 CCR 6151(c)(1) Portable fire extinguishers are left on the ground and are not properly mounted. T8 CCR 3203(a)(7) New employees are not provided effective training. Employees are stacking pallets above the approved height, not wrapping pallets, don't use appropriate personal protective equipment near the powered industrial truck battery charging stations, and have attempted to charge batteries with incompatible chargers.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Personal protective equipment is not provided to employees exposed to hazards in the machine shop. 2. Machine guarding is not provided to protect the operators of grinding equipment and boring mills in the machine shop. 3. Maintenance shop employees are exposed to a fine mist produced when a mixture of coolant and grinder shavings is sprayed against the wall. 5. There is no emergency eye wash station in the machine shop. 6. Employees are exposed to airborne dust from grinding operations in the maintenance shop. 7. The practice of social distancing and use of face coverings are not implemented at the facility to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in accordance with CDC and OSHA guidelines.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: A manager recently came into to the workforce when he/she knew they were very sick, to the point he/she was just laying in her office with their head down. They had a mask on that Saturday, August 28/2021. A few days later the following week, about Monday or Tuesday, they seemed to have felt a tiny bit better but they did not have on a mask and was around all of the employees and customers in close direct contact. About Friday night, he/she informs a manager that they took a COVID-19 test sometime after Saturday, but before Friday to my knowledge and it came back positive. Now with this information it would be logical to at least have the exposed employees be sent home or even tested but it was failed to do so and they claimed that everyone there will be fine and that he/she the only one that is sick. Now, being up there I noticed that several employees were throwing up that Sunday night and were strongly encouraged to stay working even though everyone was getting sick. Several people called out of work because they could not bring themselves to come in due to their condition. Multiple people, have tried to explain that someone needs to shut the restaurant down before they have no employees to work because they are all getting sick. The person was really sick still working until 2am. They have failed to take any responsibility in the fact that he/she won't do what is best for her employees, customers, and the Denny's franchise. He/she has exchanged some hurtful words towards a manager telling them that they need to stay open and keep calling different employees to come in.

Employees were provided inadequate respiratory protection such as but not limited to cloth facial coverings and KN95 masks to be worn while providing direct care to COVID-19 presumed or positive patients. 6. Employees were not offered fit test for respiratory usage. 7. Employees are not provided training on respiratory protection appropriate to be worn during COVID-19 treatments. 8. The employer provided non- safety (no engineered sharp cover) needle devices for use during injections. The employer has implied safety needles were too expensive.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Employees are experiencing symptoms of illness due to unknown chemicals from containers being unlabeled (spray bottles) of chemical(s) for cleaning of wheel chair seats and pads. 2. Employees are exposed to health hazards from overwhelming odors of aerosol glue at the foaming workstation due to a lack of adequate ventilation. 3. The employer is not providing adequate ventilation when requiring employees to use paint thinners, cleaning chemical(s) and to control fabric fibers generated at the CNC autometrix fabric cutter. 4. Employer has not conducted hazard communication training for employees using cleaning chemical(s). 5. Employer does not provide adequate personal protective equipment (gloves and respiratory protection, available for employees using cleaning chemical(s), aprons. 6. Employer does not provide employees with masks or aprons when requiring employees to cut a variety of fabrics. 7. Employees are exposed to respiratory health hazards due to excessive dust generated from foam cut by multiple bandsaws. (The violations exist in the sewing department at the pad printing station, the individual sewing stations, the M8 CNC fabric cutting station, and the foaming station located next to the sewing department) Applicable OSHA Standards: 29 CFR 1910.133, 1910.132, 1910.134, 1910.1200

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Employer failed to notify staff of direct exposure to COVID-19. Behavioral medicine staff are not being notified directly every time there is a COVID exposure. 2. Employer not providing testing to behavioral health employees despite being continuously exposed and requiring mandatory regular testing for other units in the facility. 3. Employer not providing staff with appropriate PPE (no medical grade N-95 masks). 4. Employees are being exposed to COVID-19 and not being notified by employee health/administration. This occurred on the adolescent unit on November 10, 2020. A patient tested positive, the entire staff was exposed, and no phone calls have been made as of November 12, 2020. 5. Patients are not in negative pressure rooms. 6. Administration refuses to require a negative COVID test before admission. 7. The employee health/infection control position is currently vacant. 8. Mitigation strategy is non-sensical and does not follow best practices. 9. Administration has continually refused to offer mass testing to behavioral medicine staff. 10. Employer is not properly quarantining patients that have been exposed. 11. A patient tested positive on the adolescent unit recently and there was no plan on how to proceed once the results came back. Also, management has not tested all the patients that were exposed. Management is downplaying the situation and has not contacted everyone that was in contact with the patient. 12. Everyday employees get e-mails stating that someone (patient or employee) has tested positive and to not worry even though this is a serious issue. 13. The behavioral medicine units are not equipped to handle a COVID-19 patient. 14. Employees do not have the proper PPE to wear while at work.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1) Employees are allegedly not wearing masks while working. An employee was allegedly ill at the workplace in the evening with active vomiting and being tired. Employees were exposed to the employee with management knowledge who did not allow the employee to leave the work area. Multiple employees were exposed to the ill employee. NO CITATION recommended. The employer requires employees to use wall-mounted thermometers to check their temperatures upon entry to the building. Hand sanitizer, disposable masks and cleaning supplies available to employees. The time clock system employees clock in at prompts them to answer questions about potential symptoms. If an employee has COVID-19 symptoms (i.e., fever, chills, cough, shortness of breath, fatigue, muscle or body aches, headache, loss of taste or smell, sore throat, congestion or runny nose, nausea or vomiting, diarrhea), they are to report it to their manager. A note in the SOP provided by the company stated the following: ¿The teammate can work if they are experiencing milder symptoms that can be attributed to another medical condition.¿ A presentation titled ¿Welcome Back Meeting¿ dated March 8, 2021 listed the following as ¿precautions¿ being implemented: ¿ If you have COVID symptoms, report to supervisor and stay home ¿ Private Offices commercially cleaned 5 days per week ¿ Common areas and call center commercially cleaned 7 days week ¿ Environmental/viral fogging 7 days per week The same presentation given to employees listed the following ¿protocols¿: ¿ Staff capacity at 50% max and in office 2 days per week ¿ Take Temperature using wall thermometer upon entry, if 100.4+ system will alarm, return home and contact supervisor ¿ Wear a mask when away from workstation and in common areas ¿ Refrain from congregating in breakroom and social distance at 6 feet ¿ Wear masks in meetings and group settings ¿ Wash/sanitize hands regularly ¿ Supervisors report positive COVID cases to Risk Mgmt who will direct on quarantine protocols The employers quarantine guidelines were detailed in a document titled ¿City Barbeque COVID FAQ (02.01.21)¿. 2) Employees are not able to social distance in office space where they are required to work where they are potentially being exposed to SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19 . NO CITATION recommended. In the Call Center, employees are positioned at every other workstation to maintain 6 ft separation as well as utilizing tall cubicle-type partitions. Employees were not seated directly across from each other, but rather seated in the workstation diagonally across. In the rest of the building, employees either work in single offices or are at workstations that are positioned in a manor to maintain a 6 ft separation.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Salon has had multiple instances of employees contracting COVID-19 and other employees feel unsafe with the way the salon is handling the issue. Several times in late spring/early summer, the salon simply told the positive employees not to come back to work without telling their other staff that they came into contact with a positive case. Most recently, the salon issued an internal statement that one staff member had tested positive for COVID, but that no other employees needed to quarantine because all interactions this staff member had with other staff was under 15 minutes, masked, and 6 feet apart. However, this is not true. All the clients this staff member cut hair for would have been in close contact for at least 30 minutes. In the break room, this staff would have had close contact with other staff because the break room is too small to maintain 6 feet distance between 3 or more people. And there were definitely 2 other people with this staff member in the break room together. Washing dishes, mixing hair color and more are all activities that are done with less than 6 feet distance. This staff was also seen by other staff with their mask off more than once throughout the day. The salon is telling people who came into contact with the positive individual that they don't need to quarantine. This is simply false and risks the health of their employees and customers.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: There have been 6 resident and 3 staff positive cases of COVID-19 since July 31. One resident has died, another is still in the hospital. The two most recent were on Saturday August 14th. The employer does not always provide proper personal protective equipment (PPE); PPE was unavailable from the 7th through the 9th. Staff had to go into positive COVID rooms wearing trash bags and some wore nothing but a surgical mask. The establishment had been opened for in-person visits for residents on the 5th of August; 5 days after an active COVID case. Employees are supposed to do daily rapid testing before their shift, but it is often impossible because proper materials are not available.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: It is alleged that: Five employees have tested positive for the Coronavirus in recent weeks. The employer is not following the recommendations (as noted in paragraph two) put in place by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) to help prevent and slow the spread of COVID-19 in the workplace. Safety practices for workers who may have had exposure to a person with suspected or confirmed COVID-10 are recommended as follows: Employees who have been exposed (the time the employee had symptoms and 2 days prior to symptoms) should self-monitor under the supervision of their employer. The employer should provide employees with masks and gloves. The employer should ensure employees social distance when feasible and, the employer should conduct enhanced cleaning and disinfect all areas such as offices, bathrooms, common areas and shared electronic equipment routinely. It is alleged that some employees who worked within three (3') feet of an employee who has tested positive have not been allowed to self-quarantine and other employees have been allowed to self-quarantine.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer requires employees to handle chemical pesticides in the production area without proper PPE such as but not limited to chemical resistant gloves; exposing employees to chemical burns and other health hazards. The employer told employees to purchase their own gloves. 2. The employer requires employees to reuse contaminated N95 respirators, contaminated half-mask respirators and contaminated cartridges (white/gray) from other employees; exposing employees to chemical hazards and health hazards in the production area of the facility. 3. The employer failed to ensure employees were practicing social distancing, maintaining six (6) feet distance, between persons within the facility in accordance to CDC (Center for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines for the COVID-19 (coronavirus disease) pandemic. 4. The employer failed to inform employees of other employee(s) who are sick with COVID-19 (coronavirus disease) within the facility as in accordance to CDC (Center for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines. 5. The employer failed to ensure periodic cleaning of the facility in the production area in accordance to CDC (Center for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines for the COVID-19 (coronavirus disease) pandemic.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer has not implemented good infection control housekeeping practices of regularly cleaning and disinfecting surfaces, equipment, and other elements of the work environment when employees have tested positive for COVID-19. 2.The employer's infection control program is not adequate as they are not ensuring that employees who have been diagnosed with covid-19 are kept separate from employees that have not tested positive. Employees are required to carpool to other locations to perform inventory with employees who have tested positive for COVID-19 without social distancing and providing masks. 3. The trucks are often loaded unsafely and load stack collapses when employees unload the boxes. Employees are often hit in the head with falling boxes. 4. Employees are made to carry heavy pallets that causes splinters trying to get them through the man door because the jack doesn't fit through the door. Employees are not provided gloves for protection. 5. Fixtures are stacked unsafely and the hooks poke out and the shelves fall. 6. The warehouse has multiple trip and fall hazards.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: This employer is not following precautions to prevent the spread of covid-19. Properties have more individuals on staff than necessary, do not wear masks, and do not social distance. Employees that have tested positive for the virus have been allowed to return to work and are not being asked to stay home until they are no longer shedding the virus, putting other employees at risk. Even though an employee reported a positive test to the company they did not provide any notice to other employees who were in contact with the individual. Employees should have a right to be informed about their exposure and individuals with a positive test should be required to self quarantine and not be in the office until they are over the illness. They have more employees in the office at once than necessary and could be allowing more employees to work from home but the company instead is forcing workers to come to the office but is failing to follow any guidelines to protect them.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The employer has not taken the appropriate steps to protect employees from SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. There have been three cases at the workplace among employees that work together. Findings: The employer has appropriate policies in place for cleaning, facial coverings, and hand hygiene and encouraged maintaining a 6ft social distancing. The inspection of the worksite revealed that employees working at a cash register did not have physical barriers such as a Plexiglas shield separating them from customers. The employees were also unable to maintain a six foot separation between them when performing activities that required both employees to be present. On May 13, 2021, the Centers of Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) announced individuals who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 no longer need to wear a face mask indoors or practice social distancing, "except where required by federal, state, local, tribal, or territorial laws, rules, and regulations, including local business and workplace guidance." At the time of the inspection, face-coverings were no longer mandated to be used by the State of Ohio although the employer still required employees to wear them. HAZARD ALERT LETTER (HAL) ISSUED.
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: the employer has not taken the appropriate steps to protect employees from sars-cov-2, the virus that causes covid-19. there have been three cases at the workplace among employees that work together. findings: the employer has appropriate policies in place for cleaning, facial coverings, and hand hygiene and encouraged maintaining a 6ft social distancing. the inspection of the worksite revealed that employees working at a cash register did not have physical barriers such as a plexiglas shield separating them from customers. the employees were also unable to maintain a six foot separation between them when performing activities that required both employees to be present. on may 13, 2021, the centers of disease control and prevention (cdc) announced individuals who are fully vaccinated against covid-19 no longer need to wear a face mask indoors or practice social distancing, "except where required by federal, state, local, tribal, or territorial laws, rules, and regulations, including local business and workplace guidance." at the time of the inspection, face-coverings were no longer mandated to be used by the state of ohio although the employer still required employees to wear them. hazard alert letter (hal) issued.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The employer has failed to protect workers from Covid-19 transmission. 1. CDC and Sonoma County has recommended social distancing and face coverings to prevent the spread in all indoor public settings, but the employer has not enforced these measures. 2. Bleach solution has been provided for workers to clean equipment with, but the solution concentration is hazardous. The solution is kept on a cart outside at all times and is stored in reused spray bottles of another cleaning product. The reused bottles result in the solution being mislabeled with use instructions, active ingredient list, and warning information for the previous product and not for the bleach solution. Employees have not been trained on the use of a bleach solution nor provided with safety data sheet or protective equipment for use of bleach solution.

The employer is not complying with the Governor's COVID-19 mandate in regard to maintaining a minimum 6-feet of separation between persons/patrons in public spaces. There is no guest capacity control inside the pool area. Guests are crammed in the pool with no social distancing. 5. The employer is not complying with the Governor¿s COVID-19 mandate in regard to persons/patrons wearing face coverings while in the Employer¿s establishment. The employer does not enforce the mask mandate on guests. Guests walk the room hallways, casino floor and pool area without masks. HAZARD LOCATION: The Housekeeping Locker Room Throughout the hotel 10/26/2020 KR

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer does not offer COVID-19 testing at no cost to the employees during work hours. T8 CCR 3205(c)(3)(B)(4) 2. The employer does not identify and evaluate all interactions, areas, activities, processes, equipment and materials that could potentially expose employees to COVID-19 hazards when they do not identify and clean commonly touched surfaces and do not vacuum the workplace. 3. The employer does not provide hand sanitizer at all commonly used equipment. 4. The employer does not provide barriers where employees' cubicles place employees within six feet of each other. 5. The employer does not provide gloves for employees required to use sanitary wipes. 6. The employer does not provide a vacuum to employees required to vacuum their own work areas. 7. The employer does not provide break areas that have sufficient spaces for all employees to eat and maintain social distancing at the same time, even when breaks are staggered. T8 CCR 3205, 3203(a)(4) & (6) 8. The employer failed to eliminate the problem of pests, insects and mosquitos. T8 CCR 3362(g)

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. In the 3rd Floor Rehab Unit, employees are not provided Personal Protective Equipment (PPE). Nurses and staff were initially told they were not allowed to wear a mask unless they were currently sick or had not received the Flu vaccine. The masks were removed from the floor and moved to a central location. 2. A patient allegedly was showing all signs of being covid-19-positive, but was never tested. The CMO of the hospital reviewed the case and approved droplet isolation, but staff had already been in and out of the room and were administering therapy for several days for pneumonia. After patient was placed on droplet precautions, PPE was provided for staff. This PPE consisted of basic surgical masks that were placed in brown paper bags and taped on the door on the inside of the patient¿s room. Additionally, the floor doctors were concerned this patient may be positive for covid-19, but upper management allegedly pressured the diagnosis to be something else. Employees asked about testing criteria and PPE concerns, but were not given satisfactory answers. 3. The 3rd Floor was divided into Rehab and OOU. The doors separating the units were the only barrier present and doctors and nurses would come from the areas where covid-19 patients were staying to obtain medications or use computers. Employees are concerned that they were not protected from exposure to coronavirus. Hazard Location: Third Floor Rehab Unit 5/19/2020 HD

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The heavy machinery known as a WAV is used to pick orders from up to 20 feet from the floor. Many employees are at risk of serious injury because they are required to wear a face covering when raising and lowering the WAV. The effects of wearing a face covering, such as feeling light-headed and disoriented could cause an employee to pass out and injure an employee while operating the WAV. The team lead and supervisor are aware of the potential hazard. A request to not operate the WAV was denied by the supervisor.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The employer is not implementing precautions to protect employees from contracting and spreading the Coronavirus (COVID-19) in the workplace: a) The requirement to wear face masks/covering is not being enforced. b) The proper wearing (covering nose and mouth) of face coverings/masks by employees is not enforced. c) Common areas and frequently touched surfaces are not regularly cleaned and disinfected. d) Trucks are not regularly cleaned or disinfected in between drivers. e) Due to the number of occupants (i.e., employees, managers, sales reps, drivers, executives, contractors, etc.) that congregate in the small warehouse, social distancing is not feasible. f) After an employee tested positive, employees were not notified within 24 hours. g) The employer has failed to report COVID positive employees to the Virginia Department of Health and the Virginia Department of Labor in accordance with 16VAC25-220.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The CEO of Chicago Public Schools said the school buildings were deep cleaned over the summer and while we were out of the building in the fall. There has been no evidence of this deep cleaning at Locke school. I do not feel comfortable being in an environment that was not practicing CDC guidelines. I mentioned myu concerns in faculty meetings, and the principal did not have answers to the questions. I then wrote a letter to CPS Talent Office on October 26th with many other concerns regarding cleaning, health, and safety. On that same day, they responded by saying that if I respond to the intent to return form, they will put together a better plan of action for a safe return to school. Since then, teachers that were in the building did not see things getting better. They reported to me that things were worse. I was made aware that administrators and lunchroom staff were not wearing masks and not social distancing. Coffee cups and food wrappers were being left in teacher's classrooms. After bringing situations like this to the principal and the Talent Office, I did not see anything changing. I asked several questions in our meetings with the principal again. He did not have many answers to my questions. On January 2nd, I wrote a letter to the CEO of CPS. I understand she is busy, but I thought I would have heard from her or her office by now. On Thursday, January 7th, I was threatened to show up for work. I received another notice the next day; this time, the threat said I would not be paid. On Friday, January 8, my principal met with a parent who wants to have her child in the building for class and me. He told the parent that there had been people in the building with COVID, but they did not get COVID from being at the school. How can he be sure of this? This is very alarming because CPS is supposed to report when they have cases at the schools. They have only reported one case at Locke School at this point. According to my principal, there have been parents, teachers, and a member of! the administrative team that has been in the building with COVID. Teachers in the building were not notified. I never said I would not work. I have been showing up virtually every day. I do not think that our schools are safe. I have mentioned this to my superiors several times, and nothing has been changed. Please advise. One concern that was fixed was the preschool modules that I would have been teaching from were considered unsafe due to poor ventilation. That was a big concern for me. They moved the preschool teachers to kindergarten rooms, but now the preschool rooms will be used as a sick children's wellness room. COVID is an airborne disease. Why would you put sick children and staff in an area that is not safe due to poor ventilation? I do not think the best decisions are being made at this crucial time of COVID.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: General Sessions Court is operating at full capacity, and not following any of the safety protocols it agreed to when the Supreme Court of Tennessee said in-person court could resume. No cleaning or sanitizing of courtrooms, people on top of each other in the hallways with masks under their noses or chin-strapped or not wearing one at all, no taking of temperatures at the door, and the sheriffs office, many of them wear these face shields that only cover the bottom portion of their faces. Hazard.Desc.Loc: Concerns include but are not limited to: Meadow crest: 1. * Worksite does not have a safety committee and no records exist for the safety committee as required by WAC 296-800-13020 2.* Health and safety protocols have not been clearly communicated or provided in writing to all employees prior returning to on-site work. 3.* Documented risk assessment is not provided and is readily available for review for employees working in this building. 4.* Employer has not provided appropriate PPE or training consistent with WAC 296-842 to employees who would be tasked with monitoring students isolated due to COVID-19 symptoms 5.* Worksite training is currently limited to a pre-recorded video, completed by self with no opportunity for questions or clarification. 6.* Employer has not identified or published information on isolation of students with COVID symptoms to employees and what happens to students who have symptoms. No clear plan for how the areas that where exposure has occurred with be cleaned and sanitized. 7.* Aside from employees mandated to work in the building at this time, the district encourages other employees to work in the building at will. There is no clear screening process, and there is no plan for managing this influx of employees moving in and out of the building throughout the day. Satori School: Currently there are approximately 14 staff members in the building experiencing these health and safety issues related to COVID in the building. Concerns include but are not limited to: 1. * Worksite does not have a safety committee and no records exist for the safety committee as required by WAC 296-800-13020 2. * Health and safety protocols have not been clearly communicated or provided in writing to all employees prior returning to on-site work. 3. * Documented risk assessment is not provided and is readily available for review for employees working in this building. 4. * Employer has not provided appropriate PPE or training consistent with WAC 296-842 to employees who would be tasked with monitoring students isolated due to COVID-19 symptoms 5. * Worksite training is currently limited to a pre-recorded video, completed by self with no opportunity for questions or clarification. 6. * Employer has not identified or published information on isolation of students with COVID symptoms to employees and what happens to students who have symptoms. No clear plan for how the areas that where exposure has occurred with be cleaned and sanitized. 7.* Health screening procedures are incomplete:, No-contact thermometer is not provided, attestation is not required prior to entering the building. 8.* Aside from employees mandated to work in the building at this time, the district encourages other employees to work in the building at will. There is no clear screening process, and there is no plan for managing this influx of employees moving in and out of the building throughout the day.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1904.4(a) - Recording Criteria * The employer did not keep records of fatalities, injuries, and illnesses that were work-related. OSH Act 5(a)(1) - General Duty Clause The employer did not furnish a place of employment that was free from recognized hazards that are causing or are likely to cause death or serious physical harm to employees. Under the general duty clause, employers must protect employees from COVID-19 hazards at the workplace by: * Ensuring social distancing at the facitlity. * Identifying and isolating suspected COVID-19 cases. * Adhering to CDC COVID-19 PPE for Healthcare Personnel * Having a plan for monitoring and assigning work restrictions for ill and exposed HCP.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The staff and the public was not notified concerning the positive COVID case at the facility. 2. The building was not sanitized, and business went on as normal after the positive case was confirmed. 3. Staff is allowed to wear their mask below their nose, on their chin, or not at all. 4. Staff has not been made aware of any new protocols concerning COVID-19. 5. Guardians and patients allowed to enter the facility without a mask. 6. Staff is not required to screen or take their temperature before entering the facility. 7. Thermometers are accessible to young children who often grab them, bang them on the table or try to put in their mouth, plus the thermometers are not cleaned or sanitized after each use. 8. Staff not allowed enough time to wipe down tables, therapy materials, and door handles before the next patient is seen.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Respiratory protection The employer requires workers use respirators depending on task. Employer did not provide medical evaluations or a fit testing. Spray finishing Primarily compressed air and airless systems are used with solvent paints and epoxies. No power coatings. Paint (Particulates) frequently migrate into the break room, which is adjacent to the spray booth/room area. - Workers often use the spray room without required respiratory protection. - Workers suffer fatigue after spraying paint with zinc. Sand-Blasting Separate building (shed) Dedicated dust collector and ductwork is not maintained (cleaned and serviced). Sand blasting and paint debris can be seen escaping ductwork into the storm drains. - Safety Training Employer includes Confined Space, Fall protection, COVID 19, and various operating certificates (forklift, man lift, etc.). Employer often asks EE¿s who have not been trained to operate equipment as a workaround to completing projects on time. Untrained EE¿s perform tasks that require training because they feel obligated in order to keep their job. There are many employees operating machinery without proper training or certifications. Safety Meetings: Business employs 20-30. No weekly safety meetings are conducted. No sign in or records of meetings are known of. There is no safety committee Flammable Storage and Handling This may include paints, thinners, and epoxies. Opened solvents are piled up at the entrance to shop instead of placed in storage location at the main shop. A separate site facility is used to store additional flammable materials with same housekeeping issues. General physical safety hazards include slip trip hazards on the floor due to buildup of paint and paint debris. Workers had to climb on top of unsafe trailers and other projects to either paint or sand blast and were not provided fall protection: harness tie ins or proper scaffolding. COVID 19 Workers come in contact / no quarantine. Location of the hazards include: HUNNICUTTS INC 3910 Bakerview Spur Bellingham, WA 98226 and Dakota Creek Industries Anacortes WA.

workers often use the spray room without required respiratory protection. - workers suffer fatigue after spraying paint with zinc. sand-blasting separate building (shed) dedicated dust collector and ductwork is not maintained (cleaned and serviced). sand blasting and paint debris can be seen escaping ductwork into the storm drains. - Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. In the work area employees are unable to stand more than 2 feet (or less) from each other, meaning that co-workers can very easily be exposed to Covid-19. 2. Employees are not allowed to wear gloves, unless they are preparing food. We are dealing directly with the public when working the drive-thru window and we are being told that gloves are not allowed due to a shortage. 3. Some employees decided to wear face masks, we were told by management they are not allowed in the food place because they carry germs. 4. Gloves are not mandatory at this particular facility. Members of management have been observed preparing food without gloves being worn. 5. The company does not have, nor do they enforce handwashing guidelines. 6. Employee working the drive-thru requested that a plastic shield be installed. Management said other McDonald¿s have tried shields and it caused spillage of food and beverages. 7. There are no disinfecting guidelines put in place, employees are bringing in their own Lysol and Clorox wipes to disinfect commonly touched surfaces.
