Hazard.Desc.Loc: The employer had not identified and addressed the hazard posed by COVID-19 in the workplace in the following way: 1. The employer does not require and enforce physical distancing and allows employees to work within 6 feet of each other. Desks are set up with workstations within 6 feet of each other and are directly adjacent to active aisle ways. Employees in meetings don't maintain physical distancing. Employees frequently disregard the maximum occupancy sign on the lunchroom. 2. The employer does not require and enforce the use of face coverings in the workplace. Employees working next to aisle ways where other employees frequently pass don't wear face coverings. Some employees wear face coverings but then pull them down to speak. 3. The employer does not ensure that commonly touched surfaces are sanitized. In practice, employees do not wipe down and sanitize shared workstations when they leave. There is no policy or enforcement to ensure these shared workstations are sanitized. Ref. Title 8 CCR 3203(a)(4)(6).

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. One employee worked Tue. July 7th 2020. She received a positive covid test Wednesday. She had been tested prior to coming in to work. They doubted the results and they were retested and confirmed positive the same day. The manager closed the shop for cleaning and shared on Facebook that it was a "possible" infection, when in fact was twice confirmed. Then she contacted those exposed (3-4 employees) to the covid positive person, as they worked together for a shift in a very tight and impossible to socially distance area. She instructed the exposed employee to get tested immediately and is encouraging them to get rapid testing. She wants to be able to add exposed employees to the schedule asap. 2. Management is NOT recommending 14 day quarantine or testing at a reasonable time-frame so that the virus could be detected. They apply a lot of pressure to the exposed employees to return to work. Management is informing staff that the virus is only contagious for 48 hours. They are pressuring testing in less than 48 hours from exposure. Management informed employees that because they wear masks it is safe to come to work sooner than 14 days. 3. The owner of Biggby currently has all three of the exposed people on the schedule for the week of July 13. 4. The Genesee County Health Department indicated that these exposed people should not be working. The owner said that they were cleared to work by the health department, the health department asserts that have issued no such clearance (as of July 13th 2020).
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: 1. one employee worked tue. july 7th 2020. she received a positive covid test wednesday. she had been tested prior to coming in to work. they doubted the results and they were retested and confirmed positive the same day. the manager closed the shop for cleaning and shared on facebook that it was a "possible" infection, when in fact was twice confirmed. then she contacted those exposed (3-4 employees) to the covid positive person, as they worked together for a shift in a very tight and impossible to socially distance area. she instructed the exposed employee to get tested immediately and is encouraging them to get rapid testing. she wants to be able to add exposed employees to the schedule asap. 2. management is not recommending 14 day quarantine or testing at a reasonable time-frame so that the virus could be detected. they apply a lot of pressure to the exposed employees to return to work. management is informing staff that the virus is only contagious for 48 hours. they are pressuring testing in less than 48 hours from exposure. management informed employees that because they wear masks it is safe to come to work sooner than 14 days. 3. the owner of biggby currently has all three of the exposed people on the schedule for the week of july 13. 4. the genesee county health department indicated that these exposed people should not be working. the owner said that they were cleared to work by the health department, the health department asserts that have issued no such clearance (as of july 13th 2020).

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Amentum employee(s) are exposed to possible COVID-19 when flying on the same flights as military personnel who are not being required to wear face coverings. Face coverings are not being enforced on flights while social distancing is not practical. 2. Amentum employee(s) are exposed to possible COVID-19 from military personnel that enter the work center without being required to wear CDC recommended face coverings or social distancing. Management is aware and state they have no control over military personnel. 3. Employee(s) are exposed to fall hazards from unsafe ladders used in the hangar bays. Ladders and guarding have open gaps that someone could fall through. 4. Employee(s) are exposed to rat, roaches, vermin, and vermin feces in the break areas where employees eat on a regular basis. This includes on and around the tables. Pest control was only utilized one time. 5. Employee(s) are exposed to over-heating temperatures in the summer months or extremely low temperatures in the winter months while working in the fuel pits for extended periods of time without frequent breaks, shelter, or water.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Air has been out for two weeks and it's been atleast 100 degrees in there. Workers are forced to wear masks for 8.5 hour shifts. After 5 days of this management finally bought 5 small fans for the whole 3 story building and brings around water once maybe twice a day. Water is located on the third floor somewhere that management only has access to. Water needs to be available in all floor so we can get when we need. Most times people are calling off or going home sick leaving people working by themselves and cannot leave register for a break. Bathrooms are clogged up and others are closed off due to covid. Air is bad and is health issue. Escalator along with elevator breaks down all the time. Floors on 1st floor are all tore up due to building shifting. This is not safe especially with covid. You need to come out immediately and access's this situation we have been working in the past two weeks. They claim air will be working Thursday so come before that! I can't believe we haven't notified you sooner. Management has not taken heat exhaustion serious. Many people feel sick and still work because they need a paycheck. We were called back promised extra cleaning, air ventilation things to make us feel safe. It's been horrible and not right. Nobody should have to work like this! Everyone complains of headaches and lightheadedness and sick.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer does not have an implemented site specific COVID-19 Illness Prevention Plan in place and is not meeting all of the requirements of the VOSH Permanent COVID-19 Final Standard, including not having any procedures in place for employee wellness screenings at the start of each shift, not providing employee face coverings and not requiring all customer facing employees in areas with substantial and high transmission rates to wear face coverings, not conducting a COVID-19 hazard risk assessment for all employees, and not conducting employee training on the employer¿s site specific COVID-19 prevention plan, or on the hazards of COVID-19 and how to recognize it. 2. The customer store area, including check-out counters, frequently touched surfaces, etc. are not being not being sanitized at least once per shift to meet the VOSH Permanent COVID-19 Final Standard sanitizing requirements. In addition, no deep cleaning is being performed of the building after a positive case of COVID-19 has been reported to management and management is not notifying employees of their possible exposure to COVID-19 when a positive case of COVID-19 has occurred. 3. The customer bathroom, which is also used occasionally by management and staff is not being maintained in a clean and sanitary condition and the bathroom is not being sanitized at least once per shift to meet the VOSH Permanent COVID-19 Final Standard sanitizing requirements. Urine is dried on the floor around the base of the toilet bowl and beneath the toilet tank. (See photo 1). 4. In the employee break room area, the table is jammed against stacked boxes of bulk candy boxes being stored behind it. The 3 table chairs are stained and caked with food and are not being sanitized properly and remains of food and candy are left on the floor and not being swept up. In addition, the seating in the break room is not set up to allow 6 foot spacing between employees to help prevent the spread of COVID-19 and the break room is not being sanitized at least once each shift in accordance with the VOSH Permanent COVID-19 Final Standard. (See 2nd photo). 5. The staff bathroom is not being maintained in a clean and sanitary condition and is not being cleaned at least once per shift to meet the VOSH Permanent COVID-19 Final Standard sanitizing requirements. Urine is dried on the floor around the base of the toilet bowl and beneath the toilet tank and there is a black sticky gunk all around the floor. (See 3rd photo). 6. The staff utility sink area is not being maintained in a clean and sanitary condition and is not being cleaned at least once per shift to meet the VOSH Permanent COVID-19 Final Standard sanitizing requirements. In addition, a mop bucket with used water and dirty cups and utensils, all of which had mold growing in them were being left in the utility sink without being emptied and cleaned. In addition, the utility sink is grimy with slime growing on the bottom and sides. (See photos 4 and 5). 7. The staff utility sink is not being adequately provided with soap, towels, and a trash can for waste towels for employee use as required by the VOSH standards. 8. Different containers of incompatible leaking chemicals are being left in the utility sink permanently, instead of being disposed of properly per the instructions on their Safety Data Sheets. The employer does not have an adequate site specific Hazard Communication Program and staff have not been provided with any training on how to clean up and properly dispose of any spilled chemicals.
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: 1. the employer does not have an implemented site specific covid-19 illness prevention plan in place and is not meeting all of the requirements of the vosh permanent covid-19 final standard, including not having any procedures in place for employee wellness screenings at the start of each shift, not providing employee face coverings and not requiring all customer facing employees in areas with substantial and high transmission rates to wear face coverings, not conducting a covid-19 hazard risk assessment for all employees, and not conducting employee training on the employer¿s site specific covid-19 prevention plan, or on the hazards of covid-19 and how to recognize it. 2. the customer store area, including check-out counters, frequently touched surfaces, etc. are not being not being sanitized at least once per shift to meet the vosh permanent covid-19 final standard sanitizing requirements. in addition, no deep cleaning is being performed of the building after a positive case of covid-19 has been reported to management and management is not notifying employees of their possible exposure to covid-19 when a positive case of covid-19 has occurred. 3. the customer bathroom, which is also used occasionally by management and staff is not being maintained in a clean and sanitary condition and the bathroom is not being sanitized at least once per shift to meet the vosh permanent covid-19 final standard sanitizing requirements. urine is dried on the floor around the base of the toilet bowl and beneath the toilet tank. (see photo 1). 4. in the employee break room area, the table is jammed against stacked boxes of bulk candy boxes being stored behind it. the 3 table chairs are stained and caked with food and are not being sanitized properly and remains of food and candy are left on the floor and not being swept up. in addition, the seating in the break room is not set up to allow 6 foot spacing between employees to help prevent the spread of covid-19 and the break room is not being sanitized at least once each shift in accordance with the vosh permanent covid-19 final standard. (see 2nd photo). 5. the staff bathroom is not being maintained in a clean and sanitary condition and is not being cleaned at least once per shift to meet the vosh permanent covid-19 final standard sanitizing requirements. urine is dried on the floor around the base of the toilet bowl and beneath the toilet tank and there is a black sticky gunk all around the floor. (see 3rd photo). 6. the staff utility sink area is not being maintained in a clean and sanitary condition and is not being cleaned at least once per shift to meet the vosh permanent covid-19 final standard sanitizing requirements. in addition, a mop bucket with used water and dirty cups and utensils, all of which had mold growing in them were being left in the utility sink without being emptied and cleaned. in addition, the utility sink is grimy with slime growing on the bottom and sides. (see photos 4 and 5). 7. the staff utility sink is not being adequately provided with soap, towels, and a trash can for waste towels for employee use as required by the vosh standards. 8. different containers of incompatible leaking chemicals are being left in the utility sink permanently, instead of being disposed of properly per the instructions on their safety data sheets. the employer does not have an adequate site specific hazard communication program and staff have not been provided with any training on how to clean up and properly dispose of any spilled chemicals.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1 There is an outbreak of Covid-19 illness in this facility. Out of a total of approximately 200 employees, thirty ( 30 ) employees who work during the twilight sort, sixty ( 60 ) employees who work during the midnight sort, and thirty ( 30 ) employees during the day shift, are sick with Covid-19. 2 Employees who are Covid-19 positive, and symptomatic with fever, coughing, and sneezing, are coming to work during all shifts, in the hub, sorting areas, and the offices. 3 In the feeder department office, 5 employees sick with Covid-19 including two supervisors came to work sick, between January 11 to January 22, 2021. These symptomatic workers infected other employees they were in close contact with, who are now themselves sick with Covid-19. 4 Employees are not social distancing. The employer is not enforcing social distancing rules and policies. 5 In the hub employees are not wearing face mask coverings. The employer is not enforcing face mask covering rules and policies. 6 Employees that could telework are not allowed to telework, in an office where positive employees have come to work sick,and infecting other employees with Covid-19. 7 Employees are not screened for fever or symptoms upon entry into the facility. The employer has asked employees to download and use a prescreening smartphone application to self check or report temperatures and symptoms, but employees are not even doing that. 8 There is no hand sanitizer bottles in the offices, nor the hub or sorting areas.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Information for Virginia school systems, such as Henry County, Virginia, that have school buildings with individual heating and cooling units in each classroom. The units are designed to circulate the classroom air only and utilize no outside air. The units are mounted on the bottom of the classroom wall, up to waist level and around 5 feet long. Air, from inside the classroom, is pulled into the bottom of the unit and blows out the top. The units cool or heat the classrooms as needed. There are hundreds of these units, in a school building, in EACH CLASSROOM. Classroom air is being recirculated within each individual classroom. A couple of senareos would be a child or teacher positive with COVID-19 and not even know it. The contagious individual is eating lunch, in the classroom, and talks, coughs or sneezes. The contagious individual, pulls down their face covering, to scratch their nose and talks, coughs or sneezes. The droplets are pulled into the individual classroom heating/cooling unit and dispersed throughout the entire classroom infecting multiple individuals.The design of a school buildings heating and cooling system must be considered in these unprecedented times, to maintain the safety of all Virginians young and old. Virginia school buildings, with heating/cooling units as described above, pose a high risk of transmission of COVID-19.
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: information for virginia school systems, such as henry county, virginia, that have school buildings with individual heating and cooling units in each classroom. the units are designed to circulate the classroom air only and utilize no outside air. the units are mounted on the bottom of the classroom wall, up to waist level and around 5 feet long. air, from inside the classroom, is pulled into the bottom of the unit and blows out the top. the units cool or heat the classrooms as needed. there are hundreds of these units, in a school building, in each classroom. classroom air is being recirculated within each individual classroom. a couple of senareos would be a child or teacher positive with covid-19 and not even know it. the contagious individual is eating lunch, in the classroom, and talks, coughs or sneezes. the contagious individual, pulls down their face covering, to scratch their nose and talks, coughs or sneezes. the droplets are pulled into the individual classroom heating/cooling unit and dispersed throughout the entire classroom infecting multiple individuals.the design of a school buildings heating and cooling system must be considered in these unprecedented times, to maintain the safety of all virginians young and old. virginia school buildings, with heating/cooling units as described above, pose a high risk of transmission of covid-19.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer did not give notice of potential COVID-19 exposure to all employees who may have had COVID-19 exposure. Ref 8CCR3205(c)(3)(B)3a 2. The employer did not provide training and instruction in the importance of frequent hand washing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds and using hand sanitizer when employees do not have immediate access to a sink or hand washing facility, and that hand sanitizer does not work if the hands are soiled. Ref 8CCR3205(c)(5(F) 3. Employers shall provide face coverings and ensure they are worn by employees. Ref 8CCR3205(c)(7)(A) 4. Employers shall implement measures to communicate to non-employees the face coverings requirements on their premises. Ref 8CCR320S(c)(7)(E) 5. Employers shall implement cleaning and disinfecting procedures, which require cleaning and disinfection of areas, material, and equipment used by a COVID- 1 9case during the high-risk exposure period. Ref 8CCR3205(c)(8)(C)3 6. The employer did not ensure that COVID-19 cases are excluded from the workplace until the return to work requirements of subsection (c)(ll) are met. Ref 8CCR3205(c)(10)(A)

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1) Employees are exposed to health hazards associated with COVID-19. It was reported that the facility is not ensuring employees are wearing masks and practicing social distancing requirements outlined by the CDC guidelines. Contrary to section 5(a)1 of the OSH Act. 2) It was reported that the facility is not cleaned and/or disinfected accordance with CDC guidelines. Contrary to Section 5(a)1 of the OSH Act. 3.) Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer has not provided the correct materials and personal protective equipment (PPE) to safely sanitize the assigned buildings. 2. We have not been trained to handle a situation involving COVID-19. 3. When employees of the buildings that are being cleaned test positive for COVID-19 we are still required to appear at work (without adequate PPE) or lose our jobs. 4. There was a company wide email that was sent stating if an employee shows symptoms or there is an outbreak at an assigned building management is to send all the employees¿ home for 14 days with pay. I believe I was showing mild symptoms of COVID-19 and it was only after multiple days of deliberating my supervisor came to the conclusion to send me home for seven days without pay. 5. I was also notified the company has received hazard pay for the employees and we have not seen any kind of pay incentive.

The bleach water no longer disinfects after 24hours of being mixed. No hand sanitizer is available or offered and in most circumstances social distancing is not possible with no accommodations made to attempt it. They give out sheets talking about social distancing, but do not practice it. They still have line up meetings. We do not have anything to disinfect our shared computer keyboards and mouses and any other shared electronic. There are no measures in place to prevent sick employees from coming into the work place. There are also no masks available even when social distancing is not possible.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The following workplace conditions raise concerns about the potential for employee illness(es) related to potential exposure to SARS-CoV-2 (severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2), the virus causing coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19): The facility has not implemented appropriate controls in response to potential exposures of COVID-19 throughout the plant. These include: 1. Employees who have taken the COVID-19 test are not required to quarantine, while awaiting test results. 2. Employees who have tested positive for COVID-19 are allowed to return to work without a negative test result. Employees who have tested positive have been allowed back on site after two days. 3. Employees receive a temperature check prior to entry into the facility. If the temperature is elevated, they are instructed to return to their car, and sit with the AC on until they cool off, or to drink something cold, and return for another test. 4. Employees sweating heavily and with elevated temperature (fever) are allowed to enter facility, and work. 5. The employer is not disinfecting the facility. 6. The employer is not enforcing social distancing. Employees are allowed to crowd into the break area and face coverings not required. 7. Work-related fatalities and hospitalizations are not recorded on the OSHA 300 logs.
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: the following workplace conditions raise concerns about the potential for employee illness(es) related to potential exposure to sars-cov-2 (severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2), the virus causing coronavirus disease 2019 (covid-19): the facility has not implemented appropriate controls in response to potential exposures of covid-19 throughout the plant. these include: 1. employees who have taken the covid-19 test are not required to quarantine, while awaiting test results. 2. employees who have tested positive for covid-19 are allowed to return to work without a negative test result. employees who have tested positive have been allowed back on site after two days. 3. employees receive a temperature check prior to entry into the facility. if the temperature is elevated, they are instructed to return to their car, and sit with the ac on until they cool off, or to drink something cold, and return for another test. 4. employees sweating heavily and with elevated temperature (fever) are allowed to enter facility, and work. 5. the employer is not disinfecting the facility. 6. the employer is not enforcing social distancing. employees are allowed to crowd into the break area and face coverings not required. 7. work-related fatalities and hospitalizations are not recorded on the osha 300 logs.

Employees are concerned that The Lodge will lack precautions when opened and have the same issues as The Fountain did.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Employer not enforcing social distancing Employer not providing PPE such as gloves, masks, face shields, etc. Business operating even though business classified as nonessential Other - The hospital is not enforcing social on the unit nor during treatment groups. They are trying, but our clients are routinely exposed to each other and staff during treatment groups and while being transported in a line. PPE is limited, and the provided mask is comically small for my face. I can feel air rushing in around the seal with each breath. I asked for a better mask or respirator when a mysterious respiratory illness ripped through all 20 of my patients last week, but was told they were extremely limited and being saved for some ambiguous time. No face shields are available, even after request. Gloves are readily available, thankfully. Although the state hospital is clearly an essential business, mental health therapists are being forced to report to work for face-to-face groups when they could very easily be conducted via teleconference. The rehabilitation department is a prime example of this, as they were deemed non-essential to the safety and security of the hospital until the emergency paid sick leave (FFCRA) was passed. Conveniently, the rehab dept. has now been deemed essential and are being forced to conduct groups in-person, although no members of the rehabilitation department are allowed on the designated "isolation unit," as they are non-essential to the safety and security of the patients. Their presence simply exposes our clients and staff to more possible sources of the virus and jeopardizes the health of our clients.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Approximately 70 employees are exposed to the following alleged hazards facility-wide: 1. Employees are not being provided with adequate PPE such as, but not limited to, face coverings/face mask and gloves. PPE is not being provided to employees and paid for by employer. An employee tested positive or was exposed to COVID-19 that was working at the facility. 2. Employees operating forklifts have had accidents within the last six months without being re-trained. 3. Employees are exposed to fall hazards while working from heights without utilizing fall protection. Employees are provided with harnesses when working from heights however they are not being required to wear harnesses through supervision and enforcement. 4. Employees are not being provided with training and communication in their native language. Employees were provided with a letter notifying employees of an employee who tested positive or was exposed to COVID-19 however the letter was in English and not provided and communicated to employees in their native language.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. Employees on the production floor or unit must maintain communications by close interactions with each other for safety due to the nature of the work being loud and dangerous therefore not allowing for the mandatory 6 foot Social Distancing rule. 2. Materials and tools are shared, used and handled by employees without being disinfected. Employees wear gloves and the employer has implemented some rules to try to avoid cross contamination but the employer needs to do more. 3. The employer allows more than 10 people to gather in small congested tool cribs in addition, employees lean on the counter while waiting. 4. The dispensary is not equip to handle the recent influx of people with any illness. To have people coming in due to COVID-19 symptoms would be putting people at risk. Employees were instructed to call for emergency personnel/Fire Marshall Office should a worker feel sick. 5. Cafeteria tables are not cleaned and disinfected regularly. Half of the tables were removed from the cafeteria now people are sitting more to a table. 6. Turnstiles are not disinfected.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Hazard Description: Employee alleges that employer is not following CDC requirements for COVID-19 positive patients by leaving patient doors open which further exposes staff to COVID-19 on the 5th floor of the West Wing. Employee alleges they are being told the doors need to be left open in order to maintain a negative pressure environment. Additionally, employee is concerned that staff do not have a separate break area from this location. Employee alleges that employer is not ensuring the proper donning/doffing of Personal Protective Equipment while caring for COVID-19 positive patients through training. Location: 5th Floor of West Wing. Second employee complaint alleges that the employer does not have a sufficient health screening process for employees, prior to the commencement of work. . The employee alleges that employees do not take their temperatures like they should be and there is no longer oversight of this process by the employer. Location: Main Hospital at 160 Allen Street in Rutland VT.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1) Employees are exposed to COVID-19 hazards. It is reported that employees that are symptomatic of COVID-19 have been at work and, at times, remove their masks while working, exposing other employees to the illness. Contrary to Section 5(a)(1) of the OSH Act. 2) Employees are exposed to COVID-19 hazards. It is reported that, while in close proximity to other employees, wearing a mask is not enforced, exposing employees to COVID-19. Contrary to Section 5(a)(1) of the OSH Act. 3) Employer does not maintain an adequate COVID-19 Prevention Program. It is reported that no enforcement of a mask policy, quarantining of symptomatic employees, or thorough contact tracing is being conducted. Thus exposing employees to hazards of COVID-19. Contrary to Section 5(a)(1) of the OSH Act.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer fails to assess hazards, correct hazards, communicate hazards or provide effective training for the hazard of working in close proximity of persons with symptoms of COVID-19 when the supervisor did not send a worker exhibiting symptoms home, and did not enforce social distancing and did not warn employees working around the sick worker. T8 CCR 3203(a)(3), (4), (6) & (7) 2. The employer has not conducted an effective hazard assessment nor adequately determined proper personal protective equipment (PPE) selection; the employer does not adequately prepare maintenance workers for work with contaminated equipment, vehicles and building; the employer does not eliminate the hazards nor train workers to adequately protect themselves and decontaminate the incoming equipment, themselves and the PPE; the employer does not provide protective clothing, gowns or coveralls for employees working on equipment potentially contaminated with COVID-19. T8 CCR 3380(f)(1-7)

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer failed to review applicable orders and guidance from the State of California and the local health department related to COVID-19 hazards and prevention. Several employees are not following the most recent Alameda County orders that require all people, regardless of vaccination status, to wear face coverings indoors. T8 CCR 3205(c)(2)(F) 2. The employer failed to implement cleaning and disinfecting procedures, which require identifying and regularly cleaning frequently touched surfaces and objects. The employer shall inform employees and authorized employee representatives of cleaning and disinfection protocols, including the planned frequency and scope of cleaning and disinfection. T8 CCR 3205(c)(7)(B)1. 3. The employer failed to ensure refuse and garbage is removed as often as necessary to avoid creating a menace to health through the development of unsanitary conditions. The bathrooms and kitchen have overflowing garbage, causing an odor and unsanitary conditions. T8 CCR 3362(e) 4. The employer failed to ensure toilet facilities are kept clean. Garbage is overflowing and on the floor, and toilets are dirty. T8 CCR 3364(b)

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. It is believed that the employer has been following the CDC guidelines as far as providing personal protective equipment, guards up at the desks, and permitting less people in the building. However, four managers have tested positive within five days (then 4 more employees tested positive...totaling 8 in 10 days and there are still tests pending) and two of those managers did not reveal this information to their supervisors who were still coming into work. Four out of five managers have had positive test results and their supervisors have continued to work in the building until this week. Now the supervisors are out of the building, but they have been in close contact with their team not knowing their managers were positive.

Hazard Location: It is the entire building and all employees and customers that are at risk Note: This complaint includes referrals received 10:58am March 27th, 2020 Not enforcing social distancing, employer is not providing any protection for employees, they offer senior hour but are still allowing anyone in during that time. 10:54am March 31st, 2020 - Anonymous Employer has not placed a cashier barrier (plexiglass), in furniture section. Employer told employees if they want gloves they need to go buy them, they are not monitoring the amount of people that are in the store. There is constantly over 50 customers in the stores all at once. Store was sanitized 2 weeks ago and hasn¿t been touched since. 4:04pm March 31st, 2020 - Anonymous Concerned for the safety of home store department, pharmacy, liquor, apparel and starbucks all are within 2 ft from the customer and there is nothing to protect them. Hazard.Desc.Loc: An employee who had been exposed to COVID 19 at home and was showing signs and symptoms of COVID 19 was not sent home from work. The employee was working with other employees in the warehouse , break room and sales floor areas. The employee was not made to wear a mask, or to socially distance from other employees, and was present in close proximity to approximately 20 other employees during a gathering in a small break room during the work day. These conditions potentially exposed other employees to COVID 19, and when management was asked to address employees concerns about potential exposure to COVID 19 no action was taken.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: It was reported to OSHA that employees are potentially exposed to health hazards associated with COVID-19. It was reported that that the employer has not implemented COVID-19 procedures or precautions such as, but not limited to, training workers about the hazards of COVID-19 and the procedures for employees with possible symptoms of COVID-19. Specifically, it was reported that employees are not required to wear face coverings, social distancing is not being implemented, and that disinfecting supplies are not available for surfaces, equipment, etc. Contrary to Section 5(a)(1) of the OSH Act.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: FoodMaxx locations at 39966 Cedar Boulevard, Newark & 699 Lewelling Boulevard, San Leandro: 1. The employer failed to communicate information about their COVID-19 policies and procedures to employees. Employees have not been provided with the company's COVID-19 Prevention Plan to understand what protocols the company is taking to minimize the risk of COVID-19 infections. Title 8 CCR 3205(c)(1)(D) 2. The employer failed to develop and implement a process for screening employees for and responding to employees with COVID-19 symptoms. The employer may ask employees to evaluate their own symptoms before reporting to work. Title 8 CCR 3205(c)(2)(B) 3. The employer failed to provide face coverings and ensure they are worn by employees when required by orders from the CDPH. The employer does not have an adequate number of face coverings for its employees. Title 8 CCR 3205(c)(6)(B), 3205(c)(6)(H) 4. The employer failed to provide training for employees on the topics of COVID-19. T8 CCR 3205(c)(5) 5. The employer failed to provide employees with an effective hand sanitizer. Title 8 CCR 3205(c)(7)(C) 6. The employer failed to implement cleaning and disinfecting procedures and/or policies which requires identifying and regularly cleaning frequently touched surfaces and objects, such as doorknobs, elevator buttons, equipment, tools, handrails, handles, controls, phones, headsets, bathroom surfaces, and steering wheels. The employer shall inform employees and authorized employee representatives of cleaning and disinfection protocols, including the planned frequency and scope of cleaning and disinfection. T8 CCR 3205(c)(7)(B)(1)
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: foodmaxx locations at 39966 cedar boulevard, newark & 699 lewelling boulevard, san leandro: 1. the employer failed to communicate information about their covid-19 policies and procedures to employees. employees have not been provided with the company's covid-19 prevention plan to understand what protocols the company is taking to minimize the risk of covid-19 infections. title 8 ccr 3205(c)(1)(d) 2. the employer failed to develop and implement a process for screening employees for and responding to employees with covid-19 symptoms. the employer may ask employees to evaluate their own symptoms before reporting to work. title 8 ccr 3205(c)(2)(b) 3. the employer failed to provide face coverings and ensure they are worn by employees when required by orders from the cdph. the employer does not have an adequate number of face coverings for its employees. title 8 ccr 3205(c)(6)(b), 3205(c)(6)(h) 4. the employer failed to provide training for employees on the topics of covid-19. t8 ccr 3205(c)(5) 5. the employer failed to provide employees with an effective hand sanitizer. title 8 ccr 3205(c)(7)(c) 6. the employer failed to implement cleaning and disinfecting procedures and/or policies which requires identifying and regularly cleaning frequently touched surfaces and objects, such as doorknobs, elevator buttons, equipment, tools, handrails, handles, controls, phones, headsets, bathroom surfaces, and steering wheels. the employer shall inform employees and authorized employee representatives of cleaning and disinfection protocols, including the planned frequency and scope of cleaning and disinfection. t8 ccr 3205(c)(7)(b)(1)

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Employees are concerned with exposure to the coronavirus (COVID-19) due to the employer's failure to adhere to OSHA/CDC recommendations such as: -Operational and communications preparations for COVID-19 -Screening and temperature check protocols for incoming individuals, staff, and visitors -Infection control, including recommended personal protective equipment (PPE) and potential alternatives during PPE shortages -Encouraging sick employees to stay home -Enhanced cleaning/disinfecting and hygiene practices -Healthcare evaluation for suspected cases, including testing for COVID-19 -Clinical care for confirmed and suspected cases -Considerations for persons at higher risk of severe disease from COVID-19 -Medical isolation of confirmed and suspected cases and quarantine of contacts, including considerations for cohorting when individual spaces are limited -Social distancing strategies to increase space between individuals in the facility
Hazard.Desc.Loc.lt: employees are concerned with exposure to the coronavirus (covid-19) due to the employer's failure to adhere to osha/cdc recommendations such as: -operational and communications preparations for covid-19 -screening and temperature check protocols for incoming individuals, staff, and visitors -infection control, including recommended personal protective equipment (ppe) and potential alternatives during ppe shortages -encouraging sick employees to stay home -enhanced cleaning/disinfecting and hygiene practices -healthcare evaluation for suspected cases, including testing for covid-19 -clinical care for confirmed and suspected cases -considerations for persons at higher risk of severe disease from covid-19 -medical isolation of confirmed and suspected cases and quarantine of contacts, including considerations for cohorting when individual spaces are limited -social distancing strategies to increase space between individuals in the facility

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer has provided plastic catering gloves instead of surgical gloves to drivers who are handling lab samples packages. The drivers are in the position of being exposed to bloodborne disease if the packages break open. 2. There are no protocols to include training in place on how to handle lab samples packages with bloodborne disease. We were never informed to sanitize our vehicles after handling the packages. 3. Lab samples packages are not labeled with the proper bloodborne diseases contained within. The lab sample packages have the tendencies to open up while transporting them to their destination. 4. There are unauthorized and personnel not affiliated with the company riding with drivers when picking up and delivering packages. 5. The employers has not provided any guidelines or procedures on COVID-19 such as, not limited to posters, self-identifications for having the COVID-19 symptoms and quarantine employees who tested positive for COVID-19.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer was well aware that there were three (3) confirmed cases of Coronavirus but those staff with close contact were never formally notified and all church activities were kept open. The staff alone has at least ten (10) cases. Many employees have had direct contact (i.e., 15-minutes or longer) with infected staff members. Several staff that initially tested negative have now tested positive. The staff demanded that the preschool be closed but management decided to keep it open until the fundraiser was finished. The preschool closed but none of the parents were informed of the positive cases. 2. The preschool director and many of the staff do not wear masks during teaching time and are told by the director as long as she does not see it employees can do what they want. 3. The church does not have a COVID preparedness plan.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. On June 8th, I was denied a face shield first night even though I was told that workers would be within 3 feet of me while working. I was told if I didn't like that they were not providing face shields, to go home. Went back the next night, June 9, where I did not receive any safety training and was given my temperature check INSIDE the building with approximately 50 other workers who were also waiting for their temperature and health screenings. I worked for 6 hours after begging to multiple supervisors for a face shield, and informed that I had to clean the tools and machines from the previous workers. No additional cleaning staff had been hired. I had to beg for cleaning supplies too. Cleaning supplies were hidden at the supervisor's desk. No hand sanitizer was available on the shop floor. I left 2 hours early because they are not staggering shifts or break times. All 350 production employees are at risk with these concerns. Although they have designated entrances and exits, once workers are inside the building, there is no attempt to keep shifts separate. Break times are the usual schedule and many workers still shift jobs and co-workers throughout the shift. The next day, June 10, I was supposed to attend there safety meeting, but instead was called to meet with the production manager, HR and safety coordinator, where I gave all concerns. They claimed they were meeting CDC guidelines and had no intention of making any changes to their practices. They sent me home and told me not to return to work until they got back to me the next week. June 19, I was informed that they denied my request for a layoff due to the unsafe working environment and if I do not report to work on Monday, June 22, I would be terminated.

The employer failed to maintain each workroom floor in a clean and, to the extent feasible, in a dry condition. Hazard.Desc.Loc: Violations of the following OSHA standards at the Montefiore Moses, Weiler, Westchester Square, Hutchinson Medical Center, or Montefiore Medical Center clinics: 1904 Failure to provide OSHA 300 Logs of Work-Related Injuries and Illnesses requested by the New York State Nurses Association on Friday, April 10th, 2020. 1910.132 No written, certified hazard assessment for COVID-10 is available. Fit testing is not being conducted on the types of respirators provided to staff to ensure a proper fit and seal. Nurses providing direct care to patients with confirmed COVID-19 are provided with gowns that are not fluid-resistant or impermeable and do not fully cover the back of the wearer. In addition, only one gown is provided per nurse per day, which creates additional infection control risk as the viral load on the gown becomes very high. Nurses are given one face shield per day and are told to clean them. The excessive use and cleaning process sometimes cause the face shield to break apart. Staff are not given access to additional face shields in a timely manner. This even includes nurses who are performing aerosol-generating procedures such as intubation on patients with confirmed COVID-19. Inconsistent or no training is provided to staff regarding safe donning and doffing of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE). Some receive video training, some receive text messages, and some receive no training at all. 1910.134 Staff are not being fit tested on the N95 respirators currently being provided. Montefiore does not have a range of sizes and types of respirators available. The 3M model 1860 N95 respirator currently being provided to nurses is causing medical reactions in many wearers including headaches, skin irritation and skin infections. Montefiore is not conducting safe procedures for discarding and cleaning disposable respirators that are in compliance with manufacturer instructions. 3M and other disposable respirator manufactures have stated that there is no proven method to safely decontaminate disposable respirator models while maintaining the fit and integrity of the respirator. In one facility a garbage bag is hanging on a wall with a sign that says, "Dispose of N95s here." It is not clear what is happening with those used respirators. Other nurses are being told that they must submit their disposable respirator to be auto-cleaned each day. This cleaning will be conducted 5 times and then a new respirator will be issued. Again, no form of cleaning/decontaminating disposable N95s has been approved by disposable respirator manufacturers. 1910.1030 Section 5(a)(1) Staff are not being provided with "clean" (uncontaminated) spaces to eat and drink during their shifts.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer failed to ensure that exits are maintained free of all obstructions and impediments to full instant use in the case of a fire or other emergency. Boxes are stacked next to and directly in front of the exit, especially during deliveries. The path between the kitchen and dining room is also blocked by boxes. T8 CCR 3225(a)(1) & 3272(b) 2. The employer failed to ensure that approved first-aid materials are stocked and replenished as necessary and readily available for employees. T8 CCR 3400(c) 3. The employer failed to provide hand protection, such as gloves or other tools, to all employees required to handle hot objects, such as metal food containers heated by boiling water and steam. T8 CCR 3384(a) 4. The employer failed to train employees on how to safely handle hot food and metal food containers. Additionally, the employer has not effectively trained the cooks in a language they understand. T8 CCR 3203(a)(7) 5. The employer failed to post the CAL/OSHA Notice of Employee Protections and Obligations entitled "Safety and Health Protection on the Job," in the workplace. T8 CCR 340 6. The employer failed to ensure that all employees in the kitchen wear face coverings when indoors. T8 CCR 3205(c)(6)(A) & (c)(2)(F) 7. The employer failed to ensure that employees are protected against slips and falls. Employees are directed to walk through the kitchen immediately after cooks mop the floors. T8 CCR 3273(a) 8. The employer failed to address uncontrolled accumulation of water where the draft beer is drained and in display bottles, leading to the growth of mold. T8 CCR 3362(g) 9. The employer failed to implement an effective hazard communication program. The employer failed to label all containers containing hazardous chemicals, including spray bottles used to clean tables. Additionally, the employer has failed to gather and make available Safety Data Sheets for all hazardous chemicals in the workplace. T8 CCR 5194(e)(1)

Hazard.Desc.Loc: HAZARD DESCRIPTION: 1. The employer is not requiring employees or clients to observe the 6 foot social distance rule. There have been over 100 clients coming in back to back and have been in close proximity, at the check in kiosks, at the screening booths and at the beds where plasma is drawn. After screening, the line to draw plasma may go all the way down the stairs. Several of the co-workers are older and some have respiratory conditions. Employees believe they may be exposed to Covid-19. The employer also does not provide employees with face masks only face shields but they are not always effective against airborne particles. The beds are only 1 1/2 to 2 feet apart and a phlebotomist may have a client at both beds to their sides. HAZARD LOCATION: The check in kiosks and the screening booths are on 1st floor, the beds are upstairs. There are two shifts, hours are between 6am to 7pm. 3/20/2020 ebm

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Under the Governor's executive order is is mandated that dental offices complete emergency treatment only. However, Afdent has continued to complete non emergency treatment and see patients for regular exams and procedures that are not considered emergent. They have been completing fillings, crown preps, comprehensive exams, taking impressions for orthodontic retainers and replacing them, etc etc. They have not been preserving PPE and have only just within the last week obtained N-95 masks for staff to use. This is a substantial concern due to the fact that dental procedures create aerosol from the patient's mouth and stay suspended in the air for hours and also subsequently get "splashed" or sprayed in a dental health care provider's face for extended periods of time. Currently the guidelines state that the use of a dental hand piece is non essential unless there is no avoiding it. Dental offices are to be using hand tools that do not create aerosol and if it is absolutely necessary to do so, they must do so in a negative air pressure room. Afdent has been using handpieces routinely on a daily basis several times per day for NON emergency treatment. I have personally spoken to friends / family that have confirmed with me that they have had appointments during the stay at home order that were not emergencies.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Destiny Dental continues to be in violation of and non-compliant with the following Infection Control Standards: Blood Borne Pathogens Standards, 29 CFR 1910.1030, 1910.1030 (g)(2); PPE Standard, 29 CFR 1910.132; Respiratory Protection Standard, 29 CFR 1910.134 as follows: Dental Assistants & Dentists: 1. Assistants do not thoroughly disinfect the operatories between patients. 1910.1030 (d)(4)(ii); Blood spatter was left on the overhead light and other items from prior patient(s). 2. Assistants (sometimes the dentists) do not wear lab coats nor gowns. Not even during procedures! Often times, the assistants (and the dentists) do not wear face masks or safety glasses during procedures and exams. 3. Assistants and Dentists have been seen touching things around the office while wearing dirty gloves. 4. On a daily basis, the assistants will team up to do X-rays. One assistant (without a vest on) will be in the room with the patient and the other will be in the hall pushing the button to run the X-ray machine. Anywhere between a single image to an 18 image FMX. 5. Assistants and Dentists go into the reception and break areas with contaminated scrubs, the occasional lab coat, and sometimes even dirty gloves on. 6. Employees are never observed washing their hands or using hand sanitizer. Sterilization Lab: 1. The dirty side and the clean side of the lab are both dirty because everything is touched with bare unwashed hands, or dirty gloved hands by most employees. 2. Instruments are never put into pouches before being run through the autoclave (sterilized). They are run through the autoclave, then put into pouches AFTER they go through, and then put into drawers with non-gloved hands OR left on the counter top for everyone to touch when assistants are looking for the instruments they need for their procedure tray. 3. Many disposable items are being re-used (e.g., the tips on the etch and composite syringes, impression trays, etc.). 4. The only sharps container is kept on the countertop in the lab and is not secured to a wall. It is always full! Laundering PPE; 29 CFR 1910.1030 (d)(4)(iv): 1. There are no on-site laundry facilities. Training; 1910.1030(g)(2): 1. Orientation, initial or beginning employment training is/has not been performed. The assistants train each other. 2. Annual training is/has not been provided to employees on anything (e.g., hazards, exposures, fire safety, BBP, etc.). The only "training" that has been provided is a 10 question online quiz that employees are supposed to take monthly through eagleassociates.net on their own time. The office manager completes this for both of the dentists. General: 1. It is believed that the office manager doesn't have the required paperwork for the COVID-19 preparedness response plan, the exposure control plan, the engineering and work practice controls. 2. Hepatitis B vaccinations were not made available to employees, including the paperwork. 3. There are not enough personal protective equipment supplies, including face masks available for employees. Employees are expected to wear what they are provided for the entire day between patients. 4. There are no emergency lights, lit "Exit" signs, an escape route in case of fire, or accessible fire extinguishers. The employer may not have a fire alarm

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The following conditions exist in all current buildings on site including the pole barn, the hangar, the break room, and the lodge: 1. There is not adequate shade, access to cool or shaded areas, access to cold water, or access to ice. 2. Manual labor is required without the use of basic farm tools such as wheelbarrows. 3. There are no safety or sanitation processes in place for mitigating the spread of COVID-19 and employees do not wear face coverings, primarily because of the oppressive heat and heavy labor required. 4. Social distancing practices are not enforced. 5. There is not a clean restroom, hand soap, or hand sanitizer available throughout the site. 6. Employee lodging is provided without any sanitizing protocols whatsoever. There is no access to clean towels or clean linens, and social distancing requirements are not enforced or even suggested. 7. Approximately 12-20 employees are at risk on any given weekday to COVID-19 spread or infection. 8. Approximately 12-20 employees on any given weekday or Saturday are at risk for heat exhaustion or heat stroke due to poor conditions and scheduling work throughout the hottest part of the day.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The management is not following the Epidemic Orders for COVID Safety in neither of the 3 restaurants. There are no daily questionaires/screening being completed. The working quarters are very limited in space and there is usually close contact with other employees. On 2 occasions, there has been COVID outbreaks in the store on Alpine, 1 being 3 weeks ago where an Assistant Manager's child tested positive for COVID. The Assistant Manager does not regularly wear a mask at work so this exposed the staff, however, Management mandated staff to work with no quarantine, no COVID Testing nor screening for exposed staff. This week another Assistant Manager, who does not regularly wear a mask, also tested positive for COVID and has reported that he infected family members also. At this point, Management is stating that staff still has to work with no quarantine or other action being taken to ensure staff safety. 2. They allow the staff to work short handed and overhours consistently which presents exhausted staff working in dangerous conditions, drunk Assistant Managers, and so on.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: Employer not disinfecting/deep cleaning work place They are making sick individuals come to work anyway even if they have symptoms of Covid19. Without a positive Covid test my employer and HR is pointing employees and employees are facing backlash and getting in trouble. This can greatly increase spread of Covid. Some people cannot seek medical care and requiring doctors notes if an employee is sick with any Covid symptoms. So if a sick employee is not able to get a doctors note or a test for Covid they are coming into work anyway possibly infecting others. The Governors orders stated do not require a doctors note and do not go to work with symptoms, however employees dont have a choice unless they risk raising their points or losing their job and pay. The employer is also not following safe distancing guidelines and the breakroom is full. Nobody has been given any masks or PPE to be in such close proximity and rather than just have the workers they need they have asked extra workers to come in and just sit in case someone does call in sick. Employees are risking their jobs unless they come in sick because without the ability for all sick employees to get a Covid test or a doctors note they have to come in regardless and that is what they are being told by supervisors, those in charge, and the Human Resources department. Even with Covid symptoms. There is even a note posted in the breakroom stating any sick employee must have a doctors note in order to miss work but they will still be pointed even with a doctors note. They also do not allow you to miss work if someone you live with has tested positive they said unless it's you personally and you have a doctors note stating you do have Covid then you have to report to work.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: A mail carrier from the Rose City Park Post Office never wears a mask when delivering mail in the neighborhood. On 4/7/21, their truck number was 6422395. For example, they walk by people walking their dog, and although the dog walkers are wearing masks, the carrier will not make any attempt to maintain six feet of social distancing while not wearing a mask.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: 1. The employer is not implementing adequate safety practices to protect its employees from the spread of SARS-CoV-2 such as, but not limited to: a. Providing face masks to employees for use while at work in areas where social distancing cannot occur. b. Increasing the frequency of cleaning commonly touched surfaces. c. Installing barriers or protective shields between employees and customers. d. Enforcing safety measures such as face covers, additional cleaning, staying home when sick, and social distancing.

Hazard.Desc.Loc: The employer has not provided adequate precautions for employees who are at risk of contracting COVID-19 on the casino gaming floor in that: 1) Respiratory protection other than a surgical mask is not provided for employees, especially dealers and servers who are required to work within six feet of patrons. 2) Employees are required to touch unsanitized surfaces that patrons have touched such as but not limited to cards and chips. 4) The employer is not ensuring that hourly sanitizer use being implemented on the floor per Casino policy. 3) Employees are instructed to not inform anyone if they have a confirmed case of COVID-19. 5) The thermometer used to perform daily temperature checks for employees is not properly calibrated.
